headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Whole Food's First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the program over to Cindy McCann, VP of Investor Relations. You may begin.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Whole Food's First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the program over to Cindy McCann, VP of Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth & Development; and David Landon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations. As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Our press release and scripted remarks are now available on our website. 
I will now turn the call over to Walter Robb.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone, from beautiful Austin, Texas. We're pleased with our Q1 results which reflect continued market share gains, healthy returns and a strong start to fiscal year 2015. Sales grew over 10% to $4.7 billion, with comp
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone, from beautiful Austin, Texas. We're pleased with our Q1 results which reflect continued market share gains, healthy returns and a strong start to fiscal year 2015. Sales grew over 10% to $4.7 billion, with comparable store sales growth accelerating on a one and a 2-year basis. With broad-based momentum across departments, storage, classes and regions, we believe our many strategic initiatives, along with improving consumer confidence, are collectively contributing to our improve results. 
Here are some of the highlights of our progress in Q1. We launched our Values Matter national brand campaign, which you may have seen in TV and print several times over the last few months. It is a real boost to team member morale, and we're looking forward to the final brand tracking results. The early read is very positive, indicating 100% increase in awareness for our target audience, with increases in both value perception and intent to shop versus our measured competitors. We are now providing fresh grocery delivery options to more homes in America than any other food retailer. Since announcing our 15-market partnership with Instacart in September, our average weekly online delivery sales have already passed the $1 million mark. With online delivery sales as high as 5% of total sales in some of our stores, we're very excited about the future potential as we expand our reach to more markets, provide richer content highlighting our quality standards and broaden our product offering. A great example is happening this week for Valentine's Day. We're offering delivery in as little as 1 hour with prices starting at $25 for a dozen of our high-quality, ethically sourced whole trade roses. Orders can be placed in advance and combined with the ability to include chocolates or some other treats, this is a deal that's hard to beat. We're the largest Apple Pay retailer in terms of both transactions and sales, further reinforcing the notion that our customer base wants to take advantage of the latest digital technologies. This payment option has grown quickly to 2% of sales which we expect will continue to increase, especially after the Apple Watch launches this year. We are exploring opportunities to extend this successful partnership, including expanding functionality to support our affinity program. 
Speaking of, we are pleased with the results of our 12-store affinity test, which shows high activation and registration rates and above average basket sizes for participants. We are continuing to incorporate customer feedback as we upgrade and add new features to this program and recently added some new talent to lead our efforts in this area. We're excited to expand the pilot to our Washington, D.C. customers this spring, with hopes of having the program live in the majority of our stores for the 2015 holiday season. And as promised, our new and improved Whole Foods Market app is now live, with nearly 600,000 downloads to date, iOS/Android users can access personalized and local store offers, events and information, along with 3,700 tested recipes where ingredients can be added to shopping lists with a single tap. Stay tuned for more unique and exciting features and updates throughout the year. 
We recognize the changing technology and growing demand for customization and fundamentally altered retailing parameter. Customers expect to connect with the brand whenever, wherever and however they choose. And as part of our broader digital road map, we are rapidly getting out an extended customer experience beyond the 4 walls of our stores. At the same time, we believe customers will always want the human connection, the sense of community and the unparalleled shopping environment our stores deliver. As we accelerate our new store openings and step up refreshes of our older stores, we are focused on evolving a richer customer experience through innovation, improved value and higher levels of transparency on all the products that we sell. 
In Q1, we opened 9 stores, expanding into Ottawa, Canada and revitalizing our brand with new large flagships in both Houston and Boston. We're opening our first tap room in 2010, we now have over 100 tap rooms and wine bars company-wide. Our Post Oak store in Houston took the next step beating our first-ever in-store microbrewery, our second brewery is already open and we expect many more to come. We refreshed 40 stores and are on track to complete 200 by year-end. While results vary depending on the scope of the project and a variety of other factors, stores typically see an immediate sales lift and we expect these investments to be one of the many factors contributing to sales momentum this year and beyond. We continue to see unit lift from the lower produce price that we are testing in several markets, which include external marketing to support these investments. It is too early for conclusive results, particularly given the holidays. However, we're looking at expanding the test to additional markets as we believe more competitive produce pricing will greatly benefit our overall value perception. We launched our Responsibly Grown rating system, which assesses growing practices and impact human health and the environment and prohibits some of the most harmful pesticides. We believe these ratings draw clear lines of differentiation between our produce and our floral departments than those of our competitors. The program has been well-received by suppliers and customers and close to 60% of our produce is already rated. We have seen the power of our differentiated standards in other areas such as meat and seafood and believe our Responsibly Grown ratings of produce will see similar success over time. And after just 2 years of setting a deadline for full GMO transparency by 2018, we are well on our way with over 25,000 Certified Organic items in over 8,500 non-GMO project verified products in our stores. 
Turning back now to the results -- our results, sales increased 10% driven by comps of 4.5% and square footage growth of 9.4%. a 20 basis points decline in gross margin was partially offset by a 4 basis point improvement in SG&A. It remains our intention to offset the impact of our strategic initiatives with improvements in our cost structure over the longer term. However, the timing of investments and the cost cuts may not align as was the case this quarter. Excluding $13 million or 28 basis points of estimated incremental marketing costs related to the launch of our brand campaign, SG&A improved 33 basis points due to leverage in salaries and benefits, more than offsetting the 20 basis point decline in gross margin. EBITDA margin was 8.5% and EPS increased 10% to $0.46. For the last 8 quarters, our new store class has averaged sales per -- gross square foot of $709, translating the productivity levels of 82% on a weighted square footage basis. Comp stores less than 2 years old have averaged 70% -- 17% comps and most importantly, a 14% return on invested capital well in excess of our weighted average cost of capital. Please see our press release for more details on our outlook for this year and note that we estimate this year's Easter shift will possibly impact comps in Q2 and negatively impact comps in Q3 by about 50 to 60 basis points. 
As we look forward, we see more opportunity for the Whole Foods Market brand than ever before. We have a deep and seasoned leadership team and we've added some fantastic new talent. Our strong and vibrant culture contributes to low turnover and high morale, which helps create a great customer experience. The demand for fresh healthy foods continues to surge, and we are best-positioned to benefit as the leading retailer of natural organic growth in America's Healthiest Grocery Store. We are committed and continuing to improve and evolve, and with 408 stores and 116 sign leases, we have confidence that we will cross the 500 store mark in 2017 and triple our store base over the longer term. 
We will now take questions. Call will end at 4:45 p.m. Central Time, [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Walter, we anticipated that question, and we talked a lot about ourselves and really the correct answer is we think it's all of them contributing to the momentum. Because the comp results are broad-based across the company and storage classes, it
componenttext: This is Walter, we anticipated that question, and we talked a lot about ourselves and really the correct answer is we think it's all of them contributing to the momentum. Because the comp results are broad-based across the company and storage classes, it suggests that every single one of these things gains some -- it really helped us to gain some additional traction.

componenttext: Okay, and just one more, on the store remodels, how far along are we now in the process? And how the store models thus far has met your expectations?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, this is David. We actually were very pleased we were able to accomplish 40 refreshes in the first quarter which you know has the holidays in it, so we're able to work our way around the holidays and we got some great results. Chicago, where we're just
componenttext: Hi, this is David. We actually were very pleased we were able to accomplish 40 refreshes in the first quarter which you know has the holidays in it, so we're able to work our way around the holidays and we got some great results. Chicago, where we're just about to open a lot of stores with our Dominic's that we're turning to a new Whole Foods, we finished to fully model Lakeview, [indiscernible] to refresh, Gold Coast to refresh, Tamarac and Denver, store like Reno, this is all new decor, new graphics, just a whole new look. And we're seeing, as Walter described, great results in all these stores, and so I would say in the next quarter, we're going to accelerate because we'll have more time without the holidays. So we're doing a lot of work in the next few quarters.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we can take our next question from Charles Grom with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: And we can take our next question from Charles Grom with Sterne Agee.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you guys -- when you evaluate your cost structure and you look at the P&L and direct store expenses, G&A, corporate overhead, I guess where do you guys think the biggest opportunity is to get leaner in the years ahead? And can we dive into that topic
componenttext: When you guys -- when you evaluate your cost structure and you look at the P&L and direct store expenses, G&A, corporate overhead, I guess where do you guys think the biggest opportunity is to get leaner in the years ahead? And can we dive into that topic a little bit?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's John here. I think it's everywhere. We're getting leverage right now as we continue to grow. But I think it's kind of taken that zero-based budgeting approach and looking at everything you're doing. I mean, we're very proud that we took out over 200
componenttext: It's John here. I think it's everywhere. We're getting leverage right now as we continue to grow. But I think it's kind of taken that zero-based budgeting approach and looking at everything you're doing. I mean, we're very proud that we took out over 200 basis points on our cost structure in the last 5 years, and I think it's reasonable to conclude we can do the same thing on a go forward basis. But it just requires a lot of hard work. I mean, obviously if we knew exactly the big areas to cut, we'd have already done that. So it's about working at it, studying it, making it a priority which is what our regional presidents are doing and our executive vice presidents for operations. We're very conscious of the fact that we need to take cost out of our system, and we've done it in the past and we're going to continue to do it going forward.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Walter, I'll just add, Chuck, that in addition to the looking up and down the P&L for the cost savings and we talked previously about distribution, purchasing and store labor, but also process changes and the way we do business and we've talked la
componenttext: This is Walter, I'll just add, Chuck, that in addition to the looking up and down the P&L for the cost savings and we talked previously about distribution, purchasing and store labor, but also process changes and the way we do business and we've talked last quarter about our efforts around rethinking our company and how we do business in areas such as data and in purchasing, these areas -- there's opportunities to make process changes, business process changes resulting in being more productive. So that's an area we're looking at hard together right now.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And this is a follow-up, just when you think about reinvesting some of those cost savings, what are you looking to see from a unit elasticity to reinvest those cost cuts back into more produce items around the perimeter of the store and expanding to other
componenttext: And this is a follow-up, just when you think about reinvesting some of those cost savings, what are you looking to see from a unit elasticity to reinvest those cost cuts back into more produce items around the perimeter of the store and expanding to other markets beyond Austin?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: To be clear, we're looking at 3 buckets. We're looking at the price investments, we're looking at marketing continuing our brand building efforts and third  the area of technology capability that we describe a lot in the call today but I think it's a litt
componenttext: To be clear, we're looking at 3 buckets. We're looking at the price investments, we're looking at marketing continuing our brand building efforts and third  the area of technology capability that we describe a lot in the call today but I think it's a little early to give you direct answer on the produce because we're still really evaluating. We have like 4 or 5 tests going on and we have stepped up a couple of more and I think we'll have more to say about that. But I think it's fair to see we're seeing good unit lift already. You want to add to that, John, or...

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're a public company so we got to juggle a lot of things, meaning that we -- I suppose if Whole Food was a private company, we would act a lot faster, but it's been our experience that the market oftentimes overreacts to anything we do. So a juggl
componenttext: Well, we're a public company so we got to juggle a lot of things, meaning that we -- I suppose if Whole Food was a private company, we would act a lot faster, but it's been our experience that the market oftentimes overreacts to anything we do. So a juggling act will be to continue to make price investments, continuing to invest in technology, continue to take costs out of the system as we can and hopefully those will be not perfectly aligned, but we think we can do it in such a way that we can continue sort of in the same type of upward trajectory that we've been doing. And we have to evaluate how's our marketing, how did it do when we did the national television advertising, we're actually very happy with it, but it's hard to know exactly how many impressions we got, it's hard to know in fact, how that drove sales. We're making technology investments. We think that's going to help us be more profitable in the long run but we still have a lot of work ahead of us. So I think the company is just going to focus on these areas and we're going to continue to work together -- take costs out of our system and hopefully that we'll be able to grow our sales and grow our comps and make all our stakeholders happy simultaneously. That's what we strive to do.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: I was going to ask you about sort of what you're seeing with the produce tests, but you have said you'll say more about that shortly, so I won't ask that. Question about if you can talk at all about the loyalty program you're working on. Can you just give us any sense of what it looks like because you don't have a regular promotional program, so it's not like you're transferring that to the card. So can you say anything more about what you're doing?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take this, this is Walter, I'll take a shot. 12 stores, we delivered going fast with the development doing and inevitably so, they were incorporated in the feedback from customers as we go. But it's a combination of card and app. We're using the term
componenttext: I'll take this, this is Walter, I'll take a shot. 12 stores, we delivered going fast with the development doing and inevitably so, they were incorporated in the feedback from customers as we go. But it's a combination of card and app. We're using the term Affinity as opposed to loyalty to try to suggest we're going to create an experience that resonates with our brand that's more than just sort of a pedestrian thing, but actually additional benefits, additional loyalty, curating some sort of individual relationship with the customer. And it's really we're just, I think, what we're seeing so far is people are responding to it, the registration's higher than we expected, the basket size is very good. It's close to $100 on that program. So granted it could be that those are some of our better customers that are using it, but it's still a very good result in terms of the basket size that's coming out there. And I think we're just really -- we have a great team working on it and we're really focused on continuing to improve the brand of it as well as the experience of it and that's where we are right now.

componenttextpreview: It's too early to have any information on that. I could tell you though that we're active with the rollout with anticipation that the customer service teams will be all online by the end of the fiscal year '15. And right now we're in the process of redefi
componenttext: It's too early to have any information on that. I could tell you though that we're active with the rollout with anticipation that the customer service teams will be all online by the end of the fiscal year '15. And right now we're in the process of redefining our business processes and laying in the technology into that to create the new sort of set of operating practices related around the front end in customer service. So that's basically where we are with it. We're really excited about the tool, we think it's going to be an incredible add to the ability for us to schedule effectively and serve the customers.

componenttext: I was hoping that you could quantify the impact from the pricing investments for the quarter, and maybe just for the gross margin line or if you even want to refer to kind of the basket dollar growth and then related to that, I was hoping you could also comment just on the second quarter to date information it looks like the basket growth slipped a little bit. I'm just curious if it's mix-related or perhaps you're even getting a bit more aggressive with that price environment?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Glenda, I'll answer your second question first, which is the second quarter results are for 3 weeks only and we had a lot of weather both last year and this year that are skewing the results. So it's very difficult to look at that and try, didn't
componenttext: This is Glenda, I'll answer your second question first, which is the second quarter results are for 3 weeks only and we had a lot of weather both last year and this year that are skewing the results. So it's very difficult to look at that and try, didn't get too much information from it so I caution you against doing that. And we are not quantifying what you're asking us for. We just want to say that we're in a very early position in the produce price investments and we're continuing to look at what we're doing so far and tweaking it, and we have plan to roll it out, as we said, to more markets and do more tests in the quarters ahead. So hopefully we will be able to give better information at some point but we are not prepared to do that this time.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, this is Walter, I would just point you to looking at the growth at the transaction count. If you look at the quarter even the 5 weeks of the new quarter, look at the tremendous improvement in the transaction growth, that's much more the story I t
componenttext: I guess, this is Walter, I would just point you to looking at the growth at the transaction count. If you look at the quarter even the 5 weeks of the new quarter, look at the tremendous improvement in the transaction growth, that's much more the story I think, in the basket, is to see a nice growth there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, this is A.C., it varies. We have seen some, especially when you often start a campaign in a particular area, a lot of times, competitors will react to it and then they'll back off a little bit over time. So we've seen a little bit of that. We've been
componenttext: Hi, this is A.C., it varies. We have seen some, especially when you often start a campaign in a particular area, a lot of times, competitors will react to it and then they'll back off a little bit over time. So we've seen a little bit of that. We've been in some other markets where people -- some competitors haven't adjusted at all to what we're doing. So it's kind of all over the map. And, again, I think eventually people wind up going back to what their normal strategy was after the initial reaction to what you do.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: John here. One thing to understand is only a few of our markets, just Whole Foods market, have like the leading market share for food in supermarkets or food retailing. I mean, in almost all of our markets, but maybe a few, we are -- our market share is r
componenttext: John here. One thing to understand is only a few of our markets, just Whole Foods market, have like the leading market share for food in supermarkets or food retailing. I mean, in almost all of our markets, but maybe a few, we are -- our market share is relatively low. We're not -- I mean, we -- the point of it is we're not a big threat to a major supermarket who dominates the market. It doesn't make -- in most cases, it doesn't make much economic sense for them to go overact and lower all their produce prices to try to match Whole Foods Market because they're destroying their profitability, or harming their profitability for very little market share gains. So this is an example we're not having a big market share works to our advantage because supermarkets either won't react or they won't -- we don't think they will hold their prices for a long period of time as A.C. made mention to. So, yes, I mean, for the most part, I think only one or two markets has much of a reaction at all. The customers react though.

componenttext: This is Walter. Not really, no, I think what we said is we expected to be down sequentially more this year than last year in the sort of 20, 25 basis point range, it seems like that's the path we're on as John mentioned. That represents a balancing of all these various things they were up to and we're actually kind of right on the path we expected to be.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about the refreshes. If you can give any further color regarding the 40 that you recently refreshed in terms of was an overwhelming majority more toward a lighter refresh or versus more toward a full-blown remodel? And then maybe if yo
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about the refreshes. If you can give any further color regarding the 40 that you recently refreshed in terms of was an overwhelming majority more toward a lighter refresh or versus more toward a full-blown remodel? And then maybe if you could also talk about the 200 that you have earmarked by year end, kind of what levels of refresh are you expecting?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's David here. So really the strategy we came up with was based on our great experience in Southern California with some of the oldest Whole Foods Market in the company, the former Missus Gauches. And we saw that the results of just doing lighter r
componenttext: Yes, it's David here. So really the strategy we came up with was based on our great experience in Southern California with some of the oldest Whole Foods Market in the company, the former Missus Gauches. And we saw that the results of just doing lighter refreshes, essentially new color, new decor, new flooring sometimes, some new lighting. That immediately caused customers to kind of see the store in kind of a new light. And it really we saw an immediate sales boost. So we essentially, with the 200 refreshes we're primarily talking about decor, putting up to the most up-to-date look and feel of our stores, stores like Brooklyn, New York, things like that. We're trying to -- we're looking at some of the way those stores feel. And so it's mainly décor and that kind of stuff. But we do every year, we do significant remodeling across our stores, adding new concepts like juice bars. Ken you want to add anything to that?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the middle of that class you have sort of we're adding new cases, new programs and taking the latest thing we have done in our new stores and implementing them into existing stores throughout the group of stores in different regions. So a lot of the ne
componenttext: In the middle of that class you have sort of we're adding new cases, new programs and taking the latest thing we have done in our new stores and implementing them into existing stores throughout the group of stores in different regions. So a lot of the new product work that A.C. is working on in private label, in frozen product requires more freezer doors, more dairy space. So we're adding cases in the growth areas of the business.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: Okay, very helpful, thank you. Just as a follow-up question to that, I know you mentioned the Reno  location earlier, but as a class are those 40 refreshes, would it be safe to say that the comp list that you are seeing in total is maybe within a few hundred basis points between some of the ones that were seen the most versus the least uplift?

componenttext: This is Walter. Looking at -- we saw pretty good growth in all the basket sizes and particularly on the higher end baskets, they continue to grow nicely. But, I mean, we offered -- I think we started by offering kind of our initiatives as kind of the principal reasons for the momentum and we offer the consumer confidence as kind of the backdrop. We have correlated the consumer confidence index to comps to look at what the relationship there, but I think this has more to do this quarter with our particular efforts in these different areas that together combined, have created a positive momentum for the company.

componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect, that's very good guidance. So my next question is regarding competition, I mean, clearly, this has been a focus of the market, it's been a focus of some of the stuff that we've done. Costco adding in a lot of stuff, Target's going to add in
componenttext: Okay, perfect, that's very good guidance. So my next question is regarding competition, I mean, clearly, this has been a focus of the market, it's been a focus of some of the stuff that we've done. Costco adding in a lot of stuff, Target's going to add in a lot of organics, Kroger's been -- what's your thoughts about I know back in the 2000, John, you mentioned that you thought it was good, when these companies are doing this, can you update us on your thought process as more of the big companies in the staples retailing space add in organics and better for you?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, it's A.C. It's a real dynamic changing marketplace. We do see products in a lot of organic products going to a lot of different retailers. It's interesting we had recent meetings with a lot of our top suppliers, and some of them are telling us that as
componenttext: Hi, it's A.C. It's a real dynamic changing marketplace. We do see products in a lot of organic products going to a lot of different retailers. It's interesting we had recent meetings with a lot of our top suppliers, and some of them are telling us that as soon as a product hits our shelves, they get calls from other competitors saying we want that product too. We kind of take pride about being the first of getting products on the shelf. And that's what we do. We really innovate. A lot of our -- our culture is about innovation and so we know that in this kind of market, people are going to be looking to sell all of the the products we do because they know that we've been successful, and it's our job to keep innovating and coming up with new products, new things like our Responsibly Grown produce program, continuing to push our animal welfare and our sustainable seafood and all those kinds of things. So it's really a challenge to us to continue to grow and innovate, and that's what gets us excited. And that's what we've been doing and that's where our focus is.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you think you're going to prices some of the ubiquitous items where this competition are priced or is that not going to be a problem?
componenttext: Do you think you're going to prices some of the ubiquitous items where this competition are priced or is that not going to be a problem?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, Whole Foods is about quality, it's about service, it's about selection, it's about ambience. We've never been and we never will be trying to be the lowest-priced supermarket. It's sort of not very attractive, doesn't give very good service. That's
componenttext: I mean, Whole Foods is about quality, it's about service, it's about selection, it's about ambience. We've never been and we never will be trying to be the lowest-priced supermarket. It's sort of not very attractive, doesn't give very good service. That's not what we're about. I mean, that's a valid niche in the marketplace, just to try to be the low-priced, low-cost operator. But that's not Whole Foods' strategy. Our strategy has always been about the quality and the service and the selection. And, yes, I mean competition's harder today than it used to be, but on the other hand, Whole Foods is a lot better today than it used to be. In fact, competition -- it is your ally. It's your ally that helps you to get better, it knocks you out of your complacency, it keeps you from being lazy, it forces you to evolve. And Whole Foods Market's a very competitive company and when we are challenged, when competition rears its head, we respond. And that's what we're doing right now. We're responding, we're evolving, we're getting better, we're getting better than our competitors are. So they're chasing us still, and maybe they've closed the gap a little bit, but we're accelerating our innovation cycle. So I think that's something people have never understood about Whole Foods market. They think we're going to sit still and let people catch us. But we're not going to sit still, we're going to rapidly innovate and improve, that's what we've done for over 35 years and that's what we're going to do going forward.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to add to that, Scott, we're going to be relevant on price. We said it before, we'll say it again. Our tracking of competitors' pricing and indexes is much more sophisticated now than it was 2 or 3 years ago. we know where we stand relative to the ot
componenttext: Just to add to that, Scott, we're going to be relevant on price. We said it before, we'll say it again. Our tracking of competitors' pricing and indexes is much more sophisticated now than it was 2 or 3 years ago. we know where we stand relative to the others and yes of course, on the items that are ubiquitous we're going to be in them and we're going to have to price them right. And we understand that. That's part of where some of these investments are going and where we continue -- where we've kind of laid out the path over the next few years. But it all fits within the broader context John just laid out about how we think about going to market and competing and showing up as a leading retailer in the marketplace.

componenttext: First question have to do with the home delivery. It sounds like it's gotten bigger traction thus far in certain stores. I'm curious how much penetration in any given store would you expect? And then secondly, how much of that business do you think is additive versus sort of cannibalizing the store?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. We really have a great partnership with our friend at Instacart. We're working super close together with them, and the sales are growing week over week every single week. So we're very excited about that. And we're looking -- we feel like w
componenttext: This is David. We really have a great partnership with our friend at Instacart. We're working super close together with them, and the sales are growing week over week every single week. So we're very excited about that. And we're looking -- we feel like we've just scratched the surface this week with the Valentines promotion and new thing. We really haven't touched prepared foods. We really haven't started with that business yet, and that's coming. So we're adding products all the time. And we are working with Instacart to -- we're starting to actually reach capacity in some of our stores and meaning to add more stores with the Instacart shopper shop in some of our cities and it's really just the beginning. It's early days, but sales are real, we're seeing some exciting stuff with the bad weather lately, where we're seeing orders really take off before bad weather, so we're picking up some additional sales that were lost to the bad weather before. Instacart adds additional shoppers in days like that. So all good news.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Remember, we do have incremental business here. We have a working number inside that's pretty good size and I think I like to have a run a little bit before we started to talk about that, but it's not insignificant in terms of incremental business.
componenttext: Remember, we do have incremental business here. We have a working number inside that's pretty good size and I think I like to have a run a little bit before we started to talk about that, but it's not insignificant in terms of incremental business.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look over the long run, I mean, Whole Foods Market is got not going to have a supermarket on every corner. And yet we have very loyal customers. So we'll begin to get more of the convenience business through Instacart than we've ever had befor
componenttext: Yes, if you look over the long run, I mean, Whole Foods Market is got not going to have a supermarket on every corner. And yet we have very loyal customers. So we'll begin to get more of the convenience business through Instacart than we've ever had before, because let's say they come to Whole Foods, they have to drive past other supermarkets to come to Whole Foods, and they do that maybe once a week, or once every couple of weeks. But now with Instacart, if they need to pick up a quart of milk or they need to pick up some berries for their cereal, they can just order from Instacart, they don't need to go drive over to one of our competitors who might be closer than Whole Foods. So I think there will be some cannibalization, of course, there will be some incremental sales that we get. And so as Walter and David said, it's so early, I mean, it so early in this. We got so much information a year from now than we have today, but all we can say is it's growing very rapidly. Our customers love it and we're really happy with it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Last thing, we are seeing some exciting steps being taken in terms of long-distance ordered where customers live in one place but kids live in another place where Instacart is and they can still shop at Whole Foods, college kids, parents. So the expansion
componenttext: Last thing, we are seeing some exciting steps being taken in terms of long-distance ordered where customers live in one place but kids live in another place where Instacart is and they can still shop at Whole Foods, college kids, parents. So the expansion of Whole Foods shopping universe is growing.

componenttext: Well that's exactly what we did do when we launched that. We did marketing in every one of those markets to partner with the investments. So we still are doing that, and we expect to continue doing that, along with whatever the next steps are we decide to take with respect to our brand campaign. Which you know, the first phase is going to wrap up. I will say we have good to great new goal of Vice President marketing communications in, happy to have her on the team, she's had tremendous years of experience to our group, and so we have a real leader in that area now. And we're just kind of rediscovering, we're kind of rediscovering marketing after all these years and the power of communicating what your differences are and what you're up to.

componenttextpreview: You have mentioned the need to balance the physical and the store experience, and you've also been talk about the digital offering. How are this balancing act getting factored into your real estate strategy with regard to any changes in the size or type o
componenttext: You have mentioned the need to balance the physical and the store experience, and you've also been talk about the digital offering. How are this balancing act getting factored into your real estate strategy with regard to any changes in the size or type of store you'll be opening going forward?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jim. As far as store size goes, we're really focused on a store size of at least 40,000 square feet. We think our sweet spot is somewhere between 40 and 50 and in most of the markets that we're currently serving, even some of the smaller markets,
componenttext: This is Jim. As far as store size goes, we're really focused on a store size of at least 40,000 square feet. We think our sweet spot is somewhere between 40 and 50 and in most of the markets that we're currently serving, even some of the smaller markets, we're finding that we need to go a little bit bigger in order to get our full offering in there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so in those larger stores, just, correct me if I'm wrong, they tend to have a longer tail in terms of the maturation. Is that right?
componenttext: And so in those larger stores, just, correct me if I'm wrong, they tend to have a longer tail in terms of the maturation. Is that right?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, of course. They tend to -- all of our stores tend to start off pretty strong, but the bigger stores, tend to take longer to reach maturity. We're building them for the long term, and we don't want to cut ourselves short. So we think there's a lot of
componenttext: Yes, of course. They tend to -- all of our stores tend to start off pretty strong, but the bigger stores, tend to take longer to reach maturity. We're building them for the long term, and we don't want to cut ourselves short. So we think there's a lot of opportunity with the bigger stores. This quarter, I think we -- our average store size we sign was approximately 44,000 square feet and it's been running about 38,000, 39,000 before this. So you can see the trends towards the bigger stores again.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we are continuing to work -- we've kind of built up over the last couple of years our exclusive brands teams. It's a very robust team now. They just did a great job with some really nice holiday items for us. We are looking at continuing to grow the
componenttext: Well, we are continuing to work -- we've kind of built up over the last couple of years our exclusive brands teams. It's a very robust team now. They just did a great job with some really nice holiday items for us. We are looking at continuing to grow the products that we have and I think improve the quality in the grocery department. We have our primary exclusive brand has been our 365 brand, which is a little more value-added but still really good quality, but we started to brand more items now under the Whole Foods brand in grocery. And generally, like, for instance, in olive oil category, we went to single source -- single sources around the globe and got some really nice olive oil and so we market those as a Whole Foods brand versus our Value 365. We've also just, in the produce department, rebranded a lot of salad mixes that we had into mostly into the Whole Foods brand as well. So we are looking for opportunities in different parts of the store to continue to expand the 365 and the Whole Foods brand.

componenttext: This is Gerry. Just looking at your gross margin, it looks like you were performing a little bit better than the worst than 30 basis points you said in the last year. Can you just talk about with your comps using a little bit especially the next couple of quarters, why that wouldn't get better? And what drivers -- what are the drivers of that -- what are the expectations there built-in to do that gross margin guidance?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: We didn't actually give gross margin guidance, I guess we gave some direction on that. I'll just point you back to our discussion earlier, which is to say our intention is and we'll continue over a multiyear process to continue to bring the gross margin d
componenttext: We didn't actually give gross margin guidance, I guess we gave some direction on that. I'll just point you back to our discussion earlier, which is to say our intention is and we'll continue over a multiyear process to continue to bring the gross margin down in a sequential fashion through a combination of these efforts around the price investments as we true up to the marketplace as needed, offset by our investments in our improvements in cost structure and process changes. So kind of what we're talking about is kind of a sort of a glide path in the order of each year sequentially, a little bit more and that's and how we've talked about the gross margin. So I think we leave it at that for now.

Good day, and welcome to the Whole Foods' First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]
It is now my pleasure to turn the program over to Cindy McCann, VP of Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth & Development; and David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations.
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Our press release and scripted remarks are now available on our website.
I will now turn the call over to Walter Robb.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone, from beautiful Austin, Texas.We're pleased with our Q1 results which reflect continued market share gains, healthy returns and a strong start to fiscal year 2015. Sales grew over 10% to $4.7 billion, with com
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone, from beautiful Austin, Texas.
We're pleased with our Q1 results which reflect continued market share gains, healthy returns and a strong start to fiscal year 2015. Sales grew over 10% to $4.7 billion, with comparable store sales growth accelerating on a 1- and a 2-year basis. With broad-based momentum across departments, store age classes and regions, we believe our many strategic initiatives, along with improving consumer confidence, are collectively contributing to our improved results.
Here are some of the highlights of our progress in Q1.
We launched our Values Matter national brand campaign, which you may have seen on TV and in print several times over the last few months. It was a real boost to team member morale, and we're looking forward to the final brand-tracking study results. The early read is very positive, indicating 100% increase in awareness for our target audience, with increases in both value perception and intent to shop versus our measured competitors.
We are now providing fresh grocery delivery options to more homes in America than any other food retailer. Since announcing our 15-market partnership with Instacart in September, our average weekly online delivery sales have already passed the $1 million mark. With online delivery sales as high as 5% of total sales in some of our stores, we're very excited about the future potential as we expand our reach to more markets, provide richer content highlighting our quality standards, and broaden our product offering.
A great example is happening this week for Valentine's Day. We're offering floral delivery in as little as 1 hour, with prices starting at $25 for a dozen of our high-quality, ethically sourced Whole Trade roses. Orders can be placed in advance, and combined with the ability to include chocolates or some other treats, this is a deal that's hard to beat.
We're the largest Apple Pay retailer in terms of both transactions and sales, further reinforcing the notion that our customer base wants to take advantage of the latest digital technologies. This payment option has grown quickly to 2% of sales, which we expect will continue to increase, especially after the Apple Watch launches this year. We are exploring opportunities to extend this successful partnership, including expanding functionality to support our Affinity program. 
Speaking of, we are pleased with the results of our 12-store Affinity test, which shows high activation and registration rates and above-average basket sizes for participants. We are continuing to incorporate customer feedback as we upgrade and add new features to this program, and recently added some new talent to lead our efforts in this area. We're excited to expand the pilot to our Washington, D.C. customers this spring, with hopes of having the program live in a majority of our stores for the 2015 holiday season.
And as promised, our new and improved Whole Foods Market app is now live, with nearly 600,000 downloads to date. iOS, Android users can access personalized and local store offers, events and information, along with 3,700 tested recipes where ingredients can be added to shopping lists with a single tap. Stay tuned for more unique and exciting features and upgrades throughout the year. 
We recognize the changing technology and growing demand for customization have fundamentally altered retailing forever. Customers now expect to connect with a brand whenever, wherever and however they choose. And as part of our broader digital road map, we are rapidly building out an extended customer experience beyond the 4 walls of our stores. At the same time, we believe customers will always want the human connection, the sense of community and the unparalleled shopping environment our stores deliver. As we accelerate our new store openings and step up refreshes of our oldest stores, we are focused on evolving a richer customer experience through innovation, improved value and higher levels of transparency on all the products that we sell.
In Q1, we opened 9 new stores, expanding into Ottawa, Canada and revitalizing our brand with new large flagships in both Houston and Boston. After opening our first taproom in 2010, we now have over 100 taprooms and wine bars company-wide.
Our Post Oak store in Houston took the next step, debuting our first-ever in-store microbrewery. Our second brewery is already opened, and we expect many more to come.
We refreshed 40 stores and are on track to complete 200 by year-end. While results vary depending on the scope of the project and a variety of other factors, stores typically see an immediate sales lift, and we expect these investments to be one of the many factors contributing to sales momentum this year and beyond.
We continue to see unit lift from the lower produce price we are testing in several markets, which included external marketing to support these investments. It is too early for conclusive results, particularly given the holidays; however, we're looking at expanding the test to additional markets as we believe more competitive produce pricing will greatly benefit our overall value perception.
We launched our Responsibly Grown rating system, which assesses growing practices that impact human health and the environment and prohibits some of the most harmful pesticides. We believe these ratings draw clear lines of differentiation between our produce and our floral departments than those of our competitors. The program has been well-received by suppliers and customers, and close to 60% of our produce is already rated. We have seen the power of our differentiated standards in other areas, such as meat and seafood, and believe our Responsibly Grown ratings in produce will see similar success over time.
And after just 2 years of setting a deadline for full GMO transparency by 2018, we are well on our way with over 25,000 certified organic items in over 8,500 Non-GMO Project Verified products in our stores.
Turning back now to the results, our results. Sales increased 10% driven by comps of 4.5% and square footage growth of 9.4%. A 20-basis-point decline in gross margin was partially offset by a 4-basis-point improvement in SG&A. It remains our intention to offset the impact of our strategic initiatives with improvements in our cost structure over the longer term. However, the timing of investments and the cost cuts may not align, as was the case this quarter.
Excluding $13 million or 28 basis points of estimated incremental marketing costs related to the launch of our brand campaign, SG&A improved 33 basis points due to leverage in salaries and benefits, more than offsetting the 20-basis-point decline in gross margin. EBITDA margin was 8.5%, and EPS increased 10% to $0.46.
For the last 8 quarters, our new store class has averaged sales per square -- gross square foot of $709, translating the productivity levels of 82% on a weighted square footage basis. Comp stores less than 2 years old have averaged 70% -- 17% comps, and most importantly, a 14% return on invested capital, well in excess of our weighted average cost of capital.
Please see our press release for more details on our outlook for this year and note that we estimate this year's Easter shift will positively impact comps in Q2 and negatively impact comps in Q3 by about 50 to 60 basis points.
As we look forward, we see more opportunity for the Whole Foods Market brand than ever before. We have a deep and seasoned leadership team and been adding some fantastic new talent. Our strong and vibrant culture contributes to low turnover and high morale, which helps create a great customer experience. The demand for fresh healthy foods continues to surge, and we are best-positioned to benefit as the leading retailer of natural and organic foods and America's Healthiest Grocery Store. We are committed to continuing to improve and evolve, and with 408 stores and 116 signed leases, we have confidence that we will cross the 500-store mark in 2017 and triple our store base over the longer term.
We will now take questions. Our call will end at 4:45 p.m. Central time. [Operator Instructions]
Thank you.

componenttext: Well, we -- this is Walter. We anticipated that question, and we talked a lot about ourselves. And really, the correct answer is we think it's all of them contributing to the momentum. If you -- because the comp results are broad-based across the company and store age classes, it just suggests that every single one of these things gained some and really helped us to gain some additional traction.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. We actually were very pleased that we're able to accomplish 40 refreshes in the first quarter, which has the holidays in it. So we're able to work our way around the holidays, and we've got some great results. Chicago, where we're just abou
componenttext: This is David. We actually were very pleased that we're able to accomplish 40 refreshes in the first quarter, which has the holidays in it. So we're able to work our way around the holidays, and we've got some great results. Chicago, where we're just about to open a lot of stores with our Dominick's that we've -- we're turning into a new Whole Foods. We finished the full remodel in Lakeview. We were forced to refresh Gold Coast, to refresh Tamarac and just Denver, store like Reno. This is all new decor, new graphics, just a whole new look. And we're seeing like, as Walter described, great results in all these stores. And so I would say, in the next quarter, we're going to accelerate because we'll have more time without the holidays. So we'll be doing a lot of work in the next few quarters.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: And we can take our next question from Charles Grom with Sterne Agee.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you guys -- when you evaluate your cost structure and you look at the P&L and direct store expenses, G&A, corporate overhead, I guess where do you guys think the biggest opportunity is to get leaner in the years ahead? Can we dive into that topic a l
componenttext: When you guys -- when you evaluate your cost structure and you look at the P&L and direct store expenses, G&A, corporate overhead, I guess where do you guys think the biggest opportunity is to get leaner in the years ahead? Can we dive into that topic a little bit?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think -- it's John here. I think it's everywhere. We're getting leverage right now as we continue to grow, but I think it's kind of taken that zero-based budgeting approach and looking at everything you're doing. I mean, we're very proud that we
componenttext: I mean, I think -- it's John here. I think it's everywhere. We're getting leverage right now as we continue to grow, but I think it's kind of taken that zero-based budgeting approach and looking at everything you're doing. I mean, we're very proud that we took out over 200 basis points on our cost structure in the last 5 years, and I think it's reasonable to conclude we can do the same thing on a go-forward basis. But it just requires a lot of hard work. I mean, obviously, if we knew exactly the big areas to cut, we'd already have done that. So it's about working at it, studying it, putting -- making it a priority, which is what our regional presidents are doing and our executive vice presidents for operations. We're very conscious of the fact that we need to take cost out of our system, and we've done it in the past, and we're going to continue to do it going forward.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. I'll just add, Chuck, that in addition to the looking up and down the P&L for the cost savings, and we had talked previously about distribution, purchasing and store labor, but also process changes and the way we do business. And we've tal
componenttext: This is Walter. I'll just add, Chuck, that in addition to the looking up and down the P&L for the cost savings, and we had talked previously about distribution, purchasing and store labor, but also process changes and the way we do business. And we've talked last quarter about our efforts around rethinking our company on how we do business and -- in areas such as data and in purchasing. These areas -- there's opportunities to make process changes, business process changes resulting in being more productive. So that's an area we're looking at hard together right now.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And this is a follow-up to that. Just when you think about reinvesting some of those cost savings, what are you looking to see from a unit elasticity to reinvest those cost cuts back into more produce items around the perimeter of the store and expa
componenttext: Okay. And this is a follow-up to that. Just when you think about reinvesting some of those cost savings, what are you looking to see from a unit elasticity to reinvest those cost cuts back into more produce items around the perimeter of the store and expanding to other markets beyond Austin?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, to be clear, we're looking at 3 buckets. We're looking at the price investments. We're looking at marketing, continuing our brand-building efforts, and third, in the area of technology capability that we described a lot in the call today. But I thin
componenttext: Well, to be clear, we're looking at 3 buckets. We're looking at the price investments. We're looking at marketing, continuing our brand-building efforts, and third, in the area of technology capability that we described a lot in the call today. But I think it's a little early to give you a direct answer on the produce because we're still really evaluating. We have like 4 or 5 tests going on, and we stepped up a couple of more, and I think we'll have more to say about that. But I think it's fair to say we're seeing good unit lift already. Do you want to add to that, John, or...

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're a public company, so we've got to juggle a lot of things, meaning, that we -- I mean, suppose if Whole Foods was a private company, we would act a lot faster. But it's been our experience that the market oftentimes overreacts to anything we do
componenttext: Well, we're a public company, so we've got to juggle a lot of things, meaning, that we -- I mean, suppose if Whole Foods was a private company, we would act a lot faster. But it's been our experience that the market oftentimes overreacts to anything we do. So a juggling act will be to continuing to make price investments, continuing to invest in technology, continue to take costs out of the system as we can. And hopefully, those will be not perfectly aligned, but we think we can do it in such a way that we can continue sort of in the same type of upward trajectory that we've been doing. And we have to evaluate, how's our marketing? How did it do? I mean, when we did the national television advertising, we're actually very happy with it, but it's hard to know exactly. We do know how many impressions we got, but it's hard to know if that -- how of much that drove sales. We're making technology investments. We think that's going to help us be more profitable in the long run, but we still have a lot of work ahead of us. So I think the company is just going to focus on these areas, and we're going to continue to work together -- take costs out of our system, and hopefully, that we'll be able to grow our sales and grow our comps and make all our stakeholders happy simultaneously. That's what we strive to do.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: I was going to ask you about sort of what you're seeing with the produce tests, but you have said you would say more about that shortly, so I won't ask that. Question about if you can talk at all about the loyalty program you're working on. Can you just give us any sense of what it looks like? Because you don't have a regular promotional program, so it's not like you're transferring that to the card. So can you say anything more about what you're doing?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me take -- this is Walter. I'll take a shot. I mean, certainly, 12 stores, and we deliver -- they are going fast with the development, and we're doing it iteratively, so they were incorporating the feedback from customers as we go. But then it's
componenttext: Well, let me take -- this is Walter. I'll take a shot. I mean, certainly, 12 stores, and we deliver -- they are going fast with the development, and we're doing it iteratively, so they were incorporating the feedback from customers as we go. But then it's a combination of card and app. It's -- we're using the term Affinity as opposed to loyalty to try to suggest that we're going to create an experience that resonates with our brand that's more than just sort of a pedestrian thing, but actually, additional benefits, additional loyalty, curating some sort of an relationship with the customer. And it's really -- we're just -- I think that's what we're seeing so far is that people are responding to it. The registration's higher than we expected. The basket size is very good. It's close to $100 on that program. So granted it could be that those are some of our better customers that are using it, but it's still a very good result in terms of the basket size that's coming out there. And I think we're just really -- we have a great team working on it, and we're really focused on continuing to improve the brand of it as well as the experience of it. And that's where we are right now.

componenttext: This is Glenda. I'll answer your second question first, which is that the second quarter results are for 3 weeks only and we had a lot of weather both last year and this year that are skewing the results. So it's very difficult to look at that and try to get too much information from it, so I caution you against doing that. And we are not quantifying what you're asking us for. We just want to say that we're in a very early position in the produce price investments, and we're continuing to look at what we're doing so far and tweaking it. And what we plan to roll it out, as we said, to more markets and do more tests in the quarters ahead. So hopefully, we will be able to give a better information at some point, but we're not prepared to do that this time.

The story, I think, in the basket is to see a nice growth there.

componenttextpreview: This is A.C. It varies. We have seen some, especially when you often -- when you start a campaign in a particular area, a lot of times, competitors will react to it, and then they'll back off a little bit over time. So we've seen a little bit of that. We'
componenttext: This is A.C. It varies. We have seen some, especially when you often -- when you start a campaign in a particular area, a lot of times, competitors will react to it, and then they'll back off a little bit over time. So we've seen a little bit of that. We've been in some other markets where people -- some competitors haven't adjusted at all to what we're doing. So it's kind of all over the map. And I mean, I think eventually people wind up going back to what their normal strategy was after the initial reaction to what you do.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: John here. One thing to understand is that only a few of our markets, just Whole Foods market, have like the leading market share for food in supermarkets or food retailing. I mean, in almost all of our markets, but maybe a few, we are -- our market share
componenttext: John here. One thing to understand is that only a few of our markets, just Whole Foods market, have like the leading market share for food in supermarkets or food retailing. I mean, in almost all of our markets, but maybe a few, we are -- our market share is relatively low. We're not -- I mean, we -- the point of it is we're not a big threat to a major supermarket who dominates the market. It doesn't make -- in most cases, it doesn't make much economic sense for them to go overact and lower all their produce prices to try to match Whole Foods Market because they're destroying their profitability or harming their profitability for very little market share gains. So this is an example. We're not having a big market share that works to our advantage because supermarkets either won't react or they won't -- we don't think they'll hold the prices for a long period of time, as A.C. made mention to. So yes, I mean, for the most part, I think only one or two markets has -- there had been much of a reaction at all.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The customers reacted, though.

It still seems like that's the path we're on, as John mentioned. componenttext: I wanted to ask you about the refreshes. If you can give any further color regarding the 40 that you recently refreshed in terms of -- was an overwhelming majority more toward a lighter refresh or versus more toward a full-blown remodel? And then maybe if you can also talk about the 200 that you have earmarked by year-end, kind of what levels of refresh are you expecting?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so David here. So really, the strategy we came up with was based on our great experience in Southern California with some of the oldest Whole Foods Markets in the company, the former Mrs. Gooch's. And we saw that the results of just doing lighter ref
componenttext: Yes, so David here. So really, the strategy we came up with was based on our great experience in Southern California with some of the oldest Whole Foods Markets in the company, the former Mrs. Gooch's. And we saw that the results of just doing lighter refreshes, essentially new color, new decor, new flooring sometimes, some new lighting, that immediately caused customers to kind of see the store in kind of a new light. And it -- really, we saw an immediate sales boost. So we -- essentially, with the 200 refreshes, we're primarily talking about decor, putting up to the most up-to-date look and feel of our stores. Stores like Brooklyn, New York, things like that. We're trying to -- we're looking at some of the way those stores feel, and so it's mainly décor and that kind of stuff. But we do -- every year, we do significant remodeling across our stores, adding new concepts like juice bars. Ken, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say, in the middle of that class, you have sort of where we're adding new cases, new programs and taking the latest things we've done in our newest stores and then implementing them into the existing stores throughout the group of stores in diffe
componenttext: Yes, I'd say, in the middle of that class, you have sort of where we're adding new cases, new programs and taking the latest things we've done in our newest stores and then implementing them into the existing stores throughout the group of stores in different regions. So a lot of the new product work that A.C. is working on in private label, in frozen product, requires more freezer doors, more dairy space. So we're adding cases in the growth areas of the business.

componenttext: Okay. Very helpful. Just as a follow-up question to that. I know you mentioned the Reno location earlier. I mean, we have correlated the consumer confidence index to comps to look at what the relationship there, but I think this has more to do this quarter with our particular efforts in these different areas that, together combined, have created a positive momentum for the company.

componenttextpreview: Okay. Perfect. That's really good guidance. So my next question is regarding competition. I mean, clearly, this has been a focus of the market. It's been a focus of some of the stuff that we have done. Costco adding in a lot of stuff, Target's going to ad
componenttext: Okay. Perfect. That's really good guidance. So my next question is regarding competition. I mean, clearly, this has been a focus of the market. It's been a focus of some of the stuff that we have done. Costco adding in a lot of stuff, Target's going to add in a lot of organics, Kroger's been -- what's your, guys, thoughts about the -- I know back in the 2000s, John, you mentioned that you thought it was good when these companies were doing this. Can you update us on your thought process as more of the big companies in the staples retailing space add in organics and better for you?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's A.C. It's a real dynamic, changing marketplace. We do see products in a lot of organic products going to a lot of different retailers. It's interesting we had recent meetings with a lot of our top suppliers, and some of them are telling us that as so
componenttext: It's A.C. It's a real dynamic, changing marketplace. We do see products in a lot of organic products going to a lot of different retailers. It's interesting we had recent meetings with a lot of our top suppliers, and some of them are telling us that as soon as a product hits our shelves, they get calls from other competitors saying we want that product, too. So we kind of take pride about being the first of getting products on the shelf, and that's what we do. We really innovate. A lot of our -- our culture is about innovation, and so there's -- we know that in this kind of market, people are going to be looking to sell all of the the products we do because they know that we've been successful. And it's our job to keep innovating and coming up with new products, new things like our Responsibly Grown produce program, continuing to push our animal welfare and our sustainable seafood and all those kinds of things. So it's really a challenge to us to continue to grow and innovate, and that's what gets us excited. And that's what we've been doing, and that's where our focus is.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you think you're going to have to price some of the ubiquitous items where these competitions has -- are priced? Or is that not going to be a problem?
componenttext: Do you think you're going to have to price some of the ubiquitous items where these competitions has -- are priced? Or is that not going to be a problem?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, Whole Foods is about quality. It's about service. It's about selection. It's about ambience. We've never been, and we never will be, trying to be the lowest-priced supermarket. That's sort of not very attractive, doesn't give very good service. Th
componenttext: I mean, Whole Foods is about quality. It's about service. It's about selection. It's about ambience. We've never been, and we never will be, trying to be the lowest-priced supermarket. That's sort of not very attractive, doesn't give very good service. That's not what we're about. I mean, that's a valid niche in the marketplace just to try to be the low-priced, low-cost operator, but that's not Whole Foods' strategy. Our strategy has always been about the quality and the service and the selection. And yes, I mean, competition is harder today than it used to be, but on the other hand, Whole Foods is a lot better today than it used to be. In fact, competition -- it is your ally. It's your ally that helps you to get better. It knocks you out of your complacency. It keeps you from being lazy. It forces you to evolve. And Whole Foods Markets is a very competitive company. And when we are challenged, when competition rears its head, we respond. And that's what we're doing right now. We're responding. We're evolving. We're getting better. We're getting better quicker than our competitors are. So they're chasing us still, and maybe they have closed the gap a little bit, but we're accelerating our innovation cycle. So I think that's something people have never understood about Whole Foods Market. They think we're going to sit still and let people catch us, but we're not going to sit still. We're going to rapidly innovate and improve. That's what we've done for over 35 years, and that's what we're going to do going forward.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess, to just add to that, Scott, we're going to be relevant on price. We said that before. We'll say it again. We're -- our tracking of competitors' pricing and indexes is much more sophisticated now than it was 2 or 3 years ago. We know where we
componenttext: And I guess, to just add to that, Scott, we're going to be relevant on price. We said that before. We'll say it again. We're -- our tracking of competitors' pricing and indexes is much more sophisticated now than it was 2 or 3 years ago. We know where we stand relative to the others. And yes, of course, on the items that are ubiquitous, we're going to be in them. We're going to have to price them right. And we understand that. That's part of where some of these investments are going and where we continue to -- where we've kind of laid out the path over the next few years. So -- but it all fits within the broader context John just laid out about how we think about going to market and competing and showing up as a leading retailer in the marketplace.
