headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. We really -- we're having great partnership with our friend at Instacart. We're working super close together with them, and the sales are growing week over week, every single week. So we're very excited about that. And we're looking -- we f
componenttext: This is David. We really -- we're having great partnership with our friend at Instacart. We're working super close together with them, and the sales are growing week over week, every single week. So we're very excited about that. And we're looking -- we feel like we've just scratched the surface this week, where the Valentine's promotion is a new thing. We really haven't touched prepared foods. We really haven't started with that business yet, and that's coming. So we're adding products all the time, and we're working with Instacart to -- we're starting to actually reach capacity in some of our stores and meaning to add more stores where the Instacart shoppers shop in some of our cities. And it's really just the beginning, it's early days, but sales are real. We're seeing some exciting stuff with the bad weather lately, where we're seeing orders really take off before bad weather. So we're picking up some additional sales that were lost to the bad weather before. Instacart adds additional shoppers in days like that. So all good news.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: So really, we do have incremental business here. We have a working number inside that's a pretty good size, and I think I'd like to have a run a little bit before we started to talk about that. But it's not insignificant in terms of incremental business s
componenttext: So really, we do have incremental business here. We have a working number inside that's a pretty good size, and I think I'd like to have a run a little bit before we started to talk about that. But it's not insignificant in terms of incremental business so...

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look over the long run, I mean, Whole Foods Market is got not going to have a supermarket on every corner, and yet we have very loyal customers. So we will begin to get more of the convenience business through Instacart than we've ever had bef
componenttext: Yes, if you look over the long run, I mean, Whole Foods Market is got not going to have a supermarket on every corner, and yet we have very loyal customers. So we will begin to get more of the convenience business through Instacart than we've ever had before because -- let's say they come to Whole Foods, they have to drive past other supermarkets to come to Whole Foods, and they do that maybe once a week or once every couple of weeks. But now with Instacart, if they need to pick up a quart of milk or they need to pick up some berries for their cereal, they can just order from Instacart. They don't need to go drive over to one of our competitors who might be closer than Whole Foods. So I think there will be some cannibalization, of course, and there'll be some incremental sales that we get. So -- and as Walter and David said, it's so early. I mean, it so early in this. We'll have so much more information a year from now than we have today, but all we can say is that it's growing very rapidly. Our customers love it, and we're really happy with it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Last thing, we are seeing some exciting steps being taken in terms of long-distance ordering, where customers live in one place but kids live in another place where Instacart is and they can still shop at Whole Foods. College kids, parents. So the expansi
componenttext: Last thing, we are seeing some exciting steps being taken in terms of long-distance ordering, where customers live in one place but kids live in another place where Instacart is and they can still shop at Whole Foods. College kids, parents. So the expansion of Whole Foods shopping universe is growing.

componenttext: It sounds good. And just one quick follow-up. On the marketing side, it sounds like you're pretty happy with the national ad, the sort of the values marketing. Are you doing any local advertising now that would be highlighting the price changes that you've made?

componenttext: Well, that's exactly what we did do when we launched that, that there was tests we did. We did marketing in every one of those markets to partner with the investments. So we still are doing that, and we expect to continue doing that along with whatever the next steps are we decide to take with respect to our brand campaign, which the first phase has kind of wrapped up. So I will say we got a great new Global Vice President of Marketing and Communications, Jeannine D'Addario. Happy to have her on the team. She's brought tremendous years of experience to our group, and so we have a real leader in that area now. And we're just kind of rediscovering. We're kind of rediscovering marketing after all these years and the power of communicating what your differences are and what you're up to.

componenttextpreview: This is Jim. As far as store size goes, we're really focused on a store size of at least 40,000 square feet. We think our sweet spot is somewhere between 40 and 50. And in most of the markets that we're currently serving, even some of the smaller markets,
componenttext: This is Jim. As far as store size goes, we're really focused on a store size of at least 40,000 square feet. We think our sweet spot is somewhere between 40 and 50. And in most of the markets that we're currently serving, even some of the smaller markets, we're finding that we need to go a little bit bigger in order to get our full offering in there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: And so in those larger stores, just -- correct me if I'm wrong -- but they tend to have a little bit of a longer tail in terms of the maturation. Is that right?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, of course. They tend to -- all of our stores tend to start off pretty strong, but the bigger stores definitely take longer to reach maturity. We're building them for the long term, and we don't want to cut ourselves short, so we think there's a lot o
componenttext: Yes, of course. They tend to -- all of our stores tend to start off pretty strong, but the bigger stores definitely take longer to reach maturity. We're building them for the long term, and we don't want to cut ourselves short, so we think there's a lot of opportunity with the bigger stores. This quarter, I think we -- our average store size we signed was approximately 44,000 square feet, and it's been running about 38,000, 39,000 before this. So you can see the trends towards the bigger stores again.

componenttextpreview: Well, we are continuing to work -- we've kind of built up over the last couple of years our exclusive brands team. It's a very robust team now. It's -- we just -- they just did a great job with some really nice holiday items for us. We are looking at cont
componenttext: Well, we are continuing to work -- we've kind of built up over the last couple of years our exclusive brands team. It's a very robust team now. It's -- we just -- they just did a great job with some really nice holiday items for us. We are looking at continuing to grow the products that we have and improve the quality in the grocery department. We have -- our primary exclusive brand has been our 365 brand, which is a little more value-added but still really good quality, but we started to brand more items now under the Whole Foods brand in grocery. And generally, like for instance, in the olive oil category, we went to single sources around the globe and got some really nice olive oil. So we market those as a Whole Foods brand versus our value at 365. We've also just, in the produce department, rebranded all our -- a lot of salad mixes that we had mostly into the Whole Foods brand as well. So we are looking for opportunities in different parts of the store to continue to expand the 365 and the Whole Foods brand.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: But we didn't actually give gross margin guidance. I guess, we gave some direction of that. I would just kind of point you back to our discussion earlier, which is, to say, our intention is, and we'll continue, over a multiyear process, to continue to bri
componenttext: But we didn't actually give gross margin guidance. I guess, we gave some direction of that. I would just kind of point you back to our discussion earlier, which is, to say, our intention is, and we'll continue, over a multiyear process, to continue to bring the gross margin down on a sequential fashion through a combination of these efforts around the price investments, and as we true up to the marketplace as needed, offset by our investments in our improvements in cost structure and process changes. So kind of what we're talking about is kind of a sort of a glide path that in the order of each year sequentially, a little bit more. And that's kind of how we've talked about the gross margin. So I think we'll leave it at that for now.

Good day, and welcome to the Whole Foods' First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]
It is now my pleasure to turn the program over to Cindy McCann, VP of Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth & Development; and David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations.
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Our press release and scripted remarks are now available on our website.
I will now turn the call over to Walter Robb.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone, from beautiful Austin, Texas.We're pleased with our Q1 results which reflect continued market share gains, healthy returns and a strong start to fiscal year 2015. Sales grew over 10% to $4.7 billion, with com
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good afternoon, everyone, from beautiful Austin, Texas.
We're pleased with our Q1 results which reflect continued market share gains, healthy returns and a strong start to fiscal year 2015. Sales grew over 10% to $4.7 billion, with comparable store sales growth accelerating on a 1- and a 2-year basis. With broad-based momentum across departments, store age classes and regions, we believe our many strategic initiatives, along with improving consumer confidence, are collectively contributing to our improved results.
Here are some of the highlights of our progress in Q1.
We launched our Values Matter national brand campaign, which you may have seen on TV and in print several times over the last few months. It was a real boost to team member morale, and we're looking forward to the final brand-tracking study results. The early read is very positive, indicating 100% increase in awareness for our target audience, with increases in both value perception and intent to shop versus our measured competitors.
We are now providing fresh grocery delivery options to more homes in America than any other food retailer. Since announcing our 15-market partnership with Instacart in September, our average weekly online delivery sales have already passed the $1 million mark. With online delivery sales as high as 5% of total sales in some of our stores, we're very excited about the future potential as we expand our reach to more markets, provide richer content highlighting our quality standards, and broaden our product offering.
A great example is happening this week for Valentine's Day. We're offering floral delivery in as little as 1 hour, with prices starting at $25 for a dozen of our high-quality, ethically sourced Whole Trade roses. Orders can be placed in advance, and combined with the ability to include chocolates or some other treats, this is a deal that's hard to beat.
We're the largest Apple Pay retailer in terms of both transactions and sales, further reinforcing the notion that our customer base wants to take advantage of the latest digital technologies. This payment option has grown quickly to 2% of sales, which we expect will continue to increase, especially after the Apple Watch launches this year. We are exploring opportunities to expand this successful partnership, including expanding functionality to support our Affinity program. 
Speaking of, we are pleased with the results of our 12-store Affinity test, which shows high activation and registration rates and above-average basket sizes for participants. We are continuing to incorporate customer feedback as we upgrade and add new features to this program, and recently added some new talent to lead our efforts in this area. We're excited to expand the pilot to our Washington, D.C. customers this spring, with hopes of having the program live in a majority of our stores for the 2015 holiday season.
And as promised, our new and improved Whole Foods Market app is now live, with nearly 600,000 downloads to date. iOS, Android users can access personalized and local store offers, events and information, along with 3,700 tested recipes where ingredients can be added to shopping lists with a single tap. Stay tuned for more unique and exciting features and upgrades throughout the year. 
We recognize that changing technology and growing demand for customization have fundamentally altered retailing forever. Customers now expect to connect with a brand whenever, wherever and however they choose. And as part of our broader digital road map, we are rapidly building out an extended customer experience beyond the 4 walls of our stores. At the same time, we believe customers will always want the human connection, the sense of community and the unparalleled shopping environment our stores deliver. As we accelerate our new store openings and step up refreshes of our oldest stores, we are focused on evolving a richer customer experience through innovation, improved value and higher levels of transparency on all the products that we sell.
In Q1, we opened 9 new stores, expanding into Ottawa, Canada and revitalizing our brand with new large flagships in both Houston and Boston. After opening our first taproom in 2010, we now have over 100 taprooms and wine bars company-wide.
Our Post Oak store in Houston took the next step, debuting our first-ever in-store microbrewery. Our second brewery is already opened, and we expect many more to come.
We refreshed 40 stores and are on track to complete 200 by year-end. While results vary depending on the scope of the project and a variety of other factors, stores typically see an immediate sales lift, and we expect these investments to be one of the many factors contributing to sales momentum this year and beyond.
We continue to see unit lift from the lower produce prices we are testing in several markets, which included external marketing to support these investments. It is too early for conclusive results, particularly given the holidays; however, we're looking at expanding the test to additional markets as we believe more competitive produce pricing will greatly benefit our overall value perception.
We launched our Responsibly Grown rating system, which assesses growing practices that impact human health and the environment and prohibits some of the most harmful pesticides. We believe these ratings draw clear lines of differentiation between our produce and our floral departments than those of our competitors. The program has been well-received by suppliers and customers, and close to 60% of our produce is already rated. We have seen the power of our differentiated standards in other areas, such as meat and seafood, and believe our Responsibly Grown ratings in produce will see similar success over time.
And after just 2 years of setting a deadline for full GMO transparency by 2018, we are well on our way with over 25,000 certified organic items in over 8,500 Non-GMO Project Verified products in our stores.
Turning back now to the results-- our results. Sales increased 10% driven by comps of 4.5% and square footage growth of 9.4%. A 20-basis-point decline in gross margin was partially offset by a 4-basis-point improvement in SG&A. It remains our intention to offset the impact of our strategic initiatives with improvements in our cost structure over the longer term. However, the timing of investments and the cost cuts may not align, as was the case this quarter.
Excluding $13 million or 28 basis points of estimated incremental marketing costs related to the launch of our brand campaign, SG&A improved 33 basis points due to leverage in salaries and benefits, more than offsetting the 20-basis-point decline in gross margin. EBITDA margin was 8.5%, and EPS increased 10% to $0.46.
For the last 8 quarters, our new store class has averaged sales per square -- gross square foot of $709, translating the productivity levels of 82% on a weighted square footage basis. Comp stores less than 2 years old have averaged 70% -- 17% comps, and most importantly, a 14% return on invested capital, well in excess of our weighted average cost of capital.
Please see our press release for more details on our outlook for this year and note that we estimate this year's Easter shift will positively impact comps in Q2 and negatively impact comps in Q3 by about 50 to 60 basis points.
As we look forward, we see more opportunity for the Whole Foods Market brand than ever before. We have a deep and seasoned leadership team and have been adding some fantastic new talent. Our strong and vibrant culture contributes to low turnover and high morale, which helps create a great customer experience. The demand for fresh healthy foods continues to surge, and we are best-positioned to benefit as the leading retailer of natural and organic foods and America's Healthiest Grocery Store. We are committed to continuing to improve and evolve, and with 408 stores and 116 signed leases, we have confidence that we will cross the 500-store mark in 2017 and triple our store base over the longer term.
We will now take questions.  [Operator Instructions]
Thank you.

componenttext: Well, we -- this is Walter. We anticipated that question, and we talked a lot bout ourselves. And really, the correct answer is we think it's all of them contributing to the momentum. If you -- because the comp results are broad-based across the company and store age classes, it just suggests that every single one of these things gained some-- and really helped us to gain some additional traction.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. We actually were very pleased that we're able to accomplish 40 refreshes in the first quarter, which has the holidays in it. So we're able to work our way around the holidays, and we've got some great results. Chicago, where we're just abou
componenttext: This is David. We actually were very pleased that we're able to accomplish 40 refreshes in the first quarter, which has the holidays in it. So we're able to work our way around the holidays, and we've got some great results. Chicago, where we're just about to open a lot of stores with our Dominick's that we've -- we're turning into a new Whole Foods. We finished the full remodel in Lakeview. We were forced to refresh Gold Coast, to refresh Tamarac in Denver, a store in Reno. This is all new decor, new graphics, just a whole new look. And we're seeing,  as Walter described, great results in all these stores. And so I would say, in the next quarter, we're going to accelerate because we'll have more time without the holidays. So we'll be doing a lot of work in the next few quarters.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: And we can take our next question from Charles Grom with Sterne Agee.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you guys -- when you evaluate your cost structure and you look at the P&L and direct store expenses, G&A, corporate overhead, I guess where do you guys think the biggest opportunity is to get leaner in the years ahead? Can we dive into that topic a l
componenttext: When you guys -- when you evaluate your cost structure and you look at the P&L and direct store expenses, G&A, corporate overhead, I guess where do you guys think the biggest opportunity is to get leaner in the years ahead? Can we dive into that topic a little bit?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think -- it's John here. I think it's everywhere. We're getting leverage right now as we continue to grow, but I think it's kind of taken that zero-based budgeting approach and looking at everything you're doing. I mean, we're very proud that we
componenttext: I mean, I think -- it's John here. I think it's everywhere. We're getting leverage right now as we continue to grow, but I think it's kind of taken that zero-based budgeting approach and looking at everything you're doing. I mean, we're very proud that we took out over 200 basis points on our cost structure in the last 5 years, and I think it's reasonable to conclude we can do the same thing on a go-forward basis. But it just requires a lot of hard work. I mean, obviously, if we knew exactly the big areas to cut, we'd already have done that. So it's about working at it, studying it, putting -- making it a priority, which is what our regional presidents are doing and our executive vice presidents of operations. We're very conscious of the fact that we need to take cost out of our system, and we've done it in the past, and we're going to continue to do it going forward.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. I'll just add, Chuck, that in addition to the looking up and down the P&L for the cost savings, and we had talked previously about distribution, purchasing and store labor, but also process changes and the way we do business. And we've tal
componenttext: This is Walter. I'll just add, Chuck, that in addition to the looking up and down the P&L for the cost savings, and we had talked previously about distribution, purchasing and store labor, but also process changes and the way we do business. And we've talked last quarter about our efforts around rethinking our company on how we do business and -- in areas such as data and in purchasing. These areas -- there's opportunities to make process changes, business process changes resulting in being more productive. So that's an area we're looking at hard together right now.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And this is a follow-up to that. Just when you think about reinvesting some of those cost savings, what are you looking to see from a unit elasticity to reinvest those cost cuts back into more produce items around the perimeter of the store and expa
componenttext: Okay. And this is a follow-up to that. Just when you think about reinvesting some of those cost savings, what are you looking to see from a unit elasticity to reinvest those cost cuts back into more produce items around the perimeter of the store and expanding to other markets beyond Austin?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, to be clear, we're looking at 3 buckets. We're looking at the price investments. We're looking at marketing, continuing our brand-building efforts, and third, in the area of technology capability that we described a lot in the call today. But I thin
componenttext: Well, to be clear, we're looking at 3 buckets. We're looking at the price investments. We're looking at marketing, continuing our brand-building efforts, and third, in the area of technology capability that we described a lot in the call today. But I think it's a little early to give you a direct answer on the produce because we're still really evaluating. We have like 4 or 5 tests going on, and we stepped up a couple of more, and I think we'll have more to say about that. But I think it's fair to say we're seeing good unit lift already. Do you want to add to that, John, or...

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're a public company, so we've got to juggle a lot of things, meaning, that we -- I mean, suppose if Whole Foods was a private company, we would act a lot faster. But it's been our experience that the market oftentimes overreacts to anything we do
componenttext: Well, we're a public company, so we've got to juggle a lot of things, meaning, that we -- I mean, suppose if Whole Foods was a private company, we would act a lot faster. But it's been our experience that the market oftentimes overreacts to anything we do. So a juggling act will be to continue to make price investments, continuing to invest in technology, continue to take costs out of the system as we can. And hopefully, those will be not perfectly aligned, but we think we can do it in such a way that we can continue sort of in the same type of upward trajectory that we've been doing. And we have to evaluate, how's our marketing? How did it do? I mean, when we did the national television advertising, we're actually very happy with it, but it's hard to know exactly. We do know how many impressions we got, but it's hard to know if that -- how of much that drove sales. We're making technology investments. We think that's going to help us be more profitable in the long run, but we still have a lot of work ahead of us. So I think the company is just going to focus on these areas, and we're going to continue to work  to take costs out of our system, and hopefully, that we'll be able to grow our sales and grow our comps and make all our stakeholders happy simultaneously. That's what we strive to do.

Question about if you can talk at all about the loyalty program you're working on. Can you just give us any sense of what it looks like? Because you don't have a regular promotional program, so it's not like you're transferring that to the card. So can you say anything more about what you're doing?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me take -- this is Walter. I'll take a shot. I mean, it's early, 12 stores, and we deliver -- they are going fast with the development, and we're doing it iteratively, so they were incorporating the feedback from customers as we go. But then it'
componenttext: Well, let me take -- this is Walter. I'll take a shot. I mean, it's early, 12 stores, and we deliver -- they are going fast with the development, and we're doing it iteratively, so they were incorporating the feedback from customers as we go. But then it's a combination of card and app. It's -- we're using the term affinity as opposed to loyalty to try to suggest that we're going to create an experience that resonates with our brand that's more than just sort of a pedestrian thing, but actually, additional benefits, additional loyalty, curating some sort of an relationship with the customer. And it's really -- we're just -- I think that's what we're seeing so far is that people are responding to it. The registration's higher than we expected. The basket size is very good. It's close to $100 on that program. So granted it could be that those are some of our better customers that are using it, but it's still a very good result in terms of the basket size that's coming out there. And I think we're just really -- we have a great team working on it, and we're really focused on continuing to improve the brand of it as well as the experience of it. And that's where we are right now.

componenttext: I was hoping that you could quantify the impact from the pricing investments for the quarter and maybe just for the gross margin line or if you even want to refer to kind of the basket dollar growth. And then related to that, I was hoping you could also comment just on the second quarter to date.  Information does look like the basket growth has slipped a little bit. I'm just curious if that's mix-related, or perhaps you're even getting a bit more aggressive with that price investment.

componenttextpreview: This is Glenda. I'll answer your second question first, which is that the second quarter results are for 3 weeks only and we had a lot of weather both last year and this year that are skewing the results. So it's very difficult to look at that and try to
componenttext: This is Glenda. I'll answer your second question first, which is that the second quarter results are for 3 weeks only and we had a lot of weather both last year and this year that are skewing the results. So it's very difficult to look at that and try to get too much information from it, so I caution you against doing that. And we are not quantifying what you're asking us for. We just want to say that we're in a very early position in the produce price investments, and we're continuing to look at what we're doing so far and tweaking it. And what we plan to roll it out, as we said, to more markets and do more tests in the quarters ahead. So hopefully, we will be able to give a better information at some point, but we're not prepared to do that this time.

componenttext: And I guess, so Walter, I would just point you to looking at the growth in the transaction count. If you look at the quarter and even the 5 weeks of the new quarter, look at the tremendous improvement in the transaction growth that's much more the story, I think, than the basket is to see a nice growth there.

componenttextpreview: This is A.C. It varies. We have seen some, especially when you often -- when you start a campaign in a particular area, a lot of times,competitors will react to it, and then they'll back off a little bit over time. So we've seen a little bit of that. We'v
componenttext: This is A.C. It varies. We have seen some, especially when you often -- when you start a campaign in a particular area, a lot of times,competitors will react to it, and then they'll back off a little bit over time. So we've seen a little bit of that. We've been in some other markets where people -- some competitors haven't adjusted at all to what we're doing. So it's kind of all over the map. And I mean, I think eventually people wind up going back to what their normal strategy was after the initial reaction to what you do.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: John here. One thing to understand is that only a few of our markets, just Whole Foods market, have like the leading market share for food in supermarkets or food retailing. I mean, in almost all of our markets, but maybe a few, we are -- our market share
componenttext: John here. One thing to understand is that only a few of our markets, just Whole Foods market, have like the leading market share for food in supermarkets or food retailing. I mean, in almost all of our markets, but maybe a few, we are -- our market share is relatively low. We're not -- I mean, we -- the point of it is we're not a big threat to a major supermarket who dominates a market. It doesn't make -- in most cases, it doesn't make much economic sense for them to go overact and lower all their produce prices to try to match Whole Foods Market because they're destroying their profitability or harming their profitability for very little market share gains. So this is an example where not having a big market share that works to our advantage because supermarkets either won't react or they won't -- we don't think they'll hold the prices for a long period of time, as A.C. made mention to. So yes, I mean, for the most part, I think in only 1 or 2 markets has there had been much of a reaction at all.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The customers reacted, though.
componenttext: The customers reacted, though.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about the refreshes. If you can give any further color regarding the 40 that you recently refreshed in terms of -- was an overwhelming majority more toward a lighter refresh or versus more toward a full-blown remodel? And then maybe if
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about the refreshes. If you can give any further color regarding the 40 that you recently refreshed in terms of -- was an overwhelming majority more toward a lighter refresh or versus more toward a full-blown remodel? And then maybe if you can also talk about the 200 that you have earmarked by year-end, kind of what levels of refresh are you expecting?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so David here. So really, the strategy we came up with was based on our great experience in Southern California with some of the oldest Whole Foods Markets in the company, the former Mrs. Gooch's. And we saw that the results of just doing lighter ref
componenttext: Yes, so David here. So really, the strategy we came up with was based on our great experience in Southern California with some of the oldest Whole Foods Markets in the company, the former Mrs. Gooch's. And we saw that the results of just doing lighter refreshes, essentially new color, new decor, new flooring sometimes, some new lighting, that immediately caused customers to kind of see the store in kind of a new light. And it -- really, we saw an immediate sales boost. So we -- essentially, with the 200 refreshes, we're primarily talking about decor, putting up to the most up-to-date look and feel of our stores. Stores like Brooklyn, New York, things like that. We're trying to -- we're looking at some of the way those stores feel, and so it's mainly décor and that kind of stuff. But we do -- every year, we do significant remodeling across our stores, adding new concepts like juice bars. Ken, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say, in the middle of that class, you have sort of where we're adding new cases, new programs and taking the latest things we've done in our newest stores and then implementing them into the existing stores throughout the group of stores in diffe
componenttext: Yes, I'd say, in the middle of that class, you have sort of where we're adding new cases, new programs and taking the latest things we've done in our newest stores and then implementing them into the existing stores throughout the group of stores in different regions. So a lot of the new product work that A.C. is working on in private label, in frozen product, requires more freezer doors, more dairy space. So we're adding cases in the growth areas of the business.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015

componenttext: Okay. Very helpful. Just as a follow-up question to that. I know you mentioned the Reno location earlier. But as a class are those 40 refreshes, would it be safe to say that the comp lift that you are seeing in total is maybe within a few hundred basis points between some of the ones that we're seeing that the most versus the least uplift?

I mean, we have correlated the consumer confidence index to comps to look at what the relationship there, but I think this has more to do this quarter with our particular efforts in these different areas that, together combined, have created a positive momentum for the company.

componenttext: Okay. Perfect. That's really good guidance. So my next question is regarding competition. I mean, clearly, this has been a focus of the market. It's been a focus of some of the stuff that we have done. Costco adding in a lot of stuff, Target's going to add in a lot of organics, Kroger's been -- what's your, guys, thoughts about the -- I know back in the 2000s, John, you mentioned that you thought it was good when these companies were doing this. Can you update us on your thought process as more of the big companies in the staples retailing space add in organics and better for you?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's A.C. It's a real dynamic changing marketplace. We do see products in-- a lot of organic products going to a lot of different retailers. It's interesting we had recent meetings with a lot of our top suppliers, and some of them are telling us that as s
componenttext: It's A.C. It's a real dynamic changing marketplace. We do see products in-- a lot of organic products going to a lot of different retailers. It's interesting we had recent meetings with a lot of our top suppliers, and some of them are telling us that as soon as a product hits our shelves, they get calls from other competitors saying we want that product, too. So we kind of take pride about being the first of getting products on the shelf, and that's what we do. We really innovate. A lot of our -- our culture is about innovation, and so there's -- we know that in this kind of market, people are going to be looking to sell a lot of the products we do because they know that we've been successful. And it's our job to keep innovating and coming up with new products, new things like our Responsibly Grown produce program, continuing to push our animal welfare and our sustainable seafood and all those kinds of things. So it's really a challenge to us to continue to grow and innovate, and that's what gets us excited. And that's what we've been doing, and that's where our focus is.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you think you're going to have to price some of the ubiquitous items where the competitions has -- are priced? Or is that not going to be a problem?
componenttext: Do you think you're going to have to price some of the ubiquitous items where the competitions has -- are priced? Or is that not going to be a problem?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, Whole Foods is about quality. It's about service. It's about selection. It's about ambience. We've never been, and we never will be, trying to be the lowest-priced supermarket. That's sort of not very attractive, doesn't give very good service. Th
componenttext: I mean, Whole Foods is about quality. It's about service. It's about selection. It's about ambience. We've never been, and we never will be, trying to be the lowest-priced supermarket. That's sort of not very attractive, doesn't give very good service. That's not what we're about. I mean, that's a valid niche in the marketplace just to try to be the low-priced, low-cost operator, but that's not Whole Foods' strategy. Our strategy has always been about the quality and the service and the selection. And yes, I mean, competition is harder today than it used to be, but on the other hand, Whole Foods is a lot better today than it used to be. In fact, competition -- it is your ally. It's your ally that helps you to get better. It knocks you out of your complacency. It keeps you from being lazy. It forces you to evolve. And Whole Foods Markets is a very competitive company. And when we are challenged, when competition rears its head, we respond. And that's what we're doing right now. We're responding. We're evolving. We're getting better. We're getting better quicker than our competitors are. So they're chasing us still, and maybe they have closed the gap a little bit, but we're accelerating our innovation cycle. So I think that's something people have never understood about Whole Foods Market. They think we're going to sit still and let people catch us, but we're not going to sit still. We're going to rapidly innovate and improve. That's what we've done for over 35 years, and that's what we're going to do going forward.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess, to just add to that, Scott, we're going to be relevant on price. We said that before. We'll say it again. We're -- our tracking of competitors' pricing and indexes is much more sophisticated now than it was 2 or 3 years ago. We know where we
componenttext: And I guess, to just add to that, Scott, we're going to be relevant on price. We said that before. We'll say it again. We're -- our tracking of competitors' pricing and indexes is much more sophisticated now than it was 2 or 3 years ago. We know where we stand relative to the others. And yes, of course, on the items that are ubiquitous, we're going to be in them. We're going to have to price them right. And we understand that. That's part of where some of these investments are going and where we continue to -- where we've kind of laid out the path over the next few years. So -- but it all fits within the broader context John just laid out about how we think about going to market and competing and showing up as a leading retailer in the marketplace.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. We really -- we're having great partnership with our friend at Instacart. We're working super close together with them, and the sales are growing week over week, every single week. So we're very excited about that. And we're looking -- we f
componenttext: This is David. We really -- we're having great partnership with our friend at Instacart. We're working super close together with them, and the sales are growing week over week, every single week. So we're very excited about that. And we're looking -- we feel like we've just scratched the surface this week with the Valentine's promotion is a new thing. We really haven't touched prepared foods. We really haven't started with that business yet, and that's coming. So we're adding products all the time, and we're working with Instacart to -- we're starting to actually reach capacity in some of our stores and needing to add more stores where the Instacart shoppers shop in some of our cities. And it's really just the beginning, it's early days, but sales are real. We're seeing some exciting stuff with the bad weather lately, where we're seeing orders really take off before bad weather. So we're picking up some additional sales that were lost to the bad weather before. Instacart adds additional shoppers in days like that. So all good news.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: So really, we do have incremental business here. We have a working number inside that's a pretty good size, and I think I'd like to have a run a little bit before we started to talk about that. But it's not insignificant in terms of incremental business s
componenttext: So really, we do have incremental business here. We have a working number inside that's a pretty good size, and I think I'd like to have a run a little bit before we started to talk about that. But it's not insignificant in terms of incremental business so...

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look over the long run, I mean, Whole Foods Market is got not going to have a supermarket on every corner, and yet we have very loyal customers. So we will begin to get more of the convenience business through Instacart than we've ever had bef
componenttext: Yes, if you look over the long run, I mean, Whole Foods Market is got not going to have a supermarket on every corner, and yet we have very loyal customers. So we will begin to get more of the convenience business through Instacart than we've ever had before because -- let's say they come to Whole Foods, they have to drive past other supermarkets to come to Whole Foods, and they do that maybe once a week or once every couple of weeks. But now with Instacart, if they need to pick up a quart of milk or they need to pick up some berries for their cereal, they can just order from Instacart. They don't need to go drive over to one of our competitors who might be closer than Whole Foods. So I think there will be some cannibalization, of course, and there'll be some incremental sales that we get. So -- and as Walter and David said, it's so early. I mean, it so early in this. We'll have so much more information a year from now than we have today, but all we can say is that it's growing very rapidly. Our customers love it, and we're really happy with it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Last thing, we are seeing some exciting steps being taken in terms of long-distance ordering, where customers live in one place but kids live in another place where Instacart is and they can still shop at Whole Foods. College kids, parents. So the expansi
componenttext: Last thing, we are seeing some exciting steps being taken in terms of long-distance ordering, where customers live in one place but kids live in another place where Instacart is and they can still shop at Whole Foods. College kids, parents. So the expansion of Whole Foods shopping universe is growing.

componenttext: Well, that's exactly what we did do when we launched that, that there was tests we did. We did marketing in every one of those markets to partner with the investments. So we still are doing that, and we expect to continue doing that along with whatever the next steps are we decide to take with respect to our brand campaign, which the first phase has kind of wrapped up. So I will say we got a great new Global Vice President of Marketing and Communications, Jeannine D'Addario. Happy to have her on the team. She's brought tremendous years of experience to our group, and so we have a real leader in that area now. And we're just kind of rediscovering. We're kind of rediscovering marketing after all these years and the power of communicating what your differences are and what you're up to.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jim. As far as store size goes, we're really focused on a store size of at least 40,000 square feet. We think our sweet spot is somewhere between 40 and 50. And in most of the markets that we're currently serving, even some of the smaller markets,
componenttext: This is Jim. As far as store size goes, we're really focused on a store size of at least 40,000 square feet. We think our sweet spot is somewhere between 40 and 50. And in most of the markets that we're currently serving, even some of the smaller markets, we're finding that we need to go a little bit bigger in order to get our full offering in there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so in those larger stores, just -- correct me if I'm wrong -- but they tend to have a little bit of a longer tail in terms of the maturation. Is that right?
componenttext: And so in those larger stores, just -- correct me if I'm wrong -- but they tend to have a little bit of a longer tail in terms of the maturation. Is that right?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, of course. They tend to -- all of our stores tend to start off pretty strong, but the bigger stores definitely take longer to reach maturity. We're building them for the long term, and we don't want to cut ourselves short, so we think there's a lot o
componenttext: Yes, of course. They tend to -- all of our stores tend to start off pretty strong, but the bigger stores definitely take longer to reach maturity. We're building them for the long term, and we don't want to cut ourselves short, so we think there's a lot of opportunity with the bigger stores. This quarter, I think we -- our average store size we signed was approximately 44,000 square feet, and it's been running about 38,000, 39,000 before this. So you can see the trends towards the bigger stores again.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we are continuing to work -- we've kind of built up over the last couple of years our exclusive brands team. It's a very robust team now. It's -- we just -- they just did a great job with some really nice holiday items for us. We are looking at cont
componenttext: Well, we are continuing to work -- we've kind of built up over the last couple of years our exclusive brands team. It's a very robust team now. It's -- we just -- they just did a great job with some really nice holiday items for us. We are looking at continuing to grow the products that we have and improve the quality in the grocery department. We have -- our primary exclusive brand has been our 365 brand, which is a little more value oriented but still really good quality. But we started to brand more items now under the Whole Foods brand in grocery. And generally, like for instance, in the olive oil category, we went to single sources around the globe and got some really nice olive oils. So we market those as a Whole Foods brand versus our value  365. We've also just, in the produce department, rebranded all our -- a lot of salad mixes that we had mostly into the Whole Foods brand as well. So we are looking for opportunities in different parts of the store to continue to expand the 365 and the Whole Foods brand.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: But we didn't actually give gross margin guidance. I guess, we gave some direction of that. I would just kind of point you back to our discussion earlier, which is, to say, our intention is, and we'll continue, over a multiyear process, to continue to bri
componenttext: But we didn't actually give gross margin guidance. I guess, we gave some direction of that. I would just kind of point you back to our discussion earlier, which is, to say, our intention is, and we'll continue, over a multiyear process, to continue to bring the gross margin down on a sequential fashion through a combination of these efforts around the price investments, and as we true up to the marketplace as needed, offset by our investments in our improvements in cost structure and process changes. So kind of what we're talking about is kind of a sort of a glide path that in the order of each year sequentially, a little bit more. And that's kind of how we've talked about the gross margin. So I think we'll leave it at that for now.

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Whole Food Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Vice President of Investor Relations, Cindy McCann. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth & Development; and David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations. As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-Q and 10-K. Our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website.
I will now turn the call over to John Mackey.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In Q2, our sales increased 10% to $3.6 billion driven by comps of 3.6% and square footage growth of 11%. We opened 11 new stores, including 3 relocations and 3 former Dominick's locations. There are many moving
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In Q2, our sales increased 10% to $3.6 billion driven by comps of 3.6% and square footage growth of 11%. We opened 11 new stores, including 3 relocations and 3 former Dominick's locations. There are many moving pieces so we can't definitively -- say definitively what caused the moderation comps during the quarter. We do know that we are not immune to the larger macro environment and the exploding demand for natural organic products has resulted in increased competition from many different channels. In addition, severe weather and cannibalization had a larger impact in Q2 than in Q1. We're on track to report our sixth consecutive year of record new store openings. A high percentage of our accelerated growth is in existing markets, which is driving market share gains but also producing a drag on comps from higher cannibalization in some cases. We saw this in Austin and Boston last year and we're seeing it in Chicago and Florida right now. Keep in mind that our average weekly sales per store are over $720,000. So even when a store gets hit, it is still highly profitable and continues to produce strong returns on invested capital. The store amount reports slower growth per year, but after anniversarying the new store opening, it regains momentum quickly. Gross margin excluding the nonroutine supplier credit declined 12 basis points due primarily to higher cost of goods sold as a percentage of sales. While we do our best to estimate the impact of our value efforts, it is more art than science and customer reactions can vary from our predictions. In addition, strong execution on the buy side helped offset our investments to a greater degree than we had forecast. For the fiscal year, we still expect a greater year-over-year decline in gross margin excluding LIFO than we saw last year. SG&A improved 29 basis points due to leverage in salaries and benefits. We're pleased with our continued expense discipline, particularly given comps were little light from our expectations. 
Turning to new stores, for the last 8 quarters, our new store class has averaged 36 stores with sales per gross square foot over $700, translating the productivity levels of 80% on a weighted square footage basis. Comparable stores less than 2 years old have averaged 16% comps, and more importantly, a 13% return on invested capital, well in excess of our weighted average cost of capital. Our EVA-based approach to site selection allows us to consider markets from Kansas to New York City. While our expectations for sales productivity and operating expenses vary depending on the type of market and other factors, when balanced with the appropriate level of capital investment, a wide variety of markets can produce healthy returns for our shareholders. We are reaffirming our fiscal year targets, comps have averaged 2.8% over the last 5 weeks, up from 2.4% for the last 9 weeks of Q2 excluding Easter. We're encouraged by this improvement and are continuing to lean into the changing marketplace, moving forward with our investments, value, marketing and technology. We continue to see unit lift from the lower produce pricing we have implemented in several markets. We added more markets in Q2 and expect this to expand as the year progresses. We continue to believe more competitive produce pricing will greatly benefit our overall value perception. We're continuing our successful Value Matters brand advertising campaign. Beginning next week, this next round will focus on digital marketing, including online video, digital display ads and mobile and social ads. In Q2, our average weekly Instacart sales increased to $1.5 million. We continue to be the leading Apple Pay retailer with over 3.3 million transactions and surpassed 4 million followers on Twitter. Given those metrics, it is not surprising that in our brand tracking results, digital outperformed with our key demographics. We plan to follow-up this fall with an exciting new Values Matter campaign which will include national television and digital. 
Now turning to other news, in our investor conference in February, I said we would be making some pretty exciting announcements over the coming months reflecting our ability to learn and grow and evolve. Today, we're excited to announce the launch of the new uniquely branded store concept unlike anything that currently exists in the marketplace. Offering our industry-leading quality standards at value prices, this new format will feature modern streamlined design, innovative technology and a curated selection. We'll offer convenient, transparent and values-oriented experience geared towards millennial shoppers while appealing to anyone looking for high-quality fresh food at great prices. We're building a team to focus exclusively on this new concept and are already negotiating leases. We plan to begin opening stores next year, and given the more standardized design and product assortment, we expect a fairly rapid expansion from there. Over the next several years, we have explored the idea of new format several times but never felt the time was right, particularly given our accelerated growth plans. That issue is now behind us as we have successfully increased our new store openings for 6 years. In addition, we now have a successful track record of opening some smaller format stores with a lower cost structure. 
The Whole Foods market brand has helped lead the shifting consciousness toward fresh, healthy foods by offering the highest quality, broader selection and best customer service, and we believe we can still triple the number of Whole Foods market stores in the United States. At the same time, we have also seen an opportunity to leverage our long history of retail innovation and extend our reach into marketplace beyond 1,200 stores. We want to underscore we see this as an and to our Whole Foods market brand and not on or. We believe the growth potential for this new and complementary brand to be as great as it is for our highly successful Whole Foods Market brand.  This is all we're going to reveal today but we look forward to share more detail about this exciting news venture some time before Labor Day. 
We'll now take questions. Our call will end at 445 Central Time today to allow more time for questions. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We can take our first question from Vincent Sinisi from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015

I know you said it's hard to say exactly or try to get a gauge exactly what happened, but can you maybe get a sense for directionally how comps were not only in those heavier cannibalize marketed but also maybe those versus some of the other markets was outside of those? Was it pretty consistent, or did you see any notable changes?

And then with the tick up that we have seen in the last 5 weeks, that was in transaction count also, so both the decline and in the uptick now have been in transaction count.

componenttext: Or a deceleration, not a decline.

componenttext: Okay, and then though one quick follow-up, if I may, realizing that it's early for this new concept but can you just give us kind of more a strategic or a qualitative position around how you kind of plan to balance that upcoming concept with, of course, all the initiatives that you're currently putting into and what your store early stages and current stores?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So there's a lot of that question. We're really going to stick to share. I think this biggest rational as this marketplace continues to grow and explode and I think by creating a second growth vehicle for our company, we can broaden the accessibility to f
componenttext: So there's a lot of that question. We're really going to stick to share. I think this biggest rational as this marketplace continues to grow and explode and I think by creating a second growth vehicle for our company, we can broaden the accessibility to fresh, healthy foods and we continue to be leaders in that sense. With respect to the resources, I mean, we said today we're creating a team right now and it's already in process, including leadership and the rest of the team members to be all focused on this. And so we are adding additional resources to be able to hit the gate running on this. We're going to have a lot more to share with you before Labor Day or some sort. We're going to have a special event where we'll communicate all the details about this and much more particulars at that time. But that's pretty much what we're going to say today.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think a couple of things we could maybe emphasize is that we do think this is a very unique concept, it's not like anything else that's out there right now. So we think we're going to come up with a complementary brand and strategy that fits well alongs
componenttext: I think a couple of things we could maybe emphasize is that we do think this is a very unique concept, it's not like anything else that's out there right now. So we think we're going to come up with a complementary brand and strategy that fits well alongside the Whole Foods Market brand. There's thing we can do with the Whole Foods Market brand. We can continue to do a better job on our expense discipline, we could continue to be aggressive in gradually lowering some of our prices, but the Whole Foods Market brand stands for the highest quality, the best selection, the highest degree of service so there's -- that brand can bend a little bit but we can't break it, we're not willing to break it. But we think we can create a complementary brand that can go places the Whole Foods Market brand cannot effectively go. So we're kind of trying to tantalize people a little bit today, but there would be a bigger reveal later on before Labor Day. We'll give you the name, we'll give you some more details about it. We're very excited about it, but we knew this information's going to leak out because we're negotiating leases. And so then if it leaks out, then we are to deny it. So it's better to just be proactive, get it out there. Yes, we are going to open a new concept store, a new brand, we'll open it up in 2016, and we're about to sign, we're signing leases right now so the information's out there. That's all we are really going to say about it today.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So David, I'm kind of really excited about the creative team, the creative start-up team we are putting together to work on this new concept. We're taking some of the sharpest, brightest folks within the Whole Foods Market and they're going to be working
componenttext: So David, I'm kind of really excited about the creative team, the creative start-up team we are putting together to work on this new concept. We're taking some of the sharpest, brightest folks within the Whole Foods Market and they're going to be working exclusively on us with us and like as John said, it's actually going to be an innovative retail concept.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we can take our next question from Charles glom from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: And we can take our next question from Charles glom from Sterne Agee.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just back in February you talked a lot about some of the initiatives you were planning to roll out for the year, loyalty, the price efforts, the remodels. Just wonder if we can talk a little bit about the price efforts. Can we did a little bit deeper into
componenttext: Just back in February you talked a lot about some of the initiatives you were planning to roll out for the year, loyalty, the price efforts, the remodels. Just wonder if we can talk a little bit about the price efforts. Can we did a little bit deeper into each of those 3 drivers, and I guess how much are you assuming that your business gets better as we progress throughout 2015 from those efforts?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chuck, this is Walter. The 3 buckets we referenced last call basically are pricing, the marketing and the technology along with our step-up efforts around bringing down our cost structure. So in each of the areas as we reference today, we're continuing th
componenttext: Chuck, this is Walter. The 3 buckets we referenced last call basically are pricing, the marketing and the technology along with our step-up efforts around bringing down our cost structure. So in each of the areas as we reference today, we're continuing the efforts in produce and within the frame of bringing the gross margins down sequentially year-over-year like we talked about. With respect to the marketing, I think we're reaffirming the Values Matters been successful starting last week, the whole new digital Values Matter rolls out with social mobile ads, digital ads and I think what you'll see this time is a better connection to actually the shopping asset which is essentially it will connect you to Instacart, it will connect you to the Affinity app, will connect you to the newsletters. So to try to work on the conversion from those ads and so we're continuing. And then this fall, we'll come out with the next version of the TV ad set. We will add onto what we did the first time around. With respect to the technology, the Affinity we're moving to the next round of markets this summer, we continue to be very pleased with that, we're getting good results, the data points. We're taking in the next 3 markets this summer and we are going to continue to learn and grow from that experience and Instacart, the numbers are in the script, but our average sales per week are up 50% from the last time we spoke to you. So that continues to grow. So there's kind of an update on these 3 buckets and we're also continuing to work on our cost control as well, and we'll have more details on that as the year progresses.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good, just a follow up to the first question, when we look at the comp, the comp deceleration from the first quarter, and I think John alluded to being a little bit below your expectations, how do you handicap it? Where does it fallout? Was it more cannib
componenttext: Good, just a follow up to the first question, when we look at the comp, the comp deceleration from the first quarter, and I think John alluded to being a little bit below your expectations, how do you handicap it? Where does it fallout? Was it more cannibalization? Was it more competition? And I guess could you quantify those buckets for us?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's difficult -- it's John here. It's difficult to quantify it but there's a lot of factors involved. As we mentioned, we have some severe cannibalization going on right now in Chicago and Florida because of very successful new stores who opened up there
componenttext: It's difficult -- it's John here. It's difficult to quantify it but there's a lot of factors involved. As we mentioned, we have some severe cannibalization going on right now in Chicago and Florida because of very successful new stores who opened up there, those markets have taken some big chunk out of those 2 cities. We know that we have -- we do have more competition than ever before, there's no question about that. And, finally, we've got -- we did have some -- it's a very weird, weird quarter for weather particularly in the North Atlantic region. We have a lot of store closures. So I mean weather is a very difficult thing to predict and sometimes it helps you, sometimes it hurts you. On balance it hurt us a little bit on Q2. So it's hard to say exactly how that divides up, but I think all 3 can be considered factors.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Ken Goldman from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Ken Goldman from JPMorgan.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015

componenttext: John, you mentioned there were a variety of reasons for the comp slowdown but you weren't 100% sure what the smoking gun was. Did some of the volatility in your comps lately incent you to sort of roll out your rewards cards any more quickly? Or do anything else get to know some of the data behind your customers? You guys gave some great data presentations, I thought at your Analyst Day, I'm just wondering how it makes you think about that, if at all.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: About Affinity card, well, yes, I think the affinity card, yes, that's what we call it, I think, yes, I think the thing has really laid the foundation properly and to really make sure we got the technology platform working well. We are iterating daily on
componenttext: About Affinity card, well, yes, I think the affinity card, yes, that's what we call it, I think, yes, I think the thing has really laid the foundation properly and to really make sure we got the technology platform working well. We are iterating daily on this platform, and yes, I mean we're constantly talking about the balance between additional investments and the speed of investments and what's the right pace for those to do that as we look at the total picture. But I think with respect to Affinity, our next step is clear, which is we're taking them now which is the next 3 markets, that's going to give us a much broader base for understanding how that works, how customers use it. It looks that the basket's higher, it looks the frequency improves. All those things look very promising. We just really got to continue to work and to iterate it sequentially as opposed to we're not ready to jump to the whole company yet.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Meredith Adler from Barclays.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Meredith Adler from Barclays.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would like to talk a little bit about the new format, it would be interesting to see what it looks like. The fact that it's different, it's hard to envision. But I'm trying to understand how you kind of how you see getting 1,200 stores with Whole Foods
componenttext: I would like to talk a little bit about the new format, it would be interesting to see what it looks like. The fact that it's different, it's hard to envision. But I'm trying to understand how you kind of how you see getting 1,200 stores with Whole Foods and then opening some meaningful number of these new stores. Aren't you going to be either cannibalizing yourself or going after similar markets, or because I guess I've never quite understood how did you get to 1,200 stores at Whole Foods.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, 1,200 stores of Whole Foods is not going to be a difficult thing to do at all. I mean we're already at 420, we got 114 in development. So we're well on our way for that. One thing to understand is, is that the market is exploding. I mean, it's i
componenttext: Meredith, 1,200 stores of Whole Foods is not going to be a difficult thing to do at all. I mean we're already at 420, we got 114 in development. So we're well on our way for that. One thing to understand is, is that the market is exploding. I mean, it's incredible what's happening. I mean, one of the things that's fun to do at Whole Foods is we go back and we look at what our sales were per store 5 years ago, 8 years ago, 10 years ago. Our sales are so much higher, our sales per square foot is so much higher. At the same time we've been so successful that we've actually bred a lot more competition, and everybody's jumping kind of on the natural organic food bandwagon, and that's really, frankly, due to our success. So I don't see that there's a problem, but what I do think is that the Whole Foods Market brand is very targeted to a certain type of customer, certain type of shopper. We think the opportunity's a lot larger than that. And we think that our certain customers at the Whole Foods Market brand's attractive to, but there's are other customers that is less attractive to. We see a whole generation of young people coming up who are quite interested in natural organic foods. The millennial generation, they're idealistic, they're values-oriented, they're mission-driven, these all play to Whole Foods Market's strengths. They're also very value-conscious. So we think a streamlined, hip, cool technology-oriented store unlike any store anybody's ever seen before that has lower capital, lower cost, perhaps lower labor costs, and lower prices is going to be very, very attractive to that particular generation. So you can't envision it yet because it hasn't been created yet. We're creating yet. It will be new, it will be different, it will be unlike any of the other stores you've seen out there, and hey, sometimes you have to wait to see it but it will be worth waiting for.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, this is Walter, I just want to add to that we continue to have a lot of excitement and enthusiasm for Whole Foods Market, our flagship brand. We got over 70 stores knocking back $1 million a week. We have tremendous success and vitality in this
componenttext: Meredith, this is Walter, I just want to add to that we continue to have a lot of excitement and enthusiasm for Whole Foods Market, our flagship brand. We got over 70 stores knocking back $1 million a week. We have tremendous success and vitality in this company that continues to grow and as we open 39, 38, 39, 40 new stores next year we're continuing that path. And it just looks like this new format that we're developing, we're going to tell you more about in a few months is going to be able to access many more broader markets probably couldn't serve with our flagship brand. So you think about it, if everybody knows this marketplace for fresh, healthy foods is getting larger by the day with the different announcements the people are making in this new concept that we're developing will allow us to access and participate and contribute and lead in many more markets than -- this opens up a whole lot of new range of opportunity for all of our stakeholders. So that's the kind of complementary idea that John talked about earlier.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015

componenttext: That's very helpful and interesting, can I just ask one sort of housekeeping question. You talked about the and adjusted to the employee appreciation event in the last 5 weeks, does that mean that the actual comp was lower, or you've already reflected that in the comp, the 2.8% that you reported?
