headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch a little bit more on gross margins. So the gross margin performance again was better than expectation this quarter, so as you guys look at the price investments that you've been making, the past few months versus prior quarters, has
componenttext: I just wanted to touch a little bit more on gross margins. So the gross margin performance again was better than expectation this quarter, so as you guys look at the price investments that you've been making, the past few months versus prior quarters, has there been any moderation in the magnitude of price investments?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, it's A.C. No, there really hasn't been the moderation. We attribute the fact that our gross margin do not decline as much in this quarter as we originally projected largely to just a little bit better purchasing than we originally -- a little better r
componenttext: Hi, it's A.C. No, there really hasn't been the moderation. We attribute the fact that our gross margin do not decline as much in this quarter as we originally projected largely to just a little bit better purchasing than we originally -- a little better results on the purchasing side. We are able to negotiate stronger value discounts with some of our suppliers especially in the grocery and produce areas than we originally thought. So when we projected that we were going to do certain investments in price as it turns out because of the volume we move, we're able to actually negotiate a little bit better cost in that than we expected to. We see, when we look at for the rest of the year, we are holding our guidance, we still see that our sequential decline in gross margin it will be what we have said at the beginning of the year would be. So we think we're going to continue with this and if we've got a better purchasing here, we'll do a little bit deeper investment going forward for the rest of the year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, David here too. I also want to point out there are so many great products that we make inside our stores and Ken and I work with all the operators in the regions on more and more products that are made exclusively inside of our Whole Foods stores. So
componenttext: Yes, David here too. I also want to point out there are so many great products that we make inside our stores and Ken and I work with all the operators in the regions on more and more products that are made exclusively inside of our Whole Foods stores. So these are products we're manufacturing ourselves. So we're really working on recipe discipline, shrink control. So it's kind of a countervailing thing that's unrelated to the pricing efforts in things like produce and grocery and whole body, those kinds of areas.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just switching to competition, we continue to hear more and more about natural organic expanding to other channels. Just wanted to understand what you guys are maybe doing differently -- what are you doing differently now to combat this threat?'
componenttext: Just switching to competition, we continue to hear more and more about natural organic expanding to other channels. Just wanted to understand what you guys are maybe doing differently -- what are you doing differently now to combat this threat?'

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think we're doing several things that we have sort of addressed. We're investing in value and prices, we're doing better job at controlling our expenses, we're investing more in marketing and we're investing more in technology. At the same time,
componenttext: I mean, I think we're doing several things that we have sort of addressed. We're investing in value and prices, we're doing better job at controlling our expenses, we're investing more in marketing and we're investing more in technology. At the same time, today, we've announced that we are coming up with a new format that we think would be specifically geared to address an entire generation of people coming up that we think line up well with Whole Foods, and this new concept would be less capital, more streamlined, it will be value-oriented but it will still have Whole Foods quality standards, it will still have our mission and drive. We think it's going to be an exciting new concept. So these are the things that we're doing. Also in some ways the new competition is -- as much as the market's expanding, a lot of people get into it for the first time and they are going to temporarily gain some shares because for convenience standpoint, they migrate certain customers over. But then they anniversary that. So the question is whether they will be able to comp their comps, 2, 3, 4, 5 years down the road. And so, I mean, one of the things that people don't fully understand is that even if Whole Foods Market just stopped, I mean our comps went flat, we were at 0, our sales per square foot, our return on invested capital, our whole store operating model is still, frankly, light years better than just anybody on the other food retailers out there that are at least public that we have their data on. So it's going to take a long time before people can catch up with us, but we're not going to sit still. We're going to continue to innovate, we're going to continue to differentiate ourselves, our commitment to prepared foods, top the sales we do there. I mean, we're doing all that we can, but the reality is there's more competition. Hey, I wish that wasn't true, but it's where we find ourselves and we think we're doing, taking the necessary steps to compete well and continue to win in the marketplace.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll add a little bit to that. We're clearly in a transition to a much more expanded marketplace. You see that's what you're referencing with foods and products available in many more places than historically. I think just add a little to each of those, t
componenttext: I'll add a little bit to that. We're clearly in a transition to a much more expanded marketplace. You see that's what you're referencing with foods and products available in many more places than historically. I think just add a little to each of those, the price thing for us is striving for relevance on price so we can continue our conversation on quality. So like we said before, we're not looking to race to the bottom. We're looking to be relevant on price so we can really, really have this conversation about quality. The second bucket with marketing specifically that is about communicating the differences because we do not just sell the same stuff. Markets sometimes wants to drop it down to lowest common denominator and while there are some common products, much of our product notes is different and I think the ability for us to communicate the the differences in our product and the product offerings that we're bringing to our customers is where we're really trying to go to these efforts, as well as create kind of a personal connection to the Affinity. Granted we've been a little slower perhaps than we should have been in terms of getting those things in place, but we are through the use of technology, building out and extending ourself where our customers are, whether it's Instacart or home delivery, which we're doing more than any other grocery store in America now, and we're really just getting started, whether it's through Affinity which builds a personal connection to customers who allow to customize their relationship with us. Whether it's through the ease of Apple Pay which will soon go to the next thing you know about which gives customers the easier, the most seamless experience, whether it's our improving app which ultimately these things can be put together to get customers integrated experience with Whole Foods digitally. All of those things are in the works, and I wish that we were doing them faster, but we're doing them as fast as we can do as we replace all of our foundational systems and technology to get there. Ultimately where we're going is to create this fuller, richer experience, physically and digitally, for our customers, as John says, we're taking these steps and we're doing it at a time when the marketplace is going through a huge transition. But make no mistake about it, we still have a tremendous amount of strength in this company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd like to actually add, we're talking about differentiation. We're still doing -- we're really ramping up a lot of our differentiation a lot on the product side. I mean, it's true that you might take some branded natural organic products that we sell an
componenttext: I'd like to actually add, we're talking about differentiation. We're still doing -- we're really ramping up a lot of our differentiation a lot on the product side. I mean, it's true that you might take some branded natural organic products that we sell and other people sell and everybody has the same things, but we're doing a lot -- we got a lot of things in place to help differentiate ourselves in product side. We're ramping up our exclusive brands team so that we can come out with, some really -- got some really great innovative and exciting products coming out in over the next 6 to 9 months. We also continue to differentiate ourselves in produce with our Responsibly Grown program and our Whole Trade guarantee products. We're the largest seller of fair trade produce and flowers in the U.S, and we continue to expand -- rapidly expand our supply there. And we've got some great new products coming in, in our meat and seafood department. We've established this Club Pack frozen program, it's doing extremely well in our seafood departments and is a very unique, high-quality product, really great price. So there's a lot of work going on, on the product side to continue to differentiate our product mix and really add the kind of products that our customers really like.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. On the in-store experience, we continue to innovate juice bars, continue to grow it as a big part of the breakfast experience in our stores. We just opened a new juice bar with our friends Hugo Fresh in Miami and we have a great juice bar w
componenttext: This is David. On the in-store experience, we continue to innovate juice bars, continue to grow it as a big part of the breakfast experience in our stores. We just opened a new juice bar with our friends Hugo Fresh in Miami and we have a great juice bar with our friends Vega up in Vancouver. We're closing in on 100 tap rooms where we serve beer, wine, all sorts of exciting things, making pitas in our new West Loop store. We're continuing to be the retail innovator in terms of in-store experience, again, things you can't get online you can only get at Whole Foods Market. I encourage you guys to go into some of our new stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Stephen Crumley from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Stephen Crumley from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the new concept, does the distribution model have to change or do you have the capacity for these smaller stores at this point?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the new concept, does the distribution model have to change or do you have the capacity for these smaller stores at this point?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We think one of the great things about this model is, is that we can leverage all of our existing distribution capabilities and our distribution partners. We can use our regional structure and yet we can create a more centrally driven model from a product
componenttext: We think one of the great things about this model is, is that we can leverage all of our existing distribution capabilities and our distribution partners. We can use our regional structure and yet we can create a more centrally driven model from a product standpoint, a pricing standpoint and an overall selection standpoint while allowing innovation to occur on limited basis within a regional and local basis. So we think we've got the right structure to really create a new model that will be highly successful. I mean, we can talk about it in general terms. We want to limit what we talk about in this call. It would be so much easier once we open the first one and people can come look at it, then you see it. We will reveal a little bit more in the next few months, but we're excited about it, we think it's a big deal. But hey, proof will be when we start opening them up.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: The question is we don't need a new distribution network.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Just changing gears a little bit, you mentioned doing a better job on expense discipline and you saw some leverage on salaries and benefits among other areas. Where are the improvements coming from at this point? And is there kind of a new
componenttext: That's helpful. Just changing gears a little bit, you mentioned doing a better job on expense discipline and you saw some leverage on salaries and benefits among other areas. Where are the improvements coming from at this point? And is there kind of a new leverage point to be thinking about as it relates to the comp?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mean comp on SG&A [indiscernible] on sales? I mean, the trick on expense leverage, it's just continued hard work. It's retails, details, about getting in there and looking at your business processes, it's something we're doing right now. We have a num
componenttext: You mean comp on SG&A [indiscernible] on sales? I mean, the trick on expense leverage, it's just continued hard work. It's retails, details, about getting in there and looking at your business processes, it's something we're doing right now. We have a number of task force doing, examining things like how we buy in the stores, how we serve in prepared foods, and we're looking at this and we're taking cost out of the system in a systematic basis. 29 basis points times $15 billion over a year is a heck of a lot of money. And we are going to continue to do that. So I think that's what we've announced we're going to do. We're also getting leverage as we continue to grow and open new stores, we're getting leverage in our overall G&A as well as store leverage. So I think that's a long-term -- I mean, we look out, we do our own internal work several years in advance, and we see, okay, we're going to continue to get expense leverage, we're going to continue to work on a process, we're going to continue to take these costs out and we're going to continue to lower prices, lower our gross margins accordingly and hopefully we'll be able to produce a similar type of bottom line that we've been producing for the last several years. That's our strategy, and we think it is a good strategy.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'm kind of encouraged by what the stores are doing. We're still committed to doing over 200 by the end of this year. We've got good results this quarter. There's some great stories, Bishop's Corner in West Hartford in Connecticut. Just spo
componenttext: This is David. I'm kind of encouraged by what the stores are doing. We're still committed to doing over 200 by the end of this year. We've got good results this quarter. There's some great stories, Bishop's Corner in West Hartford in Connecticut. Just spoke to Laura Dermon, the Regional President there, their sales are higher than the regional comp number, and we're very excited about focusing a lot of energy in Colorado sort of like [indiscernible], Cherry Creek, Colfax, Wash Park, Colorado Boulevard. Some of our oldest stores former Wild Oats, where we're doing the new color, the new painting, the new look, but we are significant chunk of them are going to happen in the summer which is the slowest time for sales for us, but also the most convenient time to do without getting in the way of our customers. So expect a significant chunk to happen in the June, July, August timeframe, but we're still committed to doing and encouraged to do them all by the end of the year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, we started at the beginning of this year with several of our markets with our first investments. And then we just started, really just rolled out not too long ago our second wave of investments. And again, we're a little different. Some were doing
componenttext: Right, we started at the beginning of this year with several of our markets with our first investments. And then we just started, really just rolled out not too long ago our second wave of investments. And again, we're a little different. Some were doing more -- everyday low pricing, others were doing a stronger promotional strategy. I think the ones we added in the second wave are more on the promotional side and some additional regions. Our plan is to continue with those with all of that going forward, and then to add at some point later in this fiscal year, we're going to add some more markets to it. But right now, we've got plans to, as we move into the new fiscal year, continue with another wave of  investments.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, I mean, obviously, everyone acknowledges you have a great store format and I appreciate this opportunity that you're looking into. But I guess the question I have is that while there is a significant opportunity with this new concept, how do you think
componenttext: So, I mean, obviously, everyone acknowledges you have a great store format and I appreciate this opportunity that you're looking into. But I guess the question I have is that while there is a significant opportunity with this new concept, how do you think about the risk that this new concept won't start a broad-based decline in margins across the board in natural and organic? And obviously including a bigger gross margin risk at your Whole Foods standard stores? And what is not just kind of a slippery slope on the margin front.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Instead of a slippery slope, Karen, I think we've already articulated for the last year and a half that the trajectory at the gross margins are going to continue to incrementally move down as the competitive marketplace emerges. So I think that we won't a
componenttext: Instead of a slippery slope, Karen, I think we've already articulated for the last year and a half that the trajectory at the gross margins are going to continue to incrementally move down as the competitive marketplace emerges. So I think that we won't acknowledge that that's as this thing broadens and widens but the thing is the opportunity keeps getting so much better, here's another way for us to do that that's going to access other communities and other folks that we could not access particularly with our Whole Foods flagship brand. So no one's saying that the size and opportunities is just enormous. I think we're all seeing that unfold daily. But I think we've already kind of laid out the trajectory that we see that the margins will in fact, go down year-over-year for the next several years. You want to add to that, John?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Karen, imagine we have this larger Whole Foods Market sort of flagship stores that got, think about our one in Austin, for example, which is a good example, a big store, great prepared foods, lots of different vendors, huge service, it's an experience whe
componenttext: Karen, imagine we have this larger Whole Foods Market sort of flagship stores that got, think about our one in Austin, for example, which is a good example, a big store, great prepared foods, lots of different vendors, huge service, it's an experience when you go into the store. And then say that's kind of the Whole Foods Market brand trajectory. And then you have this new format that is -- the stores are not as large, they're more streamlined, they're tech-savvy, there's less capital being invested in it, they're very convenient for people and they're very value-focused with a tailored product mix. So maybe if you go into a big Whole Foods Market, maybe you've got a thousand different kinds of wine from a price point all the way from $2.99 to a few hundred dollars, but maybe in our new concept store, you'll have a more tailored mix of wine. It would just be good quality value wines and they won't have the same upward trajectory. So is it something that's going to harm Whole Foods Market? We don't see it that way. We see it as complementary. We'll see that our loyalty card program will include both brands we see people crossing over in it. And -- but one of the things that I think I've learned from other businesses is you have to be willing to evolve with the marketplace. You have to be willing to do what it takes to serve your customers better and you can't not do that because it might possibly take sales from your existing flagship brand. You got to be willing to serve your customers where you find them. That would cause the Whole Foods Market flagship brand to evolve as we roll out our next brand, just like it's evolving right now with the competition that we're facing. So we see that there was a huge opportunity that the natural organic foods revolution is sweeping America. We intend to be -- continue to be the leader in this category for the rest of the century. And so we're evolving with the marketplace. We're going to create a new -- we are creating a new format, a new concept that's not been seen, that no one else has done, it's going to be unique and we think it's going to be very exciting to the customer base and we'll see what happens. It's hard to predict exactly what's going to happen until you start doing it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just going to add, I'm really glad John brought that up because you were there at the investor conference, we talked a lot about about us being a company that is continually changing, evolving, growing, you read the marketplace as it is and you say
componenttext: I was just going to add, I'm really glad John brought that up because you were there at the investor conference, we talked a lot about about us being a company that is continually changing, evolving, growing, you read the marketplace as it is and you say how do you continue to respond? How do you continue to evolve? And for us as a group thing about it, we think this is a way for to think as it gets bigger, it allows us to broaden our reach, accelerate our growth, serve more people and bringing healthier food to the world. So we do see it as an evolution of our company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I agree, evolution is obviously the key to survival. I did have another question just on your existing store base and your store growth plans, obviously looking back to 2007 and '08 when you find larger stores and then kind of retrenched and obviously
componenttext: No, I agree, evolution is obviously the key to survival. I did have another question just on your existing store base and your store growth plans, obviously looking back to 2007 and '08 when you find larger stores and then kind of retrenched and obviously there was a macro element to retrenching, but you're obviously moving on your Whole Foods fleet to a larger format. And I guess, first question is, is the the larger increase in store size basically to accommodate mostly the wine bars and the beer halls? And then can you help me to understand how that impacts ROIC going forward? Different packages wine bar and...

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We do have our tap rooms and wine bars. We want to make Whole Foods Market this incredible experience for people, I mean, we want the stores to be fun, we want them to be exciting, we want them to be places that are destinations for people to come. It's a
componenttext: We do have our tap rooms and wine bars. We want to make Whole Foods Market this incredible experience for people, I mean, we want the stores to be fun, we want them to be exciting, we want them to be places that are destinations for people to come. It's an experience that -- food is a very sensual, exciting thing for people. We want these stores to be incredibly exciting. So the trend line for Whole Foods Market will probably be towards larger stores, they're very experientially oriented with a differentiated product mix for the customer base. And then we'll have our new format that the stores would be more streamlined, it won't be as large, it would be value-oriented, there will be a more tailored product mix. They'll be very tech-savvy stores and they'll be very exciting to the -- until we think to the meeting differentiation of about 90 million people. We think these concepts are very complementary to each other. There will be some overlap, but in the best of all words for Whole Foods, people will shop both stores. They'll come in and enjoy the big exciting Whole Foods Market and they'll do fill-in shops at the new concept and their stores will intermix with each other in a very unique way. We'll have a larger product mix at the bigger flagship Whole Foods Market stores than we will in the new format. We'll have a more tailored mix there. So that's what's -- we really can't say too much more than that. There'll be a bigger reveal later on as we get -- this summer. So it's not that far away. You have to wait a few months, and we'll give you more.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We will use our technology platforms and our programs to connect shoppers across both of them so that will also support the complementary of both.
componenttext: We will use our technology platforms and our programs to connect shoppers across both of them so that will also support the complementary of both.

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Whole Foods' Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Vice President of Investor Relations, Cindy McCann. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth & Development; and David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations. As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-Q and 10-K. Our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website.
I will now turn the call over to John Mackey.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In Q2, our sales increased 10% to $3.6 billion driven by comps of 3.6% and square footage growth of 11%. We opened 11 new stores, including 3 relocations and 3 former Dominick's locations. There are many moving
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. In Q2, our sales increased 10% to $3.6 billion driven by comps of 3.6% and square footage growth of 11%. We opened 11 new stores, including 3 relocations and 3 former Dominick's locations. There are many moving pieces so we can't definitively -- say definitively what caused the moderation in comps during the quarter. We do know that we are not immune to the larger macro environment, and the exploding demand for natural and organic products has resulted in increased competition from many different channels. In addition, severe weather and cannibalization had a larger impact in Q2 than in Q1. We're on track to report our sixth consecutive year of record new store openings. A high percentage of our accelerated growth is in existing markets, which is driving market share gains but also producing a drag on comps from higher cannibalization in some cases. We saw this in Austin and Boston last year, and we're seeing it in Chicago and Florida right now. Keep in mind that our average weekly sales per store are over $720,000. So even when a store gets hit, it is still highly profitable and continues to produce strong returns on invested capital. The store might report slower growth per year, but after anniversary-ing the new store opening, it regains momentum quickly. Gross margin, excluding the nonroutine supplier credit, declined 12 basis points due primarily to higher cost of goods sold as a percentage of sales. While we do our best to estimate the impact of our value efforts, it is more art than science and customer reactions can vary from our predictions. In addition, strong execution on the buy side helped offset our investments to a greater degree than we had forecast. For the fiscal year, we still expect a greater year-over-year decline in gross margin excluding LIFO than we saw last year. SG&A improved 29 basis points due to leverage in salaries and benefits. We're pleased with our continued expense disciplines, particularly given comps were little light on our expectations. 
Turning to new stores, for the last 8 quarters, our new store class has averaged 36 stores with sales per gross square foot over $700, translating the productivity levels of 80% on a weighted square footage basis. Comparable stores less than 2 years old have averaged 16% comps, and more importantly, a 13% return on invested capital, well in excess of our weighted average cost of capital. Our EVA-based approach to site selection allows us to consider markets from Olathe, Kansas to New York City. While our expectations for sales productivity and operating expenses vary depending on the type of market and other factors, when balanced with the appropriate level of capital investment, a wide variety of markets can produce healthy returns for our shareholders. We are reaffirming our fiscal year targets. Comps have averaged 2.8% over the last 5 weeks, up from 2.4% for the last 9 weeks of Q2 excluding Easter. We're encouraged by this improvement and are continuing to lean into the changing marketplace, moving forward with our investments in value, marketing and technology. We continue to see unit lift from the lower produce pricing we have implemented in several markets. We added more markets in Q2 and expect this to expand as the year progresses. We continue to believe more competitive produce pricing will greatly benefit our overall value perception. 
We're continuing our successful Value Matters brand advertising campaign. Beginning next week, this next round will focus on digital marketing, including online video, digital display ads and mobile and social ads. In Q2, our average weekly Instacart sales increased to $1.5 million. We continue to be the leading Apple Pay retailer with over 3.3 million transactions and surpassed 4 million followers on Twitter. Given those metrics, it is not surprising that in our brand tracking results, digital outperformed with our key demographics. We plan to follow-up this fall with an exciting new Values Matter campaign which will include national television and digital. 
Now turning to other news. At our investor conference in February, I said we would be making some pretty exciting announcements over the coming months, reflecting our ability to learn, grow and evolve. Today, we're excited to announce the launch of the new uniquely branded store concept unlike anything that currently exists in the marketplace. Offering our industry-leading quality standards at value prices, this new format will feature modern streamlined design, innovative technology and a curated selection. We'll offer convenient, transparent and values-oriented experience geared towards millennial shoppers, while appealing to anyone looking for high-quality fresh food at great prices. We're building a team to focus exclusively on this new concept and are already negotiating leases. We plan to begin opening stores next year, and given the more standardized design and product assortment, we expect a fairly rapid expansion from there. Over the next several years, we have explored the idea of new format several times but never felt the time was right, particularly given our accelerated growth plans. That issue is now behind us as we have successfully increased our new store openings for 6 years. In addition, we now have a successful track record of opening some smaller format stores with a lower cost structure. 
The Whole Foods Market brand has helped lead the shift in consciousness toward fresh, healthy foods by offering the highest quality, broader selection and best customer service, and we believe we can still triple the number of Whole Foods Market stores in the United States. At the same time, we have also seen an opportunity to leverage our long history of retail innovation and extend our reach in the marketplace beyond 1,200 stores. We want to underscore we see this as an and to our Whole Foods market brand and not an or. We believe the growth potential for this new and complementary brand to be as great as it is for our highly successful Whole Foods Market brand. This is all we're going to reveal today, but we look forward to sharing more detail about this exciting news venture some time before Labor Day. 
We'll now take questions. Our call will end at 4:45 Central Time today to allow more time for questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015

componenttext: Just wanted to, of course, ask just firstly on the sales deceleration later in the quarter. I know you said it's hard to say exactly or try to get a gauge exactly what happened, but can you maybe give us a sense for directionally how comps were not only in those heavier cannibalized markets, but also maybe those versus some of the other markets was outside of those? Was it pretty consistent, or did you see any notable changes?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Glenda. Yes, we did see a broad-based decline across many markets in the period from the early on in the quarter to later in the quarter, most of that being in transaction count. And then with the tick up that we have seen in the last 5 weeks, tha
componenttext: This is Glenda. Yes, we did see a broad-based decline across many markets in the period from the early on in the quarter to later in the quarter, most of that being in transaction count. And then with the tick up that we have seen in the last 5 weeks, that was in transaction count also, so both the decline and in the uptick now have been in transaction count.

componenttext: Or a deceleration, not a decline.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then one quick follow-up, if I may, realizing that it's early for this new concept, but can you just give us kind of more a strategic or a qualitative discussion around how you kind of plan to balance that upcoming concept with, of course, all t
componenttext: Okay, and then one quick follow-up, if I may, realizing that it's early for this new concept, but can you just give us kind of more a strategic or a qualitative discussion around how you kind of plan to balance that upcoming concept with, of course, all the initiatives that you're currently putting into and what your store early stages and current stores?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So there's a lot in that question. We're really going to stick to we share -- I think this biggest rational is this marketplace continues to grow and explode and I think -- we think by creating a second growth vehicle for our company, we can broaden the a
componenttext: So there's a lot in that question. We're really going to stick to we share -- I think this biggest rational is this marketplace continues to grow and explode and I think -- we think by creating a second growth vehicle for our company, we can broaden the accessibility to fresh, healthy foods and we continue to be leaders in that sense. With respect to the resources, I mean, we said today we're creating a team right now, and it's already in process, including leadership and the rest of the team members to be all that focused on this. And so we are adding additional resources to be able to hit the gate and running on this. We're going to have a lot more to share with you before Labor Day or some sort. We're going to have a special event where we'll communicate all the details about this and much more particulars at that time. But that's pretty much what we're going to say today.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think a couple of things we could maybe emphasize is that we do think this is a very unique concept. It's not like anything else that's out there right now. So we think we're going to come up with a complementary brand and strategy that fits well alongs
componenttext: I think a couple of things we could maybe emphasize is that we do think this is a very unique concept. It's not like anything else that's out there right now. So we think we're going to come up with a complementary brand and strategy that fits well alongside the Whole Foods Market brand. There's things we can do with the Whole Foods Market brand. We can continue to do a better job on our expense discipline. We could continue to be aggressive in gradually lowering some of our prices, but the Whole Foods Market brand stands for the highest quality, the best selection, the highest degree of service so there's -- that brand can bend a little bit, but we can't break it. We're not willing to break it. But we think we can create a complementary brand that can go places the Whole Foods Market brand cannot effectively go. So we're kind of trying to tantalize people a little bit today, there will be a bigger reveal later on before Labor Day. We'll give you the name, we'll give you some more details about it. We're very excited about it, but we knew this information's going to leak out because we're negotiating leases. And so then if it leaks out, then we are to deny it. So it's better just to be proactive, get it out there. Yes, we are going to open a new concept store, a new brand. We'll open it up in 2016, and we're about to sign -- we're signing leases right now so the information's out there. That's all we're really going to say about it today.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So David, I'm kind of really excited about the creative team -- the creative start-up team we're putting together to work on this new concept. We're taking some of the sharpest, brightest folks at Whole Foods Market and they're going to be working exclusi
componenttext: So David, I'm kind of really excited about the creative team -- the creative start-up team we're putting together to work on this new concept. We're taking some of the sharpest, brightest folks at Whole Foods Market and they're going to be working exclusively on us with us. And like as John said, it's surely going to be an innovative retail concept.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we can take our next question from Charles Grom with Sterne Agee CRT.
componenttext: And we can take our next question from Charles Grom with Sterne Agee CRT.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just back in February you talked a lot about some of the initiatives you were planning to roll out though out the year, loyalty, the price efforts, the remodels. Just wondering if you can talk a little bit about the price efforts. Can we dig a little bit
componenttext: Just back in February you talked a lot about some of the initiatives you were planning to roll out though out the year, loyalty, the price efforts, the remodels. Just wondering if you can talk a little bit about the price efforts. Can we dig a little bit deeper into each of those 3 drivers? And I guess how much are you assuming that your business gets better as we progress throughout 2015 from those efforts?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chuck, this is Walter. Yes, the 3 buckets we referenced last call basically are pricing, the marketing and the technology along with our step-up efforts around bringing down our cost structure. So in each of the areas as we reference today, we're continui
componenttext: Chuck, this is Walter. Yes, the 3 buckets we referenced last call basically are pricing, the marketing and the technology along with our step-up efforts around bringing down our cost structure. So in each of the areas as we reference today, we're continuing the efforts in produce and within the frame of bringing the gross margins down sequentially year-over-year like we talked about. With respect to the marketing, I think we're reaffirming that Values Matters has been successful starting last week, the whole new digital Values Matter rolls out with social mobile ads, digital ads. And I think what you'll see this time is a better connection to actually the shopping app, which is essentially it will connect you to Instacart, it will connect you to the Affinity app, will connect you to newsletter app. So to try to work on the conversion from those ads and so we're continuing. And then this fall, we'll come out with the next version of the TV ad set. We'll add onto what we did the first time around. With respect to the technology, the Affinity we're moving to the next round of markets this summer, we continue to be very pleased with that, we're getting good results, good data points. We're taking in the next 3 markets this summer, and we are going to continue to learn and grow from that experience. And Instacart, the numbers are in the script, but our average sales per week are up 50% from the last time we spoke to you. So that continues to grow. And so there's kind of an update on those 3 buckets and we're also continuing to work on our cost control as well, and we'll have more details on that as the year progresses.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good, and just a follow up to the first question. When you do look at the comp, the comp deceleration from the first quarter, and I think John alluded to being a little below bit below your expectations, and -- I mean, how do you handicap it? Where is the
componenttext: Good, and just a follow up to the first question. When you do look at the comp, the comp deceleration from the first quarter, and I think John alluded to being a little below bit below your expectations, and -- I mean, how do you handicap it? Where is the fallout? Is it more cannibalization? Was it more competition? And I guess, could you quantify those buckets for us?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's difficult -- it's John here. It's difficult to quantify it, but there's a lot of factors involved. As we mentioned, there's -- we have some severe cannibalization going on right now in Chicago and Florida because of very successful new stores that op
componenttext: It's difficult -- it's John here. It's difficult to quantify it, but there's a lot of factors involved. As we mentioned, there's -- we have some severe cannibalization going on right now in Chicago and Florida because of very successful new stores that opened up there, and those markets have taken some big chunk out of those 2 cities. We know that we have -- we do have more competition than ever before, there's no question about that. And, finally, we've got -- we did have some -- it's very weird, weird quarter for weather particularly in the North Atlantic region. We have a lot of store closures. So I mean, weather is a very difficult thing to predict and sometimes it helps you, sometimes it hurts you. On balance, it hurt us a little bit in Q2. So it's hard to say exactly how that divides up, but I think all 3 can be considered factors.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, you mentioned there were a variety of reasons for the comp slowdown, but you weren't 100% sure what the smoking gun was. Did some of the volatility in your comps lately incent you to sort of roll out your rewards cards any more quickly? Or do anythi
componenttext: John, you mentioned there were a variety of reasons for the comp slowdown, but you weren't 100% sure what the smoking gun was. Did some of the volatility in your comps lately incent you to sort of roll out your rewards cards any more quickly? Or do anything else to -- get to know some of the data behind your customers? You guys gave some great data presentations, I thought at your Analyst Day, I'm just wondering how it makes you think about that, if at all.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: .The Affinity card, yes, well, that's what we call it. The -- I think, yes, we're -- I think the thing has tried to laid the foundation properly and to really make sure we've got the technology platform working well. We are iterating daily on this platf
componenttext:
.
The Affinity card, yes, well, that's what we call it. The -- I think, yes, we're -- I think the thing has tried to laid the foundation properly and to really make sure we've got the technology platform working well. We are iterating daily on this platform. And yes, I mean we're constantly talking about the balance between additional investments and the speed of investments and the -- and what's the right pace for those to do that as we look at the total picture. So -- but I think with respect to Affinity, our next step is clear, which is we're taking it now, which is the next 3 markets. That's going to give us a much broader base for understanding how that works, how customers use it. It looks that the basket's higher, it looks the frequency improves. All those things look very promising. We just really got to continue to work and to iterate it sequentially as opposed to we're not ready to jump to the whole company yet.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Meredith Adler with Barclays.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Meredith Adler with Barclays.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would like to talk a little bit about the new format. And it would be interesting to see what it looks like because the fact that it's different, it's hard to envision. But I'm trying to understand kind of how you see getting 1,200 stores with Whole Foo
componenttext: I would like to talk a little bit about the new format. And it would be interesting to see what it looks like because the fact that it's different, it's hard to envision. But I'm trying to understand kind of how you see getting 1,200 stores with Whole Foods and then opening some meaningful number of these new stores. Aren't you going to be either cannibalizing yourself or going after similar markets? Or -- and because I guess I've never quite understood how did you get to 1,200 stores at Whole Foods.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, 1,200 stores of Whole Foods is not going to be a difficult thing to do at all. I mean, we're already at 420, we got 114 in development. So we're well on our way for that. One thing to understand is that the market is exploding. I mean, it's incr
componenttext: Meredith, 1,200 stores of Whole Foods is not going to be a difficult thing to do at all. I mean, we're already at 420, we got 114 in development. So we're well on our way for that. One thing to understand is that the market is exploding. I mean, it's incredible what's happening. I mean, if you -- one of the things that's fun to do at Whole Foods is we go back and we'd look at what our sales were per store 5 years ago, 8 years ago, 10 years ago. Our sales are so much higher, our sales per square foot is so much higher. And at the same time, we've been so successful that we've actually bred a lot more competition, and everybody's jumping kind of on the natural organic food bandwagon, and that's really, frankly, due to our success. So I don't see that there's a problem, but what I do think is that the Whole Foods Market brand is very targeted to a certain type of customer, certain type of shopper. We think the opportunity's a lot larger than that. And we think there are certain customers at the Whole Foods Market brand's attractive to, but there are other customers that is less attractive to. And we see a whole generation of young people coming up who are quite interested in natural organic foods. The millennial generation, they're idealistic, they're values-oriented, they're mission-driven. These all play to Whole Foods Market's strengths. They're also very value-conscious. So we think a streamlined, hip, cool technology-oriented store unlike any store anybody's ever seen before that has lower capital, lower cost, perhaps lower labor costs, and lower prices is going to be very, very attractive to that particular generation. So you can't envision it yet because it hasn't been created yet. We're creating yet. It will be new, it will be different, and it will be unlike any of the other stores you've seen out there. And hey, sometimes you have to wait to see it but it will be worth waiting for.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, this is Walter. I just want to add -- just continue to add that we continue to have a lot of excitement and enthusiasm for Whole Foods Market, our flagship brand. I mean, we got over 70 stores knocking back $1 million a week. We have tremendous
componenttext: Meredith, this is Walter. I just want to add -- just continue to add that we continue to have a lot of excitement and enthusiasm for Whole Foods Market, our flagship brand. I mean, we got over 70 stores knocking back $1 million a week. We have tremendous success and vitality in this company that continues to grow. And as we open 39, 38, 39, 40 new stores next year, we're continuing down that path. And it just looks that this new format that we're developing, that we're going to tell you more about in a few months is going to be able to access many more broader markets and [indiscernible] niche perhaps that we couldn't serve with our flagship brand. And so you think about it, if everybody knows this marketplace for fresh, healthy foods is getting larger by the day, with the different announcements that people are making. And this new concept that we're developing will allow us to access and participate and contribute and lead in many more markets than -- and this opens up a whole lot of new range of opportunity for all of our stakeholders. So that's the kind of complementary idea that John talked about earlier.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful and interesting. Can I just ask one sort of housekeeping question? You talked about the -- an adjust to the employee appreciation event in the last 5 weeks, does that mean that their actual comp was lower? Or you've already reflected t
componenttext: That's very helpful and interesting. Can I just ask one sort of housekeeping question? You talked about the -- an adjust to the employee appreciation event in the last 5 weeks, does that mean that their actual comp was lower? Or you've already reflected that in the comp, the 2.8% that you reported?

componenttext: The 2.8% is the last 5 weeks, which includes Easter in both years. Is that what you're asking me, Meredith?
