componenttext: John, you mentioned there were a variety of reasons for the comp slowdown, but you weren't 100% sure what the smoking gun was. Did some of the volatility in your comps lately incent you to sort of roll out your rewards cards any more quickly? Or do anything else to -- get to know some of the data behind your customers? You guys gave some great data presentations, I thought at your Analyst Day.  I'm just wondering how it makes you think about that, if at all.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: .The Affinity card, yes, well, that's what we call it. The -- I think, yes, we're -- I think the thing has tried to laid the foundation properly and to really make sure we've got the technology platform working well. We are iterating daily on this platf
componenttext:
.
The Affinity card, yes, well, that's what we call it. The -- I think, yes, we're -- I think the thing has tried to laid the foundation properly and to really make sure we've got the technology platform working well. We are iterating daily on this platform. And yes, I mean, we're constantly talking about the balance between additional investments and the speed of investments and the -- and what's the right pace for those to do that as we look at the total picture. So -- but I think with respect to Affinity, our next step is clear, which is we're taking it now, which is the next 3 markets. That's going to give us a much broader base for understanding how that works, how customers use it. It looks that the basket's higher, it looks the frequency improves. All those things look very promising. We just really got to continue to work and to iterate it sequentially as opposed to we're not ready to jump to the whole company yet.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Meredith Adler with Barclays.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Meredith Adler with Barclays.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would like to talk a little bit about the new format. And it would be interesting to see what it looks like because the fact that it's different, it's hard to envision. But I'm trying to understand kind of how you see getting to 1,200 stores with Whole
componenttext: I would like to talk a little bit about the new format. And it would be interesting to see what it looks like because the fact that it's different, it's hard to envision. But I'm trying to understand kind of how you see getting to 1,200 stores with Whole Foods and then opening some meaningful number of these new stores. Aren't you going to be either cannibalizing yourself or going after similar markets? Or -- and because I guess I've never quite understood how do you get to 1,200 stores at Whole Foods.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, 1,200 stores of Whole Foods is not going to be a difficult thing to do at all. I mean, we're already at 420, we got 114 in development. So we're well on our way for that. One thing to understand is that the market is exploding. I mean, it's incr
componenttext: Meredith, 1,200 stores of Whole Foods is not going to be a difficult thing to do at all. I mean, we're already at 420, we got 114 in development. So we're well on our way for that. One thing to understand is that the market is exploding. I mean, it's incredible what's happening. I mean, if you -- one of the things that's fun to do at Whole Foods is we go back and we'd look at what our sales were per store 5 years ago, 8 years ago, 10 years ago. Our sales are so much higher, our sales per square foot is so much higher. And at the same time, we've been so successful that we've actually bred a lot more competition, and everybody's jumping kind of on the natural organic food bandwagon, and that's really, frankly, due to our success. So I don't see that there's a problem, but what I do think is that the Whole Foods Market brand is very targeted to a certain type of customer, certain type of shopper. We think the opportunity's a lot larger than that. And we think there are certain customers at the Whole Foods Market brand's attractive to, but there are other customers that is less attractive to. And we see a whole generation of young people coming up who are quite interested in natural organic foods. The millennial generation, they're idealistic, they're values-oriented, they're mission-driven. These all play to Whole Foods Market's strengths. They're also very value-conscious. So we think a streamlined, hip, cool technology-oriented store unlike any store anybody's ever seen before that has lower capital, lower cost, perhaps lower labor costs, and lower prices is going to be very, very attractive to that particular generation. So you can't envision it yet because it hasn't been created yet. We're creating it. It will be new, it will be different, and it will be unlike any of the other stores you've seen out there. And hey, sometimes you have to wait to see it but it will be worth waiting for.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, this is Walter. I just want to add -- just continue to add that we continue to have a lot of excitement and enthusiasm for Whole Foods Market, our flagship brand. I mean, we got over 70 stores knocking back $1 million a week. We have tremendous
componenttext: Meredith, this is Walter. I just want to add -- just continue to add that we continue to have a lot of excitement and enthusiasm for Whole Foods Market, our flagship brand. I mean, we got over 70 stores knocking back $1 million a week. We have tremendous success and vitality in this company that continues to grow. And as we open 39, 38, 39, 40 new stores next year, we're continuing down that path. And it just looks that this new format that we're developing, that we're going to tell you more about in a few months is going to be able to access many more broader markets and communities that perhaps we couldn't serve with our flagship brand. And so you think about it, if everybody knows this marketplace for fresh, healthy foods is getting larger by the day, with the different announcements that people are making. And this new concept that we're developing will allow us to access and participate and contribute and lead in many more markets than -- and this opens up a whole lot of new range of opportunity for all of our stakeholders. So that's the kind of complementary idea that John talked about earlier.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful and interesting. Can I just ask one sort of housekeeping question? You talked about the -- an adjust to the employee appreciation event in the last 5 weeks, does that mean that their actual comp was lower? Or you've already reflected t
componenttext: That's very helpful and interesting. Can I just ask one sort of housekeeping question? You talked about the -- an adjust to the employee appreciation event in the last 5 weeks, does that mean that their actual comp was lower? Or you've already reflected that in the comp, the 2.8% that you reported?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: The 2.8% is the last 5 weeks, which includes Easter in both years. Is that what you're asking me, Meredith?
componenttext: The 2.8% is the last 5 weeks, which includes Easter in both years. Is that what you're asking me, Meredith?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, the employee appreciation event, there's a comp that [indiscernible]
componenttext: No, the employee appreciation event, there's a comp that [indiscernible]

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. What about it?
componenttext: Yes. What about it?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, is that the number -- the 2.8% is reflecting?
componenttext: Well, is that the number -- the 2.8% is reflecting?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: It excludes it in last year, yes.
componenttext: It excludes it in last year, yes.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to touch a little bit more on gross margins. So the gross margin performance again was better than expectation this quarter, so as you guys look at the price investments that you've been making, the past few months versus prior quarters,
componenttext: So I just wanted to touch a little bit more on gross margins. So the gross margin performance again was better than expectation this quarter, so as you guys look at the price investments that you've been making, the past few months versus prior quarters, has there been any moderation in the magnitude of price investments?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's A.C. No, there really hasn't been the moderation. We attribute the fact that the -- our gross margin do not decline as much in this quarter as we originally projected to -- largely to just a little bit better purchasing than we originally -- a little
componenttext: It's A.C. No, there really hasn't been the moderation. We attribute the fact that the -- our gross margin do not decline as much in this quarter as we originally projected to -- largely to just a little bit better purchasing than we originally -- a little better results on the purchasing side. We are able to negotiate stronger value discounts with some of our suppliers especially in the grocery and produce areas than we originally thought. So when we projected that we were going to do certain investments in price as it turns out because of the volume we moved, we're able to actually negotiate a little bit better cost on that than we expected to. But we see, when we look out for the rest of the year, we are holding our guidance, we still see that our sequential decline in gross margin, it will be what we have said at the beginning of the year would be. So we think we're going to continue with this. And if we've got a little better purchasing here, we'll do a little bit deeper investment going forward for the rest of the year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, David here too. Also, I'd want to point out that there's so many great products that we make inside our stores, and Ken and I working with all the operators in the regions on more and more products that are made exclusively inside of our Whole Foods
componenttext: Yes, David here too. Also, I'd want to point out that there's so many great products that we make inside our stores, and Ken and I working with all the operators in the regions on more and more products that are made exclusively inside of our Whole Foods stores. So these are products we're manufacturing ourselves. So we're really working on recipe discipline, shrink control. So it's kind of a countervailing thing that's unrelated to the pricing efforts in things like produce and grocery and Whole Body, and those kind of areas.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just switching to competition, we continue to hear more and more about natural organic expanding to other channels. I just want to understand what you guys are maybe doing differently -- what are you doing differently now to combat this threat?
componenttext: And then just switching to competition, we continue to hear more and more about natural organic expanding to other channels. I just want to understand what you guys are maybe doing differently -- what are you doing differently now to combat this threat?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think we're doing several things that we've already sort of addressed. We are investing in value and prices. We're doing a better job at controlling our expenses. We're investing more in marketing, and we're investing more in technology. At the
componenttext: I mean, I think we're doing several things that we've already sort of addressed. We are investing in value and prices. We're doing a better job at controlling our expenses. We're investing more in marketing, and we're investing more in technology. At the same time, today, we've announced that we are coming out with a new format that we think will be specifically geared to address an entire generation of people coming up that we think -- that line up well with Whole Foods. And this new concept will be less capital, more streamlined. It will have -- it will be value-oriented, and it will -- but it will still have Whole Foods quality standards. It will still have our mission and drive. We think it's going to be an exciting new concept. So these are the things that we're doing. Also in some ways the new competition is -- as much as the market's expanding, a lot of people get into it for the first time and they are going to temporarily gain some share because for convenience standpoint or they migrate certain customers over. But then they anniversary that. So the question is whether they will be able to comp their comps, 2, 3, 4, 5 years down the road. And so, I mean, one of the things that people don't fully understand is that even if Whole Foods Market just stopped, I mean our comps went flat, we were at 0, our sales per square foot, our return on invested capital, our whole store operating model is still, frankly, light years better than just anybody on the other food retailers out there that are at least public that we have their data on. So it's going to take a long time before people can catch up with us, but we're not going to sit still. We're going to continue to innovate. We're going to continue to differentiate ourselves. Our commitment to prepared foods, top the sales we do there. I mean, we're doing all that we can, but the reality is, there's more competition. Hey, I wish that wasn't true, but it's where we find ourselves. And we think we're doing, taking the necessary steps to compete well and continue to win in the marketplace.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Walter. I'm just going to add a little bit to that. I think we're clearly in a transition to a much more expanded marketplace. You see that's what you're referencing with foods and products available in many more places than historically. So I think
componenttext: It's Walter. I'm just going to add a little bit to that. I think we're clearly in a transition to a much more expanded marketplace. You see that's what you're referencing with foods and products available in many more places than historically. So I think just add a little to each of those, I mean the price thing for us is striving for relevance on price so we can continue our conversation on quality. So like we said before, we're not looking to race to the bottom. We're looking to be relevant on price so we can really, really have this conversation about quality. And to the second bucket with marketing specifically, it's about communicating the differences because we do not all sell the same stuff. And markets sometimes wants to drop it down to the lowest common denominator. And while there are some common products, much of our product niche is different. And I think the ability for us to communicate the differences in our product and the product offerings that we're bringing to our customers is where we're really trying to go to these efforts, as well as create a kind of a personal connection through the Affinity. Granted we've been a little slower perhaps than we should have been in terms of getting those things in place, but we are, through the use of technology, building out and extending ourself where our customers are, whether it's through Instacart or home delivery, which we're doing more than any other grocery store in America now, and we're really just getting started, whether it's through Affinity, which builds a personal connection to customers who allow to customize their relationship with us. Whether it's through the ease of Apple Pay that -- which will soon go to the next thing you know about, which will gives customers the easier, the most seamless experience. It's whether it's our improving app which ultimately these things can be put together to give customers more integrated experience with Whole Foods digitally. All those things are in the works. And I wish that we were doing them faster, but we're doing them as fast as we can do as we replace all of our foundational systems and technology to get there. Ultimately, where we're going is to create this fuller, richer experience, physically and digitally, for our customers. And as John says, we're taking these steps and we're doing it at a time when the marketplace is going through a huge transition. But make no mistake about it, we still have a tremendous amount of strength in this company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd like to actually add, we're talking about differentiation. We're still doing -- we're really ramping up a lot of our differentiation a lot on the product side. I mean, it's true that you might take some branded natural organic products that we sell an
componenttext: I'd like to actually add, we're talking about differentiation. We're still doing -- we're really ramping up a lot of our differentiation a lot on the product side. I mean, it's true that you might take some branded natural organic products that we sell and other people sell and everybody has the same things, but we're doing a lot -- we got a lot of things in place to help differentiate ourselves in product side. We've been ramping up our exclusive brands team so that we can come out with some really -- got some really great innovative and exciting products coming out in over the next 6 to 9 months. We also continue to differentiate ourselves in produce with our Responsibly Grown program and our Whole Trade Guarantee products. We're the largest seller of fair trade produce and flowers in the U.S, and we continue to expand -- rapidly expand our supply there. And we've got some great new products coming in, in our meat and seafood department. We've established this club pack frozen program. It's doing extremely well in our seafood departments and is a very unique, high-quality product, really great price. And so there's a lot of work going on on the product side to continue to differentiate our product mix and really add the kind of products that our customers really like.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And this is David. On the in-store experience, we continue to innovate -- juice bars continue to grow as a big part of the breakfast experience in our stores. We just opened a great new juice bar with our friends Jugofresh in Miami, and we have a great ju
componenttext: And this is David. On the in-store experience, we continue to innovate -- juice bars continue to grow as a big part of the breakfast experience in our stores. We just opened a great new juice bar with our friends Jugofresh in Miami, and we have a great juice bar with our friends Vega up in Cambie in Vancouver. We're closing in on 100 tap rooms where we serve beer, wine, and all sorts of exciting things, making pitas in our new West Loop store. We're continuing to be the retail innovator in terms of in-store experience. Again, things you can't get online, you can only get at Whole Foods Market. I encourage you guys to go into some of our new stores.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Stephen Grambling with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Stephen Grambling with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the new concept. Does the distribution model have to change? Or do you have the capacity for these smaller stores at this point?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the new concept. Does the distribution model have to change? Or do you have the capacity for these smaller stores at this point?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We think one of the great things about this model is that we can leverage all of our existing distribution capabilities and our distribution partners. We can use our regional structure and yet we can create a more centrally driven model from a product sta
componenttext: We think one of the great things about this model is that we can leverage all of our existing distribution capabilities and our distribution partners. We can use our regional structure and yet we can create a more centrally driven model from a product standpoint, a pricing standpoint and an overall selection standpoint while allowing innovation to occur on a limited basis within a regional and local basis. So we think we've got the right structure to really create a new model that will be highly successful. I mean, we can talk about it in general terms. We want to limit what we talk about in this call. It will be so much easier once we open the first one and people can come look at it, then you see it. And we will be -- we will reveal a little bit more in the next few months, but we're excited about it. We think it's a big deal. But hey, the proof will be when we start opening them up.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: But to his question is, no, we don't need a new distribution network to service.
componenttext: But to his question is, no, we don't need a new distribution network to service.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We do not need a new distribution network.
componenttext: We do not need a new distribution network.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood and that's helpful. And I guess changing gears a little bit. You mentioned better -- doing a better job on expense discipline and you saw some leverage on salaries and benefits among other areas. Where are the improvements coming from at this p
componenttext: Understood and that's helpful. And I guess changing gears a little bit. You mentioned better -- doing a better job on expense discipline and you saw some leverage on salaries and benefits among other areas. Where are the improvements coming from at this point? And is there kind of a new leverage point to be thinking about as it relates to the comp?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mean on comp on SG&A? Or do you mean on sales? I mean, the trick on expense leverage, it's just continued hard work. It's retails, details, about getting in there and looking at your business processes. It's something we're doing right now. We have a
componenttext: You mean on comp on SG&A? Or do you mean on sales? I mean, the trick on expense leverage, it's just continued hard work. It's retails, details, about getting in there and looking at your business processes. It's something we're doing right now. We have a number of task force going, examining things like how we buy in the stores, how we serve in prepared foods, and we're looking at this and we're taking cost out of the system in a systematic basis. 29 basis points times $15 billion over a year is a heck of a lot of money. And we are going to continue to do that. So I think that's what we've announced we're going to do. We're also getting leverage as we continue to grow and open new stores, we're getting leverage in our overall G&A as well as store leverage. So I think that's a long-term -- I mean, we look out, we do our own internal work several years in advance. We see, okay, we're going to continue to get expense leverage. We're going to continue to work on a process. We're going to continue to take these costs out, and we're going to continue to lower prices, lower our gross margins accordingly. And hopefully we'll be able to produce a similar type of bottom line that we've been producing for the last several years. That's our strategy, and we think it's a good strategy.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could sneak one more housekeeping? And just on the refreshes, can you just refresh us on how many have actually occurred year-to-date and how those are performed?
componenttext: If I could sneak one more housekeeping? And just on the refreshes, can you just refresh us on how many have actually occurred year-to-date and how those are performed?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'm kind of encouraged by what the stores are doing. We're still committed to doing over 200 by the end of this year. We've got good results this quarter. There's some great stores, Bishops Corner in West Hartford in Connecticut. Just spoke
componenttext: This is David. I'm kind of encouraged by what the stores are doing. We're still committed to doing over 200 by the end of this year. We've got good results this quarter. There's some great stores, Bishops Corner in West Hartford in Connecticut. Just spoke to Laura Derba, the Regional President there, and their sales are higher than the regional comp number. And we're very excited to be focusing a lot of energy in Colorado, stores like Fort Collins, Cherry Creek, Colfax, Washington Park, Colorado Boulevard. Some of our oldest stores, former Wild Oats, where we're doing the new color, the new painting, the new look. But we are -- a significant chunk of them are going to happen in the summer which is the slowest time for sales for us, but also the most convenient time to do without getting in the way of our customers. So expect a significant chunk to happen in the June, July, August time frame, but we're still committed to doing and encouraged to do them all by the end of the year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jerry Gray with Cowen.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jerry Gray with Cowen.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the Instacart business grew about 50% sequentially in terms of your average weekly sales volume. Was there any new markets or new stores added there? Is that mostly organic growth within the existing stores?
componenttext: So the Instacart business grew about 50% sequentially in terms of your average weekly sales volume. Was there any new markets or new stores added there? Is that mostly organic growth within the existing stores?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is mostly organic growth. We added one small market, but the next burst of markets is soon to come.
componenttext: That is mostly organic growth. We added one small market, but the next burst of markets is soon to come.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. I would say that we're also -- if you look on the Instacart app, we're adding new items all the time. We're starting to add more and more of our prepared foods mix, which wasn't available when we started with Instacart. So there's a more fu
componenttext: This is David. I would say that we're also -- if you look on the Instacart app, we're adding new items all the time. We're starting to add more and more of our prepared foods mix, which wasn't available when we started with Instacart. So there's a more full shop for our customers and they're responding.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, great. And then just on the gross margin, with your produce pricing, could you give us any more details on the rollout of that and how the cadence of that is going to go in the second half and into next year as you expand that to additional mar
componenttext: All right, great. And then just on the gross margin, with your produce pricing, could you give us any more details on the rollout of that and how the cadence of that is going to go in the second half and into next year as you expand that to additional markets?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, we started at the beginning of this year with several of our markets with our first investments. And then we just started, really just rolled out not too long ago our second wave of investments. And again, we're a little different. Some were doing
componenttext: Right, we started at the beginning of this year with several of our markets with our first investments. And then we just started, really just rolled out not too long ago our second wave of investments. And again, we're a little different. Some were doing more -- everyday low pricing, others were doing a stronger promotional strategy. I think the ones we added in the second wave are more on the promotional side and some additional regions. Our plan is to continue with those -- with all of that going forward, and then to add at some point later in this fiscal year, we're going to add some more markets to it. But right now, we've got plans to, as we move into the new fiscal year, continue with another wave of investments.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I mean, obviously, everyone acknowledges you have a great store format, and I appreciate this opportunity that you're looking into. But I guess the question I have is that while there is a significant opportunity with this new concept, how do you think
componenttext: So I mean, obviously, everyone acknowledges you have a great store format, and I appreciate this opportunity that you're looking into. But I guess the question I have is that while there is a significant opportunity with this new concept, how do you think about the risk that this new concept won't start a broad-based decline in margins across the board in natural and organic? And obviously including a bigger gross margin risk at your Whole Foods standard stores? And why is it not just kind of a slippery slope on the margin front?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, instead of a slippery slope, Karen, I think we've already articulated for the last 1.5 years that the trajectory at the gross margins are going to continue to incrementally move down as the competitive marketplace emerges. So I think that we weren't
componenttext: Well, instead of a slippery slope, Karen, I think we've already articulated for the last 1.5 years that the trajectory at the gross margins are going to continue to incrementally move down as the competitive marketplace emerges. So I think that we weren't acknowledging that as this thing broadens and widens but the thing is the opportunity keeps getting so much bigger, here's another way for us to do that, that's going to access other communities and other folks that we could not access particularly with our Whole Foods flagship brand. So no one's saying that the -- the size of opportunities is just enormous. I think we're all seeing that unfold daily. But I think we've already kind of laid out the trajectory that we see that the margins will, in fact, go down year-over-year for the next several years. You want to add to that, John?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, Karen, imagine that we have these larger Whole Foods Market sort of flagship stores that got, think about our one in Austin, for example, which is a good example, a big store, great prepared foods, lots of different venues, huge service. It'
componenttext: Well, I mean, Karen, imagine that we have these larger Whole Foods Market sort of flagship stores that got, think about our one in Austin, for example, which is a good example, a big store, great prepared foods, lots of different venues, huge service. It's an experience when you go into the store. And then say that's kind of the Whole Foods Market brand trajectory. And then you have this new format that is, the stores are not as large, they're more streamlined, they're tech-savvy, there's less capital being invested in it, they're very convenient for people and they're very value-focused with a tailored product mix. So maybe if you go into a big Whole Foods Market, maybe you've got a thousand different kinds of wine from a price point all the way from $2.99 to a few hundred dollars. But maybe in this -- our new concept store, you'll have a more tailored mix of wine. You won't have -- it will just be good quality value wines and they won't have the same upward trajectory. So is it something that's going to harm Whole Foods Market? We don't see it that way. We see it as complementary. We'll see that our loyalty card program will include both brands, and we see people crossing over in it. And -- but one of the things that I think I've learned from other businesses is you have to be willing to evolve with the marketplace. You have to be willing to do what it takes to serve your customers better, and you can't not do that because it might possibly take sales from your existing flagship brand. You've got to be willing to serve your customers where you find them. That will cause the Whole Foods Market flagship brand to evolve as we roll out our next brand, just like it's evolving right now with the competition that we're facing. So we see that this is a huge opportunity that the natural organic foods revolution is sweeping America. We intend to be the -- continue to be the leader in this category for the rest of the century. And so we're evolving with the marketplace. We're going to create a new -- we are creating a new format, a new concept that's not been seen, that no one else has done. It's going to be unique and we think it's going to be very exciting to the customer base, and we'll see what happens. It's hard to predict exactly what's going to happen until you start doing it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just going to add, Karen, I'm really glad John brought that up because you were there at the -- our investor conference, and we talked a lot about us being a company that is willing -- continually changing, evolving, growing. You read the marketplac
componenttext: I was just going to add, Karen, I'm really glad John brought that up because you were there at the -- our investor conference, and we talked a lot about us being a company that is willing -- continually changing, evolving, growing. You read the marketplace as it is, and you say, "How do you continue to respond? How do you continue to evolve?" And for us as a group thinking about it, we think this is a way for us to think as it gets bigger, it allows us to broaden our reach, accelerate our growth, serve more people in bringing healthier food to the world. So we do see it as an evolution of our company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I agree, evolution is obviously the key to survival. I said I did have another question just on your existing store base and your store growth plans. Obviously, looking back to 2007 and '08 when you'd find larger stores and then kind of retrenched, an
componenttext: No, I agree, evolution is obviously the key to survival. I said I did have another question just on your existing store base and your store growth plans. Obviously, looking back to 2007 and '08 when you'd find larger stores and then kind of retrenched, and obviously there was a macro element to retrenching. But you're obviously moving on your Whole Foods fleet to a larger format. And I guess, first question is, are you -- is the larger increase in store size basically to accommodate mostly the wine bars and the beer halls? And then can you help me just to understand how that impacts ROIC going forward, if it's in fact it is wine bar and beer halls?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we do have our tap rooms and wine bars. And we want to make Whole Foods Market this incredible experience for people, I mean, we want the stores to be fun, we want them to be exciting, we want them to be places that are destinations for peop
componenttext: Well, I mean, we do have our tap rooms and wine bars. And we want to make Whole Foods Market this incredible experience for people, I mean, we want the stores to be fun, we want them to be exciting, we want them to be places that are destinations for people to come. It's an experience that -- food is a very sensual, exciting thing for people. We want these stores to be incredibly exciting. So the trend line for Whole Foods Market will probably be towards larger stores. They're very experientially oriented with a very differentiated product mix for the customer base. And then we'll have our new format that will be -- the stores will be more streamlined. It won't be as large. It will be value-oriented. There will be a more tailored product mix. There will very tech-savvy stores, and they'll be very exciting to the -- to, we think, to the millennial generation of about 90 million people. So we think these concepts are very complementary to each other. There will be some overlap, and -- but in the best of all worlds for Whole Foods, people will shop both stores. They'll come in and enjoy the big, exciting Whole Foods Market and they'll do fill-in shops at the new concept and the stores will intermix with each other in a very unique way. And we'll have a larger product mix at the bigger flagship Whole Foods Market stores than we will in the new format. We'll have a more tailored mix there. So that's what's -- we really can't say too much more than that. There'll be a bigger reveal later on as we get in -- this summer. So it's not that far away. You have to wait, like, a few months, and we'll give you more.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Whole Food's Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Whole Food's Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey; and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey; and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth & Development; and David Lannon; and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations. As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-Q and 10-K. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. We will discuss our Q3 comparable store sales growth results, excluding the 95 basis point negative impact from the Easter shift and Team Member Double Discount Day. Also please note our results include an $8 million expense or 21 basis points related to the implementation of California's new [indiscernible] law. 
Walter?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. I will briefly review the quarter and focus most of my time today on our outlook going forward. Year-over-year, our quarterly sales grew $255 million to a record $3.6 billion. We opened 8 new stores and increasi
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. I will briefly review the quarter and focus most of my time today on our outlook going forward. Year-over-year, our quarterly sales grew $255 million to a record $3.6 billion. We opened 8 new stores and increasing our operating square footage 11% to $16 million and expanding our reach to 422 stores across 41 states and 3 countries. On an adjusted basis, comparable store sales increased 2.2% for the quarter, moderating 90 basis points from Q2. We estimate that the negative impact from cannibalization was 30 basis points greater in Q3 than in Q2. Comps improved 20 basis points from the last 9 weeks of Q2 to the first 10 weeks of Q3, driven primarily by a 70 basis point improvement in traffic, which was partially offset by a 50 basis point decrease in basket size. We attribute the moderation in basket size primarily due to our value efforts and to cost deflation in few key product categories, including produce. 
Comps dropped sharply in week 11 and, after our New York City Weights and Measures audit received national media attention and averaged just 0.4% for the last 2 weeks of the quarter. We have seen a slight improvement in trends fourth quarter to date. However, comps are still well below our 2.5% average for the 19 weeks prior to the negative publicity. We believe increasing headwinds are also a factor as sales began to stabilize in the last few weeks of Q3 last year. 
I want to take a moment to address the New York City Weights and Measures Audit. As well as New York City Department of Consumer Affairs came to us, we worked to understand and address the issues to prevent them from happening again. I want to emphasize these were not systematic but rather caused by inadvertent human error. The audit included errors that were both favorable to customers as well. These are weights and measures issues that can be found in any supermarket. Clear and transparent pricing is integral to how we operate. We have taken immediate steps to address these issues including improving our training regarding in-store packing, weighing and labeling processes, and expanding our third quarter auditing process company-wide. We built our business on the core value of satisfying and delighting our customers. It is what our customers have grown to love and expect from us and approach to pricing transparency is no different. If the price is not accurate and not priced in the customer's favor, then that item is free to the customer, no charge, no question. 
Turning back to our results, gross margin x LIFO decreased 66 basis points year-over-year driven primarily by an increase in cost of goods sold as a percentage of sales. Our results reflect our more aggressive efforts to improve our price relevancy as well as higher shrink in the last 2 weeks of the quarter given that purchases were planned for a higher-level of sales heading into the 4th of July holiday. SG&A increased 24 basis points to 28.4% of sales against a record low in the prior year, due primarily to higher depreciation as a percentage of sales. Results included 21 basis points in expense related to the implementation of California's new paid and sick leave law. Despite lower-than-expected sales, we maintain our labor expense disciplines and leverage wages. 
Our new store class for the last 8 quarters has averaged 38 stores, with sales per gross square foot of approximately $700, translating to productivity levels of 78% on a weighted square footage basis. Comparable stores less than 2 years old have averaged 15% comps and most importantly, a 13% return on invested capital well in excess of our weighted average cost of capital. In a challenging sales environment, we delivered 9.7% EBITDA margin, $287 million of operating cash flow and a 15% return on invested capital. Year-to-date, we have produced industry-leading sales per gross square foot of $990, over $1 billion in EBITDA and $1 billion in cash flow from operation. A strong balance sheet and robust cash flows, we have self-funded our new store development and strategic growth initiatives while returning over $325 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. 
The Whole Foods Market brand has helped lead the shift in consciousness towards fresh healthy foods. With 424 stores totaling more than 16 million square feet today, we expect the cost of 500 store mark in fiscal year 2017 and over the longer term continue to seek potential for 1,200 Whole Foods Market stores in the United States. As announced last quarter, we are introducing a second format, 365 By Whole Foods Market, which we believe expands our growth opportunity beyond the 1,200 stores. While more streamlined than a typical Whole Foods Market store, our 365 store will be guided by the same industry-leading quality standards. As a second growth vehicle, 365 will be very complementary to our Whole Foods Market brand, allowing us to address the value quality proposition in a new while maintaining the integrity the Whole Foods Market brand represents in the marketplace. 365 President Jeff Turner is building a top-notch team and has hit the ground running. We are excited today to announce leases for the 5 365 stores in Los Angeles, Santa Monica, Portland, Houston and Belleveu, Washington. These are all A+ real estate sites which meet our required EVA hurdle return. We are currently targeting up to 5 365 store openings in the second half of next calendar year, with the expectation of doubling that number of openings for calendar 2017. With opportunities new and existing as well as urban and suburban markets, most of are our first stores are expected to be in the existing markets to better leverage our existing team member base and infrastructure. Our first 365 By Whole Foods Market store is scheduled to open in Silverlake area of Los Angeles, where we converted a lease and development from Whole Foods Market to 365. Los Angeles is the perfect dense urban market, where customers already love our quality standards and transparency to introduce our latest evolution focused on quality food and value in a convenient format. We're excited to reveal more as things develop. 
Turning now to our outlook for Q4, we have opened 2 new stores and expect to open 8 additional stores, including 1 relocation. If current comp trends continue, we would expect sales growth of approximately 7% and diluted earnings per share of $0.34 to $0.35. This outlook reflects current trends, as well as some headwinds from moderating inflation, increased cannibalization and our own value efforts. For the fiscal year, this translates to sales growth of approximately 9% with comps in the low-single digits and square footage up 10%. We continue to expect EBITDA margin of approximately 9% and ROIC greater than 14%. For the next fiscal year, we are forecasting ending square footage growth of approximately 9% or 7.5% growth on a weighted square footage basis, reflecting a back-end-loaded store opening schedule. We will provide additional details in our outlook next quarter. 
In summary, in this retail marketplace, which is more dynamic and competitive than ever, we believe we are taking the necessary steps to position ourself for the long-term. While we acknowledge it is taking longer than we would have hoped, we believe continue to invest in our price relevancy, our marketing and our technologies the right strategy to regain sales momentum. We are encouraged by the unit lift we have seen from our price investments and will continue to expand on that strategy. We are committed to investing in marketing to support our value efforts as well as our brand and our excited by our new brand campaign this fall. Year-to-date, we have made progress in our Digital and technology efforts to better serve our customers. We are live with both work date for all of our team members, have launched our new iOS and Android mobile ads, refreshed our web experience and are testing and evolving our Affinity program. While still in the early stages, we have also piloted our new 1 POS and kiosk ordering for food menus and rolling out a labor scheduling to our customers service teams. We will continue to build out and enhance these efforts next year while also beginning to mobilize our new product platform which will bring us many exciting capabilities such as perpetual inventory, replenishment, sales space planning and price optimization. We remain focused on innovating optimization. We remain focused on enervating and evolve optimization. We remain focused on innovating and evolving to best serve our customers diverse purchasing preferences in this rapidly changing marketplace, from the unique experience of our Whole Foods Market stores to the growing online channel for home delivery to the exciting launch of our 365 and Whole Foods Market stores, we are leaning in to extend our reach into new as well as existing customers. 
We will now take questions. Our call will end at 445 Central Time today to allow more time for questions. So please if you can, limit yourself to one question at a time so everyone has an opportunity to participate. Thank you.

componenttext: I think in the comments here we said that the, I mean, retired to give you the evidence on the chart that kind of showed the breakdown of the quarter, the weeks in the quarter, the end of the quarter, the start of the quarter and the start of the new quarter to help you get some visibility into the impact of it. Clearly it affected the comps. Clearly there's other factors at work here too in terms of the headwinds from the previous year strong sales and so forth. But by any measure it has significant impact on our sales. And with respect to the second part of your question, we've already taken the steps to again, this was in light of our New York City stores to upgrade the training processes right away, to bring in a third-party firms who audit our procedures and results and improve those and those steps have ready been taken. In fact, we've been inspected subsequent times since without incident so all those things were already in place.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I would like to follow on to the last questions. The question isn't just how you got your people to do the right thing because clearly you've done that. The question is how do you change customer perception that somehow Whole Foods can't be truste
componenttext: I guess I would like to follow on to the last questions. The question isn't just how you got your people to do the right thing because clearly you've done that. The question is how do you change customer perception that somehow Whole Foods can't be trusted?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think that's a really fair question, Meredith, and there's no -- we're taking all the steps, you can trust us to be, if trust is broken, it has to be rebuilt a step at a time and through solid execution day in and day out. And there's no magic b
componenttext: I mean, I think that's a really fair question, Meredith, and there's no -- we're taking all the steps, you can trust us to be, if trust is broken, it has to be rebuilt a step at a time and through solid execution day in and day out. And there's no magic bullet for restoring whatever trust was lost other than us being transparent about what it is, make sure you put this in context and this is something that every supermarket has. And that we've taken the steps and that we continue to convince our customers that we're doing the right thing by them each and everyday. I mean, every store now has the customer pledge at the register letting them know that if you have any concerns, ask and we'll recheck. If you're dissatisfied, we'll give it back to you, whatever. So all of those things are in place. I think it's just a matter of song wood and doing a good work day in and day out to continue to build that trust.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, John here. We don't think our track record is any different than any other supermarket. We're not sure why Whole Foods was singled out for this attention. We don't know why the media ran wild with this. Our error rates are very small, we've done
componenttext: Meredith, John here. We don't think our track record is any different than any other supermarket. We're not sure why Whole Foods was singled out for this attention. We don't know why the media ran wild with this. Our error rates are very small, we've done our own auditing. We put in procedures now so that we can perhaps be perfect. But we believe an objective evaluation if you compare Whole Foods' record, these are inadvertent errors, and there's no systematic mistakes being made here, it's a very small percentage of our total product. It's just something that went viral in the media and it has hurt our trust, and yet we do feel like we're victims of -- we don't know exactly why or the DCA went after Whole Foods like this. We're not sure why the media went crazy with it. But it did happen. We are taking steps to not give costs for this in the future. As far as reestablishing trust with our customers, there's no magic wand we can wave -- we're going to do third-party audits, we're going to show that, we're going to be transparent about it, and hopefully over time, the basic integrity of our company and the good customer service we provide will put this in the past and we'll move on past it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David, I'd also just say we're very encouraged by the result of our third-party audits. We're doing them across the country, not just in New York but with everywhere and we are passing audit after audit. We're eliminating the few errors we do find
componenttext: This is David, I'd also just say we're very encouraged by the result of our third-party audits. We're doing them across the country, not just in New York but with everywhere and we are passing audit after audit. We're eliminating the few errors we do find and our team members are really active about this because they want to do right by their neighbors and their customers and we're all over it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, you see the sales trends, your have them on the chart there. You can see it's too early but there's some hope that we're going back in the other direction now and we will -- the additional steps we're taking, the bigger picture here to do, rebuil
componenttext: I guess, you see the sales trends, your have them on the chart there. You can see it's too early but there's some hope that we're going back in the other direction now and we will -- the additional steps we're taking, the bigger picture here to do, rebuild the momentum, sales momentum of the company which is in our pricing efforts, our marketing efforts, our technology and platform efforts, all those things continue, and to continue to do that and we do have our initial branding coming this fall which again is an effort to kind of highlight what the company is all about and remind people what's different about Whole Foods Market.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we can take our next question from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we can take our next question from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Color on the new 365 format. So I just had a couple of questions. I guess the 30,000 square-foot size seems a little bigger than I would have thought and you did indicate in the prepared remarks that there would be A+ locations. So I guess with that type
componenttext: Color on the new 365 format. So I just had a couple of questions. I guess the 30,000 square-foot size seems a little bigger than I would have thought and you did indicate in the prepared remarks that there would be A+ locations. So I guess with that type of like location, how do you get comfortable that you can maintain your ROIC because obviously price points will be lower and rents seems like they're going to be in line with what you're paying at your Whole Foods format? And then I guess the 4 markets that you've indicated you're going to open, obviously you also told us some rationale from that, but there are obviously, I guess close to existing Whole Foods store. So how do you think about the rest of the cannibalization?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Karen, John here. We actually think we'll get superior ROICs with the 365 format. We're going to have significantly reduced capital investments as well as significantly lower labor costs and of course we don't know whether we will open some stores, but wh
componenttext: Karen, John here. We actually think we'll get superior ROICs with the 365 format. We're going to have significantly reduced capital investments as well as significantly lower labor costs and of course we don't know whether we will open some stores, but when we project this out, if we get anything close to what Whole Foods Market sales per square foot are in our new stores, the 365 stores are going to be incredibly profitable and with very high ROICs, even with reduced gross margins. I mean, will there be some cannibalization of Whole Foods? I mean, probably, but we don't know exactly how much until we do. It will probably be less than we open up an actual branded Whole Foods Market store because it's going to appeal to a little bit different customer we think. So it is an experiment. We do have 5 stores committed, we have several other stores we are negotiating leases on. And a year from now, we're going to have a lot more data for you because we'll have some stores open, we'll see what they're doing, will see what affects are, we'll see what the ROICs are. All I can say is we're super excited about it. We think we're going to have great stores, good locations, low gross margins, lower labor, low capital investments and very high returns on invested capital, so.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other comment, with 365, we look at it as a hand and we feel it's very complementary to being in the area of Whole Foods so a customer has choices between going into a 365 or Whole Foods depending upon the time, what they want to accomplish with the s
componenttext: One other comment, with 365, we look at it as a hand and we feel it's very complementary to being in the area of Whole Foods so a customer has choices between going into a 365 or Whole Foods depending upon the time, what they want to accomplish with the shop. And so we're hoping that it captures both of their choices when they decide to go out and shop. So we're not -- we look at the cannibalization, we think it is going to be lower but we also are really encouraged by the chance that we have to capture more trips that the customer have shopping.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David, Ken and I have been working really hard, really excited about the Silverlake design. I think one of for questions was about the size difference say between 25 to 30k, and we're are of staying disciplined about what we're going to do with th
componenttext: This is David, Ken and I have been working really hard, really excited about the Silverlake design. I think one of for questions was about the size difference say between 25 to 30k, and we're are of staying disciplined about what we're going to do with the 365 model. We have this concept we're calling Friends of 365 where we are actually talking to interesting local suppliers that might rent out a small part of the space. Again, our core store would be somewhere between 25 to 30 but we're also looking at opportunities to work with some local suppliers to give it some local flavor as well.

componenttext: Yes, hi, well, we've been, I would say it's a little bit of both. We definitely continued -- beginning of the year we started around the produce investments which we've continued through the year and we've added some additional ones in some categories, but it's been more of a constant work in primarily in produce, a little bit in grocery, a little bit in meat and seafood where we worked on prices, we tried to really get ourselves very clear on pricing to the marketplace. We watch what's going on in the marketplace, adjusted for some of that and it's kind of an ongoing process where we're happy with, especially happy with the unit growth that we've seen in produce and in some of the other areas. And that's encouraged us to look forward to doing even more next year.

componenttext: This is David, I also just want to say we really feel we're hitting our groove with our produce prices here in the Austin market and we're encouraged to roll out in other places in next year.

componenttext: Yes, the Affinity program is currently in the Philadelphia market, and we're moving shortly to another couple markets with some additional tests. We've actually -- we have slowed down the rollout which we anticipated because we have so much feedback from the customers about the features they like or the suggestions they have so we are on target couple of markets and that's where we are right now. We're just going a little slower in order it right as we go. And so that's where we are.

componenttext: In terms of that 365 store in Silver Lake, at least according to some media report, that location originally was going to be a legacy banner with a 1 bar, et cetera, and juice, can you talk about some of the factors that went into her choosing this particular location for the 365 launch? What about that area that was most appealing that sort of led you to go with that one rather than somewhere else?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, super cool neighborhood, we probably want to live there. So we're pretty excited about it. We feel it's a very knowledgeable core customer that understands Whole Foods. We also think that there's a variety of other stores right inside that market th
componenttext: Well, super cool neighborhood, we probably want to live there. So we're pretty excited about it. We feel it's a very knowledgeable core customer that understands Whole Foods. We also think that there's a variety of other stores right inside that market that we can compete with very well. It's also, with our 365 brand, we see that size store that's in Silverlake actually fits within that brand of 365 modeling. Whole Foods, the mothership will be bigger stores more like 40 to 50,000 square feet. And that kind of fit the right market. And also we really -- we're excited about the work that Ken and I and Jeff and the team have done in terms of the very interesting store design, some of the tech enhancements, and we want to get it out in the public sooner or later. Because we've signed -- we have that signed lease, so we just kind of intercepted it for the 365 concept. We're thinking that we'll probably be able to sneak a wine bar in there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One way to think about it, I mean, this is not going to be hard and fast rule because it would be exceptions may but in general, to Whole Foods Market brand is going to be bigger stores, it's going to be where we can do all the really cool stuff with our
componenttext: One way to think about it, I mean, this is not going to be hard and fast rule because it would be exceptions may but in general, to Whole Foods Market brand is going to be bigger stores, it's going to be where we can do all the really cool stuff with our prepared foods, lots of venues, bigger product selection, it's just these are going to be, I mean, more stores kind of like our flagship store in Austin and we think that type of format has tremendous competitive advantages in the marketplace. But to get big store locations, that's a more selective market that we can do those type of stores. We see the 365 stores as being a smaller and able to slide into lots of markets where we can't find the big format store. So same quality standards and it will just be a little bit of focus. It will be a lot easier to explain actually when we open a store up and people can see it. Then it would be really clear, it's like, oh, I get it, and hopefully you'll say this is a terrific idea.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Just to remind you on the 365, just to expand the reach to more customers, to more communities and while we're starting in one that we're well-established in, it's an area that we're not exactly in right now. And I think so it does complement the other stores in and around it, but that's the whole purpose of 365 is to see us broadening our reach a little bit.

componenttextpreview: I just want to just going to perishables deflation, it's obviously something that a lot of players are struggling with right now. Is it something that affects Whole Foods differently or harder than maybe some of the conventional grocers? And also, how do
componenttext: I just want to just going to perishables deflation, it's obviously something that a lot of players are struggling with right now. Is it something that affects Whole Foods differently or harder than maybe some of the conventional grocers? And also, how do you foresee it playing out? When do you think you can anniversary the pressure on the perishables deflation side? Just my second sort of little question, any comment on sort of when we might be hitting the peak cannibalization or should be expect sequential pressures on comps to continue from cannibalization?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, it's A.C., I'll answer the first part. We've definitely been seeing some deflation in produce and a lot of it is our pricing investments because we're not seeing deflation, for instance, in organic produce, there's a lot of demand there and there's st
componenttext: Hi, it's A.C., I'll answer the first part. We've definitely been seeing some deflation in produce and a lot of it is our pricing investments because we're not seeing deflation, for instance, in organic produce, there's a lot of demand there and there's still upward pressure on prices and we sell a lot such a high percentage of our going to produce that, that affects us but our pricing initiatives in produce have definitely cost us, overall, to see a lowering of prices. And as I said earlier, we've been very happy with the unit lift there. The other area we've seen a little bit of deflation is in seafood. Some of the higher volume items that we sell like wild salmon at this time of the year is cheaper than last year, shrimp prices have come down and we also are surely more of our value frozen program. I know that I've seen some other retailers talk about the deflation in dairy, and while conventional dairy has come down a little bit, organic dairy, which we sell a lot of, is still seeing inflationary pressures. So in cases like that, we're probably dealing more the issue of not trying not to pass along some of the price increases that we've been seeing to keep those prices reasonable. We're also seeing a little bit of inflation in a few key areas like nuts like almonds and pistachios. Definitely they're seeing a lot of inflation because of the droughts in California. And we sell a lot of olive oil and there was a big crop failure in Italy this year, so we're seeing a little there. So we're really seeing a little bit going both ways in inflation.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: And with regard to cannibalization, just a little that. We do estimate that in Q3, that impact was about 30 basis points greater than it was in Q2 and that will probably continue, if not get a little bit worse in Q4.

componenttextpreview: And with respect your second question, John, you may add some to, that, I mean, will tell you this team is 100% focused on looking at every aspect of our business and including growth rates and what possibilities might be there with some of the leases sig
componenttext: And with respect your second question, John, you may add some to, that, I mean, will tell you this team is 100% focused on looking at every aspect of our business and including growth rates and what possibilities might be there with some of the leases signed along the way, there are some limited festivity in the first bit of time but although scenarios minute that as a what makes the most sense for the company. Want to add to that, John?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's, of course, I hope this isn't heresy but gradually don't manage to the company to maximize same-store sales but to maximize return on invested capital and EVA. And what this go down in comps doesn't real estate is so that it requires us to refo
componenttext: Well, it's, of course, I hope this isn't heresy but gradually don't manage to the company to maximize same-store sales but to maximize return on invested capital and EVA. And what this go down in comps doesn't real estate is so that it requires us to reformulate or recalculate when we look at new stores with a lower comp base, that means it's a tougher real estate hurdle. So we just had a real estate meeting in Tuesday and all the sites we were looking at on Tuesday, which was about 10 sites, they all had to have lower comp expectations. And that made achieving our 5-year EVA hurdle more difficult for them. And just a couple of them washed out. That would have passed intrigue issue as to meetings with more aggressive comp assumptions. So we've already adjusted, you might say, to a lower comp basis and that makes it difficult -- more difficult for locations to hit the ROICs and EVAs that we require. I suppose the good news is that even with the lower comps, we still have a lot of sites that are going to be extremely profitable for us and profitable for the shareholders. So I think the key takeaway there is we're not going to slow down our growth unless we can't find locations that are going to produce 5-year EVAs on a present value basis that will give us the returns on invested capital that we're looking for. As long as we can, that's how we're going to continue to manage the business. And so, anyway, that's our answer.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: To point out the 365 stores, you have visibility to look at real estate differently and the low cost to build out gives you the opportunity for growth there that we can look at sites that are Whole Foods we can also look at sites at 365. That opens a whole new dimension for us to grow there as well.

We forget about what we're doing that's why we reaffirmed our vertical.

componenttext: Just a clarification, after the financial crisis, you were able to go back and adjust some of the terms and conditions. Was that a function of that error or as necessary, could you do that here with the 114 in the pipeline if circumstances develop [indiscernible].

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jim, I think 2008 was more a function of the economic reality of  the time. In particular as it related to developers. Many of the sites that we terminated were because the landlords could no longer deliver the sites on the terms that we had set f
componenttext: This is Jim, I think 2008 was more a function of the economic reality of  the time. In particular as it related to developers. Many of the sites that we terminated were because the landlords could no longer deliver the sites on the terms that we had set forth and they still gave us an opportunity to exit some sites that became marginal based on the economic times.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: They couldn't get our financing so we terminated. We're not in the same situation today. We have gone back and reviewed our real estate. Yes, there are a few locations that, given the current comp environment, are not 5-year EVA deals anymore, but they're
componenttext: They couldn't get our financing so we terminated. We're not in the same situation today. We have gone back and reviewed our real estate. Yes, there are a few locations that, given the current comp environment, are not 5-year EVA deals anymore, but they're still good deals for us. And but the most important things are the ones that are in the pipeline in a sense we're legally committed to go forward and we're still very confident that we haven't most of our stores are really outstanding stores. All we can do is adjust to the new comp environment by changing our real estate protocols to have a steeper approval hurdle to get through and we've done that. We've made the adjustment. And so the stores that we, for example, signed and announced today, those are all going to do well with very low comps according to our projections.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you look at the development schedules as a whole, the 114 stores, prior to the adjustment in comps, they have this less than 5 years EVA on a pro forma basis. So it's not as we've gone from 5 to 6 to 7 years. We feel like the overall schedule is still
componenttext: If you look at the development schedules as a whole, the 114 stores, prior to the adjustment in comps, they have this less than 5 years EVA on a pro forma basis. So it's not as we've gone from 5 to 6 to 7 years. We feel like the overall schedule is still within the 5-year EVA.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe one other thing to add, we've also made the real estate hurdle even tougher because we have assumed --we've looked ahead and we assumed the price investments we're making. We've dialed that in to the formula. So we're assuming for new stores, much l
componenttext: Maybe one other thing to add, we've also made the real estate hurdle even tougher because we have assumed --we've looked ahead and we assumed the price investments we're making. We've dialed that in to the formula. So we're assuming for new stores, much lower gross margins than they historically had. And even so, we still are finding great sites with lower gross margins with lower comp growth, it still hit our 5-year EVA hurdle.

componenttext: This is David, the store reopened this year with open a lot of blockbusters.
