componenttext: Okay, I guess, slightly different direction, back on 365, I'm a little confused. Is the primary goal to capture new incremental customers who don't currently shop Whole Foods, or is it to capture additional trips from existing customers?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's both, both, both.  Although I have to quibble with words. We never feel like we can capture any customers. At best, we can rent them for a little while if we continue to create value and service to them, but we do think the 365 is going to have some
componenttext: It's both, both, both.  Although I have to quibble with words. We never feel like we can capture any customers. At best, we can rent them for a little while if we continue to create value and service to them, but we do think the 365 is going to have some appeal to our existing Whole Foods customer base because in some cases, it will have a greater appeal to more value-oriented customer that we already have. I think it's going to open up a whole new set of customers who so far have, for various reasons, have not liked Whole Foods Market, potentially, potentially, they think our prices are too high. There's no question 365 is going to have very, very competitive prices.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then real quick on the house passing HR 1599, you guys have any comments there what the next steps are toward GMO labeling?
componenttext: Okay, and then real quick on the house passing HR 1599, you guys have any comments there what the next steps are toward GMO labeling?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well we know that the House passed it and we know that the proposal is that there would be -- the USDA would set of programs and that no mandatory labeling would be required if any laws were passed by states, they will be preempted. We know that it still
componenttext: Well we know that the House passed it and we know that the proposal is that there would be -- the USDA would set of programs and that no mandatory labeling would be required if any laws were passed by states, they will be preempted. We know that it still has to go to the Senate and it could change from what it is currently. They may happen, they may not happen, we don't really know anything with that. We made it very clear that we support labeling. We think it's important from a transparency standpoint. We've heard from a lot of our customers. Polls have shown that the vast majority of Americans would like to know if there's GMOs in their products. Then we support labeling for people to know that. How it will affect us, we don't know. We're not exact 100% sure, but we don't think that it affects any of the current labeling that we have in place that we've worked with, the non-GMO project, working with some other third-party verifiers. We think that, from the way we read the law, that they would be able to get -- the program they are working with wouldn't be disrupted by this, and eventually, they could get accredited to continue to do what they're doing.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: John here, my interpretation is that it doesn't affect Whole Foods at all. Whole Foods is still committed to transparency regarding GMOs. We're going to do exactly what we committed to do and we will hit our deadlines. My interpretation reading that is th
componenttext: John here, my interpretation is that it doesn't affect Whole Foods at all. Whole Foods is still committed to transparency regarding GMOs. We're going to do exactly what we committed to do and we will hit our deadlines. My interpretation reading that is they're basically trying to preempt states like Vermont and other states from creating their own GMO laws, so they're trying to prevent the states from doing that. It will not affect a private certification or Whole Foods' own efforts for transparency.

componenttext: I wanted to dig in a little more on your produce price cut test markets. Our price were showing you are doing about 10% to 12% price cut in those produce areas and initially it sounded like you're getting a double-digit volume lift there. You now have some duration to it. Are you still seeing enthusiasm from customers, now that the tests have been going on for sometime, and have you been taking some of those best ideas out to the other stores in the produce sections?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've said in the past that when you make price adjustments and price investments in the produce department, there's lag time. It can take anywhere from 6 to 9 months until you start to see -- initially you'll see a nice increase in units, but you s
componenttext: Well, we've said in the past that when you make price adjustments and price investments in the produce department, there's lag time. It can take anywhere from 6 to 9 months until you start to see -- initially you'll see a nice increase in units, but you still may be negative in overall sales dollars because it's kind of how deep the price cuts are. So we have been very encouraged, we started to see in the last couple of periods where the actual sales have gone positive and those produce departments are comping positive now. So the units now have increased in a lot of them above where the investment is. That's been very encouraging to us, and we definitely have plans to use those learnings in additional storage and regions as we go forward, especially next fiscal year.

componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Whole Food's Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth & Development; and David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations. 
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. We will discuss our Q3 comparable store sales growth results, excluding the 95 basis point negative impact from the Easter shift and Team Member Double Discount Day. Also, please note our results include an $8 million expense, or 21 basis points, related to the implementation of California's new paid sick leave law. 
Walter?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. I will briefly review the quarter and focus most of my time today on our outlook going forward. Year-over-year, our quarterly sales grew $255 million to a record $3.6 billion. We opened 8 new stores and increasi
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. I will briefly review the quarter and focus most of my time today on our outlook going forward. Year-over-year, our quarterly sales grew $255 million to a record $3.6 billion. We opened 8 new stores and increasing our operating square footage 11% to $16 million and expanding our reach to 422 stores across 41 states and 3 countries. On an adjusted basis, comparable store sales increased 2.2% for the quarter, moderating 90 basis points from Q2. We estimate that the negative impact from cannibalization was 30 basis points greater in Q3 than in Q2. Comps improved 20 basis points from the last 9 weeks of Q2 to the first 10 weeks of Q3, driven primarily by a 70 basis point improvement in traffic, which was partially offset by a 50 basis point decrease in basket size. We attribute the moderation in basket size primarily due to our value efforts and to cost deflation in few key product categories, including produce. 
Comps dropped sharply in week 11, and after our New York City weights and measures audit received national media attention, and averaged just 0.4% for the last 2 weeks of the quarter. We have seen a slight improvement in trends fourth quarter to date. However, comps are still well below our 2.5% average for the 19 weeks prior to the negative publicity. We believe increasing headwinds are also a factor as sales began to stabilize in the last few weeks of Q3 last year. 
I want to take a moment to address the New York City weights and measures audit. As soon as the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs came to us, we worked to understand and address the issues to prevent them from happening again. I want to emphasize these were not systematic, but rather caused by inadvertent human error. The audit included errors that were favorable to customers as well. These are weights and measures issues that can be found in any supermarket. 
Clear and transparent pricing is integral to how we operate. We have taken immediate steps to address these issues including improving our training regarding in-store packing, weighing and labeling processes, and expanding our third-party auditing process company-wide. We built our business on the core value of satisfying and delighting our customers. It is what our customers have grown to love and expect from us and our approach to pricing transparency is no different. If a price is not accurate and not priced in the customer's favor, then that item is free to the customer, no charge, no question. 
Turning back to our results, gross margin, x LIFO, decreased 66 basis points year-over-year driven primarily by an increase in cost of goods sold as a percentage of sales. Our results reflect our more aggressive efforts to improve our price relevancy as well as higher shrink in the last 2 weeks of the quarter, given that purchases were planned for a higher level of sales heading into the 4th of July holiday. SG&A increased 24 basis points to 28.4% of sales against a record low in the prior year, due primarily to higher depreciation as a percentage of sales. Results included 21 basis points in expense related to the implementation of California's new paid sick leave law. Despite lower-than-expected sales, we maintained our labor expense disciplines and leveraged wages. 
Our new store class for the last 8 quarters has averaged 38 stores, with sales per gross square foot of approximately $700, translating to productivity levels of 78% on a weighted square footage basis. Comparable stores less than 2 years old have averaged 15% comps and most importantly, a 13% return on invested capital well in excess of our weighted average cost of capital. In a challenging sales environment, we delivered 9.7% EBITDA margin, $287 million of operating cash flow and a 15% return on invested capital. Year-to-date, we have produced industry-leading sales per gross square foot of $990, over $1 billion in EBITDA and $1 billion in cash flow from operations. Through our strong balance sheet and robust cash flows, we have self-funded our new store development and strategic growth initiatives while returning over $325 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. 
The Whole Foods Market brand has helped lead the shift in consciousness towards fresh, healthy foods. With 424 stores totaling more than 16 million square feet today, we expect to cross the 500-store mark in fiscal year 2017, and over the longer term, continue to seek potential for 1,200 Whole Foods Market stores in the United States. 
As announced last quarter, we are introducing a second format, 365 by Whole Foods Market, which we believe expands our growth opportunity beyond the 1,200 stores. While more streamlined than a typical Whole Foods Market store, our 365 stores will be guided by the same industry-leading quality standards. As a second growth vehicle, 365 will be very complementary to our Whole Foods Market brand, allowing us to address the value-quality proposition in a new way while maintaining the integrity the Whole Foods Market brand represents in the marketplace. 365 President Jeff Turnas is building a top-notch team and has hit the ground running. We are excited today to announce leases for the 5 365 stores in Los Angeles, Santa Monica, Portland, Houston and Bellevue, Washington. These are all A+ real estate sites which meet our required EVA-hurdle return. We are currently targeting up to 5 365 store openings in the second half of next calendar year, with the expectation of doubling that number of openings in calendar 2017. With opportunities in new and existing as well as urban and suburban markets, most of our first stores are expected to be in the existing markets to better leverage our existing team member base and infrastructure. Our first 365 by Whole Foods Market store is scheduled to open in the Silver Lake area of Los Angeles, where we converted a lease and development from Whole Foods Market to 365. Los Angeles is the perfect dense urban market, where customers already love our quality standards and transparency to introduce our latest evolution focused on quality food and value in a convenient format. We're excited to reveal more as things develop. 
Turning now to our outlook for Q4, we have opened 2 new stores and expect to open 8 additional stores, including 1 relocation. If current comp trends continue, we would expect sales growth of approximately 7% and diluted earnings per share of $0.34 to $0.35. This outlook reflects current trends, as well as some headwinds from moderating inflation, increased cannibalization and our own value efforts. 
For the fiscal year, this translates to sales growth of approximately 9%, with comps in the low-single digits and square footage up 10%. We continue to expect EBITDA margin of approximately 9% and ROIC greater than 14%. For the next fiscal year, we are forecasting ending square footage growth of approximately 9% or 7.5% growth on a weighted square footage basis, reflecting a back-end-loaded store-opening schedule. We will provide additional details in our outlook next quarter. 
In summary, in this retail marketplace, which is more dynamic and competitive than ever, we believe we are taking the necessary steps to position ourself for the long-term. While we acknowledge it is taking longer than we would have hoped, we believe we continue to invest in our price relevancy, our marketing and our technologies the right strategy to regain sales momentum. We are encouraged by the unit lift we have seen from our price investments and will continue to expand on that strategy. We are committed to investing in marketing to support our value efforts as well as our brand and are excited by our new brand campaign this fall. 
Year-to-date, we have made progress in our digital and technology efforts to better serve our customers. We are live with both Workday for all of our team members, have launched our new iOS and Android mobile apps, refreshed our web experience and are testing and evolving our Affinity program. While still in the early stages, we have also piloted our new OnePOS and kiosk ordering for food menus and are rolling out labor scheduling to our customer service teams. We will continue to build out and enhance these efforts next year while also beginning to mobilize our new product platform, which will bring us many new exciting capabilities such as perpetual inventory, replenishment, space planning and price optimization. 
We remain focused on innovating and evolving to best serve our customers' diverse purchasing preferences in this rapidly changing marketplace. From the unique experience of our Whole Foods Market stores, to the growing online channel for home delivery, to the exciting launch of our 365 by Whole Foods Market stores, we are leaning in to extend our reach to new as well as existing customers. 
We will now take questions. Our call will end at 4:45 Central Time today to allow more time for questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

componenttext: Walter, when you look at the slowdown over the past 5 weeks, I guess, how can you guys be so precise that the New York audit is the primary factor? And I guess more importantly, what steps are you taking to fix the problem, given that it seems like it's bled into the first few weeks here of the fourth quarter?

componenttextpreview: Chuck, well, again, I think in our -- in the script -- in the comments here we said that we -- look, I mean, we tried to give you the evidence on the chart there that kind of showed the breakdown of the quarter, of the weeks in the quarter, at the end of
componenttext: Chuck, well, again, I think in our -- in the script -- in the comments here we said that we -- look, I mean, we tried to give you the evidence on the chart there that kind of showed the breakdown of the quarter, of the weeks in the quarter, at the end of the quarter, the start of the quarter and the start of the new quarter to help you get some visibility into the impact of it. Clearly, it affected the comps. Clearly, there's other factors at work here too in terms of the headwinds from the previous year strong sales and so forth. But by any measure, it has significant impact on our sales. And with respect to the second part of your question, we've already taken the steps to again, this was in light of our New York City stores to upgrade the training processes right away, to employ -- to bring in a third-party firm to audit our procedures and results and improve those, and those steps have ready been taken. And in fact, we've been inspected subsequent times since without incident so all those things were already in place.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I, would like to follow on to the last questions. The question isn't just how you get your people to do the right thing because clearly you've done that. The question is how do you change customer perception that somehow Whole Foods can't be trust
componenttext: I guess I, would like to follow on to the last questions. The question isn't just how you get your people to do the right thing because clearly you've done that. The question is how do you change customer perception that somehow Whole Foods can't be trusted?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think that's a really fair question, Meredith, and there's no -- we're taking all the steps, even trust had us to be -- if trust is broken, it has to be rebuilt a step at a time and through solid execution day in and day out. And there's no
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that's a really fair question, Meredith, and there's no -- we're taking all the steps, even trust had us to be -- if trust is broken, it has to be rebuilt a step at a time and through solid execution day in and day out. And there's no magic bullet for restoring whatever trust was lost other than us being transparent about what it is, make sure you put this in context that this is something that every supermarket has. And that we've taken the steps and that we continue to convince our customers that we're doing the right thing by each and every day. I mean, every store now has the customer pledge at the register, letting them know that if you have any concerns, all ask and we'll recheck and if you're dissatisfied, we'll give it back to you, whatever. So all of those things are in place. And I think it's just a matter of sawn wood and doing a good work day in and day out to continue to build that trust.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, John here. We don't think our track record is any different than any other supermarket. We're not sure why Whole Foods was singled out for this attention. We don't know why the media ran wild with this. Our error rates are very small, we've done
componenttext: Meredith, John here. We don't think our track record is any different than any other supermarket. We're not sure why Whole Foods was singled out for this attention. We don't know why the media ran wild with this. Our error rates are very small, we've done our own auditing. We put in procedures now so that we can perhaps be perfect. But we believe an objective evaluation, if you compare Whole Foods' record, these are inadvertent errors, and there's no systematic mistakes being made here. It's a very small percentage of our total product. It's just something that went viral in the media, and it has hurt our trust. And yet we do feel like we're victims of -- we don't know exactly why or the DCA went after Whole Foods like this. We're not sure why the media went crazy with it. But it did happen. We are taking steps to not give cause for this in the future. As far as reestablishing trust with our customers, there's no magic wand we can wave. We're giving -- we're going to do third-party audits, we're going to show that, we're going to be transparent about it, and hopefully over time, the basic integrity of our company and the good customer service we provide will put this in the past and we'll move on past it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'll just say we're very encouraged by the results of our third-party audits. We're doing them across the country, not just on New York but everywhere and we're passing audit after audit. We're eliminating the few errors we do find. And our
componenttext: This is David. I'll just say we're very encouraged by the results of our third-party audits. We're doing them across the country, not just on New York but everywhere and we're passing audit after audit. We're eliminating the few errors we do find. And our team members are really active about this because they want to do right by their neighbors and their customers, and they're -- we're all over it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Meredith, you see the sales trends, you have them on the chart there you can see. As Glenda said, it's too early, but it does. There is some hope that we're going back in the other direction now and we will -- the steps -- the additional steps we're ta
componenttext: So Meredith, you see the sales trends, you have them on the chart there you can see. As Glenda said, it's too early, but it does. There is some hope that we're going back in the other direction now and we will -- the steps -- the additional steps we're taking the bigger picture here to do, rebuild the momentum, sales momentum of the company, which is in our pricing efforts, our marketing efforts, our technology and platform efforts, all those things continue, and to continue to do that. And we do have our additional brand campaign coming this fall, which again is an effort to kind of highlight what the company is all about and remind people what's different about Whole Foods Market.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we can take our next question from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we can take our next question from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I just have a couple of questions. I guess the 30,000 square-foot size seems a little larger than I would have thought, and you did indicate it in the prepared remarks that there will be A+ locations. So I guess with that type of, like, location, how d
componenttext: So I just have a couple of questions. I guess the 30,000 square-foot size seems a little larger than I would have thought, and you did indicate it in the prepared remarks that there will be A+ locations. So I guess with that type of, like, location, how do you get comfortable that you can maintain your ROIC because obviously price points will be lower and rents seemed like they're going to be in line with what you're paying at your Whole Foods format? And then I guess the 4 markets that you've indicated you're going to open, obviously you've also told us some rationale from that, but there are obviously, I guess close to existing Whole Foods store. So how do you think about the rest of the cannibalization?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Karen, John here. We actually think we'll get superior ROICs with the 365 format. We're going to have significantly reduced capital investments as well as significantly lower labor costs. And of course, we don't know whether we'll actually open some store
componenttext: Karen, John here. We actually think we'll get superior ROICs with the 365 format. We're going to have significantly reduced capital investments as well as significantly lower labor costs. And of course, we don't know whether we'll actually open some stores. But when we project this out, if we get anything close to what Whole Foods Market sales per square foot are in our new stores, the 365 stores are going to be incredibly profitable and with very high ROICs, even with reduced gross margins. I mean, will there be some cannibalization of Whole Foods? I mean, probably, but we don't know exactly how much until we do. It will probably be less than we open up an actual branded Whole Foods Market store because it's going to appeal to a little bit different customer, we think. So it is an experiment. We do have 5 stores committed. We have several other stores we are negotiating leases on. And a year from now, we're going to have a lot more data for you because we'll have some stores open, we'll see what they're doing, will see what the effects are, we'll see what our ROICs are. All I can say is we're super excited about it. We think we're going to have great stores, good locations, low gross margins, low labor, low capital investments and very high returns on invested capital, so.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other point I want to make is, with 365, we look at it as a hand and we feel like it's very complementary to being in the area of Whole Foods so that a customer has choices between going into a 365 or Whole Foods depending upon the time, what they wan
componenttext: One other point I want to make is, with 365, we look at it as a hand and we feel like it's very complementary to being in the area of Whole Foods so that a customer has choices between going into a 365 or Whole Foods depending upon the time, what they want to accomplish with the shop. And so we're hoping that it captures both of their choices when they decide to go out and shop. So we're not -- we look at the cannibalization, we think it is going to be lower, but we also are really encouraged by the chance that we have to capture more trips that the customer would have shopping.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: This is David. Ken and I have been working really hard on the -- really excited about the Silver Lake design. I think one of your questions was about the size difference say between 25 to 30k, and we're kind of staying disciplined about what we're going to do with the 365 model. We have this concept we're calling Friends of 365 where we are actually talking to interesting local suppliers that might rent out a small part of the space. So again, our core store will be somewhere between 25 to 30, but we're also looking at opportunities to work with some local suppliers to give it some local flavor as well.

componenttext: And also just to follow up on the price investments, can you give any further color in terms of, are they coming from an expanded number of SKUs? Or is it more heavier cuts from still a relatively same select base? Can you give any color around that?

componenttextpreview: Yes, hi, well, we've been -- I would say it's a little bit of both. We definitely have continued -- beginning of the year we started around the produce investments, which we've continued through the year. And we've added some additional ones in some categ
componenttext: Yes, hi, well, we've been -- I would say it's a little bit of both. We definitely have continued -- beginning of the year we started around the produce investments, which we've continued through the year. And we've added some additional ones in some categories, but it's been more of a constant work in primarily in produce, a little bit in grocery, a little bit in meat and seafood, where we've worked on prices, we've tried to really get ourselves very clear on pricing to the marketplace. We watch what's going on in the marketplace, adjusted for some of that. And it's kind of an ongoing process where we're happy with -- especially happy with the unit growth that we've seen in produce and in some of the other areas. And that's encouraged us to look forward to doing even more next year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: This is David. I also just want to say we really feel we're hitting our groove with our produce prices here in the Austin market and we're encouraged to roll out in other places in next year.

componenttext: Great. And if I could just one quick, quick question, can you just give us an update going back to the kind of trust and loyalty? Can you give us an update in terms of how many stores have this Affinity program and plans for the rest of this year?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the Affinity program is currently in the Philadelphia market, and we're moving shortly to another couple markets with some additional tests. We've actually -- we have slowed down the rollout which we really anticipated because we've gotten so much fe
componenttext: Yes, the Affinity program is currently in the Philadelphia market, and we're moving shortly to another couple markets with some additional tests. We've actually -- we have slowed down the rollout which we really anticipated because we've gotten so much feedback from our customers about the features they like or the suggestions they have, so we're on to a couple of new markets. And that's where we are right now. We're just going a little slower in order to get right as we go. And -- but we're so that's where we are.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of that 365 store in Silver Lake, at least according to some media reports, that location originally was going to be a legacy banner with a one bar, et cetera, I'm curious, can you talk about some of the factors that went into your choosing this
componenttext: In terms of that 365 store in Silver Lake, at least according to some media reports, that location originally was going to be a legacy banner with a one bar, et cetera, I'm curious, can you talk about some of the factors that went into your choosing this particular location for the 365 launch? What about that area was most appealing that sort of led you to go with that one rather than somewhere else?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, super cool neighborhood, you probably want to live there. So we're pretty excited about it. We're excited about it. We feel it's a very knowledgeable core customer that understands Whole Foods. We also think that there's a variety of other stores ri
componenttext: Well, super cool neighborhood, you probably want to live there. So we're pretty excited about it. We're excited about it. We feel it's a very knowledgeable core customer that understands Whole Foods. We also think that there's a variety of other stores right inside that market that we can compete with very well. And it's also, with our 365 brand, we see that size store that's in Silver Lake actually fits within that brand of 365 model. And the Whole Foods will -- Whole Foods is the mother ship that will be bigger stores more like 40,000 to 50,000 square feet. And that kind of fit the right market. And also we really -- we're excited about the work that Ken and I and Jeff and the team have done in terms of the very interesting store design, some of the tech enhancements, and we want to get it out in the public sooner than later. Because we've signed that -- we have that signed lease, so we just kind of intercepted it for the 365 concept. And we're thinking that we'll probably be able to still sneak a wine bar in there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One way to think about it, I mean, this is not going to be hard and fast rule because there will be exceptions made, but in general, the Whole Foods Market brand is going to be bigger stores, it's going to be where we can do all the really cool stuff with
componenttext: One way to think about it, I mean, this is not going to be hard and fast rule because there will be exceptions made, but in general, the Whole Foods Market brand is going to be bigger stores, it's going to be where we can do all the really cool stuff with our prepared foods, lots of venues, bigger product selection, it's just these are going to be, I mean, more stores kind of like our flagship store in Austin and we think that type of format has tremendous competitive advantages in the marketplace. We see the -- but to get big store locations, that's a more selected markets that we can do those type of stores. We see the 365 stores as being a smaller and able to slide in, in lots of markets where we can't find the big format store. So same quality standards, and it will just be a little bit of focus. It will be a lot easier to explain actually when we open a store up in -- and people can see it. Then it would be really clear, it's like, "Oh, I get it." And hopefully you'll say, "This is a terrific idea."

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Ken, I think that [indiscernible] just to remind you on the 365, as just to expand the reach to more customers, to more communities. And while we're starting in one that we're well-established in, it's an area that we're not exactly in right now. And I think -- so it does complement the other stores in and around it, but it's just -- that's the whole purpose of 365 is to see us about broadening our reach a little bit.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a little bit more on the perishables deflation. It's obviously something that a lot of players are struggling with right now. Is it something that affects Whole Foods differently or harder than maybe some of the conventional grocers?
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a little bit more on the perishables deflation. It's obviously something that a lot of players are struggling with right now. Is it something that affects Whole Foods differently or harder than maybe some of the conventional grocers? And also, how do you foresee it playing out? When do you think you can anniversary the pressure on the perishables deflation side? Just my second sort of little question. And any comment on sort of when we might be hitting the peak cannibalization or should be expect sequential pressures on comps to continue from cannibalization?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's A.C., I'll answer the first part. We've definitely been seeing some deflation in produce and a lot of it is our pricing investments because we're not seeing deflation, for instance, in organic produce, there's a lot of demand there, and there's still
componenttext: It's A.C., I'll answer the first part. We've definitely been seeing some deflation in produce and a lot of it is our pricing investments because we're not seeing deflation, for instance, in organic produce, there's a lot of demand there, and there's still upward pressure on prices. And we sell a lot such a high percentage of organic produce that, that affects us. But our pricing initiatives in produce have definitely cost us, overall, to see a lowering of prices. And as I said earlier, we've been very happy with the unit lift there. The other area we've seen a little bit of deflation is in seafood. Some of the higher volume items that we sell like wild salmon at this time of the year is cheaper than last year. Shrimp prices have come down, and we also are selling more of our value frozen program. I know that I've seen some other retailers talk about a deflation in dairy, and while conventional dairy has come down a little bit, organic dairy, which we sell a lot of, is still seeing inflationary pressures. So in cases like that, we're probably dealing more with an issue of not trying not to pass along some of the price increases that we've been seeing to keep those prices reasonable. We're also seeing a little bit of inflation in a few key areas like nuts like almonds and pistachios. They've definitely been seeing a lot of inflation because of the droughts in California. And we sell a lot of olive oil and that's -- there was a big crop failure in Italy this year, so we're seeing a little there. So we're really seeing a little bit going both ways in inflation.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And with regard to cannibalization, just a little bit on that. We do estimate that in Q3, the impact was about 30 basis points greater than it was in Q2 and that will probably continue, if not get a little bit worse in Q4.
componenttext: And with regard to cannibalization, just a little bit on that. We do estimate that in Q3, the impact was about 30 basis points greater than it was in Q2 and that will probably continue, if not get a little bit worse in Q4.

componenttext: Can you explain what's happening with the square footage development next year that's creating that back-weighted dynamic? So why not slow down the growth?

componenttext: So just with regard to the square footage growth -- this is Glenda, it's just timing of store openings that creates the difference between the ending square footage growth and the average square footage growth next year. So we have quite a few openings toward the end of the year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And with respect your second question -- I see that, John, you want to add some, too, a bit. I mean, I'm telling you this team is 100% focused on looking at every aspect of our business and including growth rates and what possibilities might be there with
componenttext: And with respect your second question -- I see that, John, you want to add some, too, a bit. I mean, I'm telling you this team is 100% focused on looking at every aspect of our business and including growth rates and what possibilities might be there with some of the leases signed along the way, there are some limited flexibility in the first bit of time, but all those scenarios are being looked at and -- as to what makes the most sense for the company. So do you want to add to that, John?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's -- of course, I hope this isn't heresy but we actually don't manage the company to maximize same-store sales, but to maximize return on invested capital and EVA. And what the slowdown in comps does in real estate is that it requires us to refor
componenttext: Well, it's -- of course, I hope this isn't heresy but we actually don't manage the company to maximize same-store sales, but to maximize return on invested capital and EVA. And what the slowdown in comps does in real estate is that it requires us to reformulate or recalculate when we look at new stores with a lower comp base, that means it's a tougher real estate hurdle. So we just had a real estate meeting on Tuesday, and all the sites we were looking at on Tuesday, which was about 10 sites, they all had to have lower comp expectations. And that made achieving our 5-year EVA hurdle more difficult for them. And a couple of them washed out. That would have passed in previous real estate meetings with more aggressive comp assumptions. So we've already adjusted, you might say, to a lower comp basis and that makes it -- more difficult for locations to hit the ROICs and EVAs that we require. I suppose the good news is that even with the lower comps, we still have a lot of sites that are going to be extremely profitable for us and profitable for the shareholders. So I think the key takeaway there is that we're not going to slow down our growth unless we can't find locations that are going to produce 5-year EVAs on a present value basis and give us the returns on invested capital that we're looking for. As long as we can, that's how we're going to continue to manage the business. And so anyway, that's our answer.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One more -- point out that as the -- for the 365 stores, you have visibility to look at real estate differently and the low cost to build out gives you that opportunity for growth there that we can look at sites that are Whole Foods and we can also look a
componenttext: One more -- point out that as the -- for the 365 stores, you have visibility to look at real estate differently and the low cost to build out gives you that opportunity for growth there that we can look at sites that are Whole Foods and we can also look at sites that are for 365. So that opens a whole new dimension for us with real estate as well.

componenttext: We'll see another [indiscernible], we did go back and looked at everything and again looked at all the metrics for the ones that have been improved or in improvement. And to John's point, just apply the higher standards to make sure that we're -- the growth that we're doing were on track with -- from an investment and capital allocation standpoint and so that's where we are. We feel good about what we're doing and that's why we reaffirmed our growth goal.

componenttext: And just a clarification, after the financial crisis, you were able to go back and adjust some of the terms and conditions. Was that a function of that era or as necessary, could you do that here with the 114 in the pipeline if circumstances develop if you need to.

componenttextpreview: This is Jim. I think 2008 was more a function of the economic reality of the time, in particular as it related to developers. Many of the sites that we terminated were because the landlords could no longer deliver the sites on the terms that we had set fo
componenttext: This is Jim. I think 2008 was more a function of the economic reality of the time, in particular as it related to developers. Many of the sites that we terminated were because the landlords could no longer deliver the sites on the terms that we had set forth and they still gave us an opportunity to exit some sites that were -- became marginal based on the economic times.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: They couldn't get their financing so we terminated. We're not in the same situation today. We have gone back and reviewed all our real estate. And yes, there are a few locations that, given the current comp environment, are not 5-year EVA deals anymore, b
componenttext: They couldn't get their financing so we terminated. We're not in the same situation today. We have gone back and reviewed all our real estate. And yes, there are a few locations that, given the current comp environment, are not 5-year EVA deals anymore, but they're still good deals for us. And but -- so the most important thing is the ones that are in the pipeline in a sense we're legally committed to go forward, and we're still very confident that we haven't -- most of those stores are really outstanding stores. All we can do is adjust to the new comp environment by changing our real estate protocols to have a steeper approval hurdle to get through, and we've done that. We've made the adjustment. And so the stores that we, for example, signed and announced today, those are all going to do well with very low comps according to our projections.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And if you look at the development schedules as a whole, the 114 stores, prior to the adjustment in comps, they have us less than 5 years EVA on a pro forma basis. So it's not as we've gone from 5 to 6 to 7 years. So yes, we feel like the overall schedule
componenttext: And if you look at the development schedules as a whole, the 114 stores, prior to the adjustment in comps, they have us less than 5 years EVA on a pro forma basis. So it's not as we've gone from 5 to 6 to 7 years. So yes, we feel like the overall schedule is still within the 5-year EVA.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe one other thing to add. We've also made the real estate hurdle even tougher because we have assumed our -- we looked ahead and we've assumed the price investments we're making. We've dialed that in to the formula. So we're assuming for new stores, m
componenttext: Maybe one other thing to add. We've also made the real estate hurdle even tougher because we have assumed our -- we looked ahead and we've assumed the price investments we're making. We've dialed that in to the formula. So we're assuming for new stores, much lower gross margins than they've historically had. And even so, we still are finding great sites with lower gross margins with lower comp growth, it still hit our 5-year EVA hurdle.

Or is it to capture additional trips from existing customers because it seemed like 2 different real estate strategies.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's both, both, both. Hold up. Well, not to quibble with words, we never feel like we can capture any customers. At best, we can rent them for a little while if we continue to create value and service to them. But we do think the 365 is going to have som
componenttext: It's both, both, both. Hold up. Well, not to quibble with words, we never feel like we can capture any customers. At best, we can rent them for a little while if we continue to create value and service to them. But we do think the 365 is going to have some appeal to our existing Whole Foods customer base because -- and maybe have a better -- in some cases, it will have a greater appeal to more value-oriented customer that we already have. But I think it's going to open up a whole new set of customers who so far have, for various reasons, have not liked Whole Foods Market, potentially, potentially, they think our prices are too high. There's no question 365 is going to have very, very competitive prices.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then real quick on the House passing HR 1599. Do you guys have any comments there or what the next steps are toward GMO labeling?
componenttext: Okay. And then real quick on the House passing HR 1599. Do you guys have any comments there or what the next steps are toward GMO labeling?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we know that the House passed it and we know that the proposal is that there would be -- USDA would set up programs and that no mandatory labeling would be required and if any laws were passed by states, they would be preempted. We know that it stil
componenttext: Well, we know that the House passed it and we know that the proposal is that there would be -- USDA would set up programs and that no mandatory labeling would be required and if any laws were passed by states, they would be preempted. We know that it still has to go to the Senate, and it could still change from what it is currently. It may happen, it may not happen, we don't really know any of that. We made a -- we've made it very clear that we support labeling. We think it's important from a transparency standpoint. We've heard from a lot of our customers. And we know polls have shown that the majority -- the vast majority of Americans would like to know if there's GMOs in their products. So -- and we support the labeling because -- for people to know that. How it will affect us, we don't know. We're not exact 100% sure, but we don't think that it affects any of the current labeling that we have in place that we've worked with, the non-GMO project and working with some other third-party verifiers. We think that, from the way we read the law, that they would be able to get -- the programs they're working with wouldn't be disrupted by this, and eventually, they could get accredited to continue to do what they're doing.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, my interpretation -- John here, is that it doesn't affect Whole Foods at all. Whole Foods is still committed to transparency regarding GMOs. We're going to continue doing exactly what we committed to do and we will hit our deadlines. My interpretatio
componenttext: Yes, my interpretation -- John here, is that it doesn't affect Whole Foods at all. Whole Foods is still committed to transparency regarding GMOs. We're going to continue doing exactly what we committed to do and we will hit our deadlines. My interpretation of reading that is they're basically trying to preempt states like Vermont and other states from creating their own GMO laws, so they're trying to prevent the states from doing that. It will not affect a private certification or Whole Foods' own efforts for transparency.

componenttext: I wanted to dig in a little more on your produce price cut test markets. Our price rates were showing that you were doing about 10% to 12% price cut in those produce areas. And initially it sounded like you're getting a double-digit volume lift there. You now have some duration to it. Are you still seeing enthusiasm from customers now that the tests have been going on for sometime? And have you been taking some of those best ideas out to the other stores in the produce sections?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've often said -- we said in the past that when you make price adjustments and price investments in the produce department, there's lag time. It can take anywhere from 6 to 9 months until you start to see -- initially, you'll see a nice increase i
componenttext: Well, we've often said -- we said in the past that when you make price adjustments and price investments in the produce department, there's lag time. It can take anywhere from 6 to 9 months until you start to see -- initially, you'll see a nice increase in units, but you still may be negative in overall sales dollars because -- depending how deep your price cuts are. So we've been very encouraged and started to see in the last couple of periods where the actual sales have gone positive, and those produce departments are comping positive now. So the units now have increased in a lot of them above where the investment is. That's been very encouraging to us, and we definitely have plans to use those learnings in additional stores in regions as we go forward, especially next fiscal year.

componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Whole Food's Third Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth & Development; and David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations. 
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. We will discuss our Q3 comparable store sales growth results, excluding the 95 basis point negative impact from the Easter shift and Team Member Double Discount Day. Also, please note our results include an $8 million expense, or 21 basis points, related to the implementation of California's new paid sick leave law. 
Walter?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. I will briefly review the quarter and focus most of my time today on our outlook going forward. Year-over-year, our quarterly sales grew $255 million to a record $3.6 billion. We opened 8 new stores, increasing
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. I will briefly review the quarter and focus most of my time today on our outlook going forward. Year-over-year, our quarterly sales grew $255 million to a record $3.6 billion. We opened 8 new stores, increasing our operating square footage 11% to $16 million and expanding our reach to 422 stores across 41 states and 3 countries. On an adjusted basis, comparable store sales increased 2.2% for the quarter, moderating 90 basis points from Q2. We estimate that the negative impact from cannibalization was 30 basis points greater in Q3 than in Q2. Comps improved 20 basis points from the last 9 weeks of Q2 to the first 10 weeks of Q3, driven primarily by a 70 basis point improvement in traffic, which was partially offset by a 50 basis point decrease in basket size. We attribute the moderation in basket size primarily due to our value efforts and to cost deflation in few key product categories, including produce. 
Comps dropped sharply in week 11, and after our New York City weights and measures audit received national media attention, and averaged just 0.4% for the last 2 weeks of the quarter. We have seen a slight improvement in trends fourth quarter to date. However, comps are still well below our 2.5% average for the 19 weeks prior to the negative publicity. We believe increasing headwinds are also a factor as sales began to stabilize in the last few weeks of Q3 last year. 
I want to take a moment to address the New York City weights and measures audit. As soon as the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs came to us, we worked to understand and address the issues to prevent them from happening again. I want to emphasize these were not systematic, but rather caused by inadvertent human error. The audit included errors that were favorable to customers as well. These are weights and measures issues that can be found in any supermarket. 
Clear and transparent pricing is integral to how we operate. We have taken immediate steps to address these issues including improving our training regarding in-store packing, weighing and labeling processes, and expanding our third-party auditing process company-wide. We built our business on the core value of satisfying and delighting our customers. It is what our customers have grown to love and expect from us and our approach to pricing transparency is no different. If a price is not accurate and not priced in the customer's favor, then that item is free to the customer, no charge, no question. 
Turning back to our results, gross margin, x LIFO, decreased 66 basis points year-over-year driven primarily by an increase in cost of goods sold as a percentage of sales. Our results reflect our more aggressive efforts to improve our price relevancy as well as higher shrink in the last 2 weeks of the quarter, given that purchases were planned for a higher level of sales heading into the 4th of July holiday. SG&A increased 24 basis points to 28.4% of sales against a record low in the prior year, due primarily to higher depreciation as a percentage of sales. Results included 21 basis points in expense related to the implementation of California's new paid sick leave law. Despite lower-than-expected sales, we maintained our labor expense disciplines and leveraged wages. 
Our new store class for the last 8 quarters has averaged 38 stores, with sales per gross square foot of approximately $700, translating to productivity levels of 78% on a weighted square footage basis. Comparable stores less than 2 years old have averaged 15% comps and most importantly, a 13% return on invested capital well in excess of our weighted average cost of capital. In a challenging sales environment, we delivered 9.7% EBITDA margin, $287 million of operating cash flow and a 15% return on invested capital. Year-to-date, we have produced industry-leading sales per gross square foot of $990, over $1 billion in EBITDA and $1 billion in cash flow from operations. Through our strong balance sheet and robust cash flows, we have self-funded our new store development and strategic growth initiatives while returning over $325 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. 
The Whole Foods Market brand has helped lead the shift in consciousness towards fresh, healthy foods. With 424 stores totaling more than 16 million square feet today, we expect to cross the 500-store mark in fiscal year 2017, and over the longer term, continue to see potential for 1,200 Whole Foods Market stores in the United States. 
As announced last quarter, we are introducing a second format, 365 by Whole Foods Market, which we believe expands our growth opportunity beyond the 1,200 stores. While more streamlined than a typical Whole Foods Market store, our 365 stores will be guided by the same industry-leading quality standards. As a second growth vehicle, 365 will be very complementary to our Whole Foods Market brand, allowing us to address the value-quality proposition in a new way while maintaining the integrity the Whole Foods Market brand represents in the marketplace. 365 President Jeff Turnas is building a top-notch team and has hit the ground running. We are excited today to announce leases for the 5 365 stores in Los Angeles, Santa Monica, Portland, Houston and Bellevue, Washington. These are all A+ real estate sites which meet our required EVA-hurdle return. We are currently targeting up to 5 365 store openings in the second half of next calendar year, with the expectation of doubling that number of openings in calendar 2017. With opportunities in new and existing as well as urban and suburban markets, most of our first stores are expected to be in the existing markets to better leverage our existing team member base and infrastructure. Our first 365 by Whole Foods Market store is scheduled to open in the Silver Lake area of Los Angeles, where we converted a lease and development from Whole Foods Market to 365. Los Angeles is the perfect dense urban market, where customers already love our quality standards and transparency to introduce our latest evolution focused on quality food and value in a convenient format. We're excited to reveal more as things develop. 
Turning now to our outlook for Q4, we have opened 2 new stores and expect to open 8 additional stores, including 1 relocation. If current comp trends continue, we would expect sales growth of approximately 7% and diluted earnings per share of $0.34 to $0.35. This outlook reflects current trends, as well as some headwinds from moderating inflation, increased cannibalization and our own value efforts. 
For the fiscal year, this translates to sales growth of approximately 9%, with comps in the low-single digits and square footage up 10%. We continue to expect EBITDA margin of approximately 9% and ROIC greater than 14%. For the next fiscal year, we are forecasting ending square footage growth of approximately 9% or 7.5% growth on a weighted square footage basis, reflecting a back-end-loaded store-opening schedule. We will provide additional details in our outlook next quarter. 
In summary, in this retail marketplace, which is more dynamic and competitive than ever, we believe we are taking the necessary steps to position ourself for the long-term. While we acknowledge it is taking longer than we would have hoped, we believe we continue to invest in our price relevancy, our marketing and our technologies the right strategy to regain sales momentum. We are encouraged by the unit lift we have seen from our price investments and will continue to expand on that strategy. We are committed to investing in marketing to support our value efforts as well as our brand and are excited by our new brand campaign this fall. 
Year-to-date, we have made progress in our digital and technology efforts to better serve our customers. We are live with both Workday for all of our team members, have launched our new iOS and Android mobile apps, refreshed our web experience and are testing and evolving our Affinity program. While still in the early stages, we have also piloted our new OnePOS and kiosk ordering for food menus and are rolling out labor scheduling to our customer service teams. We will continue to build out and enhance these efforts next year while also beginning to mobilize our new product platform, which will bring us many new exciting capabilities such as perpetual inventory, replenishment, space planning and price optimization. 
We remain focused on innovating and evolving to best serve our customers' diverse purchasing preferences in this rapidly changing marketplace. From the unique experience of our Whole Foods Market stores, to the growing online channel for home delivery, to the exciting launch of our 365 by Whole Foods Market stores, we are leaning in to extend our reach to new as well as existing customers. 
We will now take questions. Our call will end at 4:45 Central Time today to allow more time for questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

componenttext: Walter, when you look at the slowdown over the past 5 weeks, I guess, how can you guys be so precise that the New York audit is the primary factor? And I guess more importantly, what steps are you taking to fix the problem, given that it seems like it's bled into the first few weeks here of the fourth quarter?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chuck, well, again, I think in our -- in the script -- in the comments here we said that we -- look, I mean, we tried to give you the evidence in the chart there that kind of showed the breakdown of the quarter, of the weeks in the quarter, at the end of
componenttext: Chuck, well, again, I think in our -- in the script -- in the comments here we said that we -- look, I mean, we tried to give you the evidence in the chart there that kind of showed the breakdown of the quarter, of the weeks in the quarter, at the end of the quarter, the start of the quarter and the start of the new quarter to help you get some visibility into the impact of it. Clearly, it affected the comps. Clearly, there's other factors at work here too in terms of the headwinds from the previous year strong sales and so forth. But by any measure, it has significant impact on our sales. And with respect to the second part of your question, we've already taken the steps to again, this was in 9 of our New York City stores to upgrade the training processes right away, to employ -- to bring in a third-party firm to audit our procedures and results and improve those, and those steps have ready been taken. And in fact, we've been inspected subsequent times since without incident so all those things were already in place.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I would like to follow on to the last questions. The question isn't just how you get your people to do the right thing because clearly you've done that. The question is how do you change customer perception that somehow Whole Foods can't be truste
componenttext: I guess I would like to follow on to the last questions. The question isn't just how you get your people to do the right thing because clearly you've done that. The question is how do you change customer perception that somehow Whole Foods can't be trusted?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think that's a really fair question, Meredith, and there's no -- we're taking all the steps, even trust had us to be -- if trust is broken, it has to be rebuilt a step at a time and through solid execution day in and day out. And there's no
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that's a really fair question, Meredith, and there's no -- we're taking all the steps, even trust had us to be -- if trust is broken, it has to be rebuilt a step at a time and through solid execution day in and day out. And there's no magic bullet for restoring whatever trust was lost other than us being transparent about what it is, make sure you put this in context that this is something that every supermarket has. And that we've taken the steps and that we continue to convince our customers that we're doing the right thing by them each and every day. I mean, every store now has the customer pledge at the register, letting them know that if you have any concerns, all ask and we'll recheck and if you're dissatisfied, we'll give it back to you, whatever. So all of those things are in place. And I think it's just a matter of sawing wood and doing a good work day in and day out to continue to build that trust.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, John here. We don't think our track record is any different than any other supermarket. We're not sure why Whole Foods was singled out for this attention. We don't know why the media ran wild with this. Our error rates are very small, we've done
componenttext: Meredith, John here. We don't think our track record is any different than any other supermarket. We're not sure why Whole Foods was singled out for this attention. We don't know why the media ran wild with this. Our error rates are very small, we've done our own auditing. We put in procedures now so that we can perhaps be perfect. But we believe an objective evaluation, if you compare Whole Foods' record, these are inadvertent errors, and there's no systematic mistakes being made here. It's a very small percentage of our total product. It's just something that went viral in the media, and it has hurt our trust. And yet we do feel like we're victims of -- we don't know exactly why or the DCA went after Whole Foods like this. We're not sure why the media went crazy with it. But it did happen. We are taking steps to not give cause for this in the future. As far as reestablishing trust with our customers, there's no magic wand we can wave. We're giving -- we're going to do third-party audits, we're going to show it out, we're going to be transparent about it, and hopefully over time, the basic integrity of our company and the good customer service we provide will put this in the past and we'll move on past it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'll just say we're very encouraged by the results of our third-party audits. We're doing them across the country, not just on New York but everywhere and we're passing audit after audit. We're eliminating the few errors we do find. And our
componenttext: This is David. I'll just say we're very encouraged by the results of our third-party audits. We're doing them across the country, not just on New York but everywhere and we're passing audit after audit. We're eliminating the few errors we do find. And our team members are really active about this because they want to do right by their neighbors and their customers, and they're -- we're all over it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Meredith, you see the sales trends, you have them on the chart there. You can see, as Glenda said, it's too early, but it does. There is some hope that we're going back in the other direction now and we will -- the steps -- the additional steps we're t
componenttext: So Meredith, you see the sales trends, you have them on the chart there. You can see, as Glenda said, it's too early, but it does. There is some hope that we're going back in the other direction now and we will -- the steps -- the additional steps we're taking the bigger picture here to do, rebuild the momentum, the sales momentum of the company, which is in our pricing efforts, our marketing efforts, our technology and platform efforts, all those things continue, and to continue to do that. And we do have our additional brand campaign coming this fall, which again is an effort to kind of highlight what the company is all about and remind people what's different about Whole Foods Market.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we can take our next question from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we can take our next question from Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I just have a couple of questions. I guess the 30,000 square-foot size seems a little larger than I would have thought, and you did indicate it in the prepared remarks that they will be A+ locations. So I guess with that type of, like, location, how do
componenttext: So I just have a couple of questions. I guess the 30,000 square-foot size seems a little larger than I would have thought, and you did indicate it in the prepared remarks that they will be A+ locations. So I guess with that type of, like, location, how do you get comfortable that you can maintain your ROIC because obviously price points will be lower and rents seem like they're going to be in line with what you're paying at your Whole Foods format? And then I guess the 4 markets that you've indicated you're going to open, obviously you've also told us some rationale from that, but they are obviously, I guess close to existing Whole Foods store. So how do you think about the risk of cannibalization?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Karen, John here. We actually think we'll get superior ROICs with the 365 format. We're going to have significantly reduced capital investments as well as significantly lower labor costs. And of course, we don't know until we actually open some stores. Bu
componenttext: Karen, John here. We actually think we'll get superior ROICs with the 365 format. We're going to have significantly reduced capital investments as well as significantly lower labor costs. And of course, we don't know until we actually open some stores. But when we project this out, if we get anything close to what Whole Foods Market sales per square foot are in our new stores, the 365 stores are going to be incredibly profitable and with very high ROICs, even with reduced gross margins. I mean, will there be some cannibalization of Whole Foods? I mean, probably, but we don't know exactly how much until we do. It will probably be less than we open up an actual branded Whole Foods Market store because it's going to appeal to a little bit different customer, we think. So it is an experiment. We do have 5 stores committed. We have several other stores we are negotiating leases on. And a year from now, we're going to have a lot more data for you because we'll have some stores open, we'll see what they're doing, will see what the effects are, we'll see what our ROICs are. All I can say is we're super excited about it. We think we're going to have great stores, good locations, low gross margins, low labor, low capital investments and very high returns on invested capital, so.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other point I want to make is, with 365, we look at it as a hand and we feel like it's very complementary to being in the area of Whole Foods so that a customer has choices between going into a 365 or a Whole Foods depending upon the time, what they w
componenttext: One other point I want to make is, with 365, we look at it as a hand and we feel like it's very complementary to being in the area of Whole Foods so that a customer has choices between going into a 365 or a Whole Foods depending upon the time, what they want to accomplish with the shop. And so we're hoping that it captures both of their choices when they decide to go out and shop. So we're not -- we look at the cannibalization, we think it is going to be lower, but we also are really encouraged by the chance that we have to capture more trips that the customer would have shopping.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: This is David. Ken and I have been working really hard on the -- we're really excited about the Silver Lake design. I think one of your questions was about the size difference say between 25k to 30k, and we're kind of staying disciplined about what we're going to do with the 365 model. We have this concept we're calling Friends of 365 where we are actually talking to interesting local suppliers that might rent out a small part of the space. So again, our core store will be somewhere between 25,000 to 30,000, but we're also looking at opportunities to work with some local suppliers to give it some local flavor as well.

componenttext: And also just to follow up on the price investments, can you give any further color in terms of, are they coming from an expanded number of SKUs? Or is it more heavier cuts from still a relatively same select base? Can you give any color around that?

componenttextpreview: Yes, well, we've been -- I would say it's a little bit of both. We definitely have continued -- beginning of the year we started around the produce investments, which we've continued through the year. And we've added some additional ones in some categorie
componenttext: Yes, well, we've been -- I would say it's a little bit of both. We definitely have continued -- beginning of the year we started around the produce investments, which we've continued through the year. And we've added some additional ones in some categories, but it's been more of a constant work in primarily in produce, a little bit in grocery, a little bit in meat and seafood, where we've worked on prices, we've tried to really get ourselves very clear on pricing to the marketplace. We watch what's going on in the marketplace, adjust it for some of that. And it's kind of an ongoing process where we're happy with -- especially happy with the unit growth that we've seen in produce and in some of the other areas. And that's encouraged us to look forward to doing even more next year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: This is David. I also just want to say we really feel we're hitting our groove with our produce prices here in the Austin market and we're encouraged to roll out in other places in next year.
