componenttext: Okay. I guess, a slightly different direction, back on 365, I'm a little confused. Is the primary goal to capture new incremental customers who don't currently shop Whole Foods? Or is it to capture additional trips from existing customers because it seemed like 2 different real estate strategies.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's both, both, both.
componenttext: It's both, both, both.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hold up. Well, not to quibble with words, we never feel like we can capture any customers. At best, we can rent them for a little while if we continue to create value and service to them. But we do think the 365 is going to have some appeal to our existin
componenttext: Hold up. Well, not to quibble with words, we never feel like we can capture any customers. At best, we can rent them for a little while if we continue to create value and service to them. But we do think the 365 is going to have some appeal to our existing Whole Foods customer base because -- and maybe have a better -- in some cases, it will have a greater appeal to more value-oriented customer that we already have. But I think it's going to open up a whole new set of customers who so far have, for various reasons, have not liked Whole Foods Market, potentially because they think our prices are too high. There's no question 365 is going to have very, very competitive prices.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then real quick on the House passing HR 1599. Do you guys have any comments there or what the next steps are toward GMO labeling?
componenttext: Okay. And then real quick on the House passing HR 1599. Do you guys have any comments there or what the next steps are toward GMO labeling?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we know that the House passed it and we know that the proposal is that there would be -- USDA would set up programs and that no mandatory labeling would be required and if any laws were passed by states, they would be preempted. We know that it stil
componenttext: Well, we know that the House passed it and we know that the proposal is that there would be -- USDA would set up programs and that no mandatory labeling would be required and if any laws were passed by states, they would be preempted. We know that it still has to go to the Senate, and it could still -- the law could change from what it is currently. It may happen, it may not happen, we don't really know any of that. We made a -- we've made it very clear that we support labeling. We think it's important from a transparency standpoint. We've heard from a lot of our customers. And we know polls have shown that the majority -- the vast majority of Americans would like to know if there's GMOs in their products. So -- and we support the labeling because -- for people to know that. How it will affect us, we don't know. We're not exact 100% sure, but we don't think that it affects any of the current labeling that we have in place that we've worked with, the non-GMO project and are working with some other third-party verifiers. We think that, from the way we read the law, that they would be able to get -- the programs they're working with wouldn't be disrupted by this, and eventually, they could get accredited to continue to do what they're doing.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, my interpretation -- John here, is that it doesn't affect Whole Foods at all. Whole Foods is still committed to transparency regarding GMOs. We're going to continue doing exactly what we committed to do and we will hit our deadlines. My interpretatio
componenttext: Yes, my interpretation -- John here, is that it doesn't affect Whole Foods at all. Whole Foods is still committed to transparency regarding GMOs. We're going to continue doing exactly what we committed to do and we will hit our deadlines. My interpretation of reading that is they're basically trying to preempt states like Vermont and other states from creating their own GMO laws, so they're trying to prevent the states from doing that. It will not affect a private certification or Whole Foods' own efforts for transparency.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our last question from Mark Wiltamuth of Jefferies.
componenttext: And we'll take our last question from Mark Wiltamuth of Jefferies.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig in a little more on your produce price cut test markets. Our price surveys were showing that you were doing about 10% to 12% price cut in those produce areas. And initially it sounded like you're getting a double-digit volume lift there. Y
componenttext: I wanted to dig in a little more on your produce price cut test markets. Our price surveys were showing that you were doing about 10% to 12% price cut in those produce areas. And initially it sounded like you're getting a double-digit volume lift there. You now have some duration to it. Are you still seeing enthusiasm from customers now that the tests have been going on for sometime? And have you been taking some of those best ideas out to the other stores in the produce sections?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've often said -- we said in the past that when you make price adjustments and price investments in the produce department, there's lag time. It can take anywhere from 6 to 9 months until you start to see -- initially, you'll see a nice increase i
componenttext: Well, we've often said -- we said in the past that when you make price adjustments and price investments in the produce department, there's lag time. It can take anywhere from 6 to 9 months until you start to see -- initially, you'll see a nice increase in units, but you still may be negative in overall sales dollars because -- depending on how deep your price cuts are. So we've been very encouraged and started to see in the last couple of periods where the actual sales have gone positive, and those produce departments are comping positive now. So that the units now have increased in a lot of them above where the investment is. That's been very encouraging to us, and we definitely have plans to use those learnings in additional stores and regions as we go forward, especially next fiscal year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: And you had mentioned you're going to move beyond 5 markets. How many are you in now with the produce price cuts?

componenttext: They're currently -- the produce investments we did were in 5 regions. I mean, that's -- and that each regions has several markets that they're in.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Food's Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, it is my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Food's Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, it is my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey; and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey; and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth & Development; David Lannon and; Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer. As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. For easier comparisons, we will discuss our results excluding the asset impairment and restructuring charges. 
I will now turn the call over to John Mackey.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. I will briefly review the quarter, focusing most of my time today on the steps we're taking to communicate our differentiation and improve our value perception that fundamentally involved in our business. In Q4,
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. I will briefly review the quarter, focusing most of my time today on the steps we're taking to communicate our differentiation and improve our value perception that fundamentally involved in our business. In Q4, our sales increased 6% to a record $3.4 billion. We opened 10 stores, expanding our reach to 431 stores across 42 states and 3 countries. After appearing to stabilize early in the quarter, our comps moderated over the last 9 weeks, driven by changes in both traffic and basket size. Our EPS mix was driven in large part by weaker than anticipated sales. However, we still delivered a strong EBITDA margin of 8% and healthy cash flow from operations at $132 million, and our seasonally slowest sales quarter of the year. In the face of increasing competition, we are not standing still. It's highlighted in our press release we made measurable progress on many of our strategic initiatives over the past year, including using technology to deliver an improved shopping experience. For the fiscal year, we produced industry-leading sales per gross square foot of $970, over $1.3 billion in EBITDA; a record $1.1 billion in cash flow from operations; and a 15% return on invested capital. Through our strong balance sheet and robust cash flows, we self-funded our new store development and strategic growth initiatives while returning close to $700 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, ending the year with approximately $582 million in cash and investments. 
Whole Foods Market has been a driving force in elevating food consciousness and raising the bar on quality standards for 35-plus years. We have a proven track record of delivering long-term shareholder value, and our tremendous success has bred increased competition. Our partners at United Natural Foods estimated over 70,000 new points of retail from natural organic products over the last 3 years. In this dynamic and increasingly competitive marketplace, we recognize we need to move faster and go deeper in creating a solid foundation for our long-term profitable growth. Later, I will outline the decisive steps we are taking to enrich the customer experience and gain efficiencies on our overall cost structure. Promotions and price investments are an integral part of our conversation, but we are not participating in a race to the bottom. Some would say increasingly everyone is selling the same food and that price is all that matters. The reality is Whole Foods Market sells the highest quality food in the world, our standards lead the industry and our selection and in-store experience cannot be matched by the competition. Yes, we're going to be competitive on price where we need to be, but first and foremost, the Whole Foods Market brand stands for the highest quality selection service. We believe values matter. It is what our customers tell us they love most about us, and we're not going to change that. 
One of the things we're doing is launching 365 by Whole Foods Market, a complementary brand that will broaden our reach to new customers and new markets, guided by the same industry leading quality standards, our 365 stores will allow us to address the value quality proposition in a new way while maintaining the integrity the Whole Foods Market brand represents in the marketplace. There has never been a time where customers have had more interest in what they eat, where it comes from and who's growing it. I believe we'll look back in 2015 and recognize it as the tipping point of the food revolution in this country about the direct connection between what you eat, your health and well-being. 
At the same time, food retailing is rapidly evolving in new ways from online delivery in 1 hour to click and collect, to personal shoppers. Some now estimate online sales could grow from 2.5% of total food retail sales to 8% or $100 billion by year 2025. Going forward, we envision a fusion of the store experience and technology that the customer center. No one delivers the dynamic in-store experience that we do. We will keep innovating and creating environments where people can connect and find a sense of community in our stores and in the digital world. Our strategy revolves around leading the race to the top in terms of the differentiated customer experience, continuing to raise the bar on quality and selection, providing new levels of transparency and accountability and leveraging technology to deliver an improved shopping experience. As the consciousness about fresh, healthy foods is awakening and the ways in which people want to buy their food evolve, the market opportunity is continuing to expand. There will be more than one winner. It is not a zero-sum game. Our company mission, commitment to transparency and culture of innovation are more relevant and timely than ever and where our company is today is just a fraction of where we think we'll be 20 years from now. 
As I highlighted earlier, while we're making progress on many of our initiatives in this dynamic marketplace, we recognize we need to move faster and go deeper to rebuild traffic and sales and create a solid foundation for our long-term profitable growth. These are the steps we are taking to communicate our differentiation and prove our price perception and fundamentally evolve our business. One, we are committed to a fundamental restructuring of the cost side of our business and it's already taking steps from this direction. We have a plan to reduce expenses by a $300 million run rate by the end of fiscal year 2017. We are systematically looking at every aspect of our business to eliminate cost that do not produce value for our customers. We recently eliminated more than 2,000 positions, are transforming our purchasing operations to allow us to function more productivity, to be more competitive and better leverage our growing size and scale and are looking for similar opportunities in other key areas. We have also introduced a new labor scheduling tool to our customer service teams with plans to expand to additional teams over the next year. Number two, we will innovate faster to further differentiate the Whole Foods Market shopping experience with the focus on our exclusive brands and prepared foods. We are operating some of the highest volume restaurants in the country and no house brand comes close to the quality standards of our exclusive brand products. Totaling close to $5 billion or 1/3 of our sales, our exclusive brands and prepared foods are key differentiators for us and we plan to partner with our suppliers to widen our competitive advantage in these areas. As part of this initiative, we have created a new global vice president of culinary and hospitality position, which we expect to fill in the coming months. Number three, we will improve our value perception through increase promotional activity and selective and strategic price reductions. We will utilize new talent, tools and systems, as well as consumer insights, benchmarks and KPI progress reporting to better track how our promotions and investments resonate with customers and impact our results. Number four, we will support our differentiation value strategies through enhanced external marketing efforts. We will use media to support our pricing efforts across all major markets, clearly communicating not only our pricing investments but our quality as well. We will holistically address the way in which we communicate our value and values to our customers at every touch point, including our online, digital and social platforms. Number five, we will invest in digital strategies to convert the strong traffic we generate online into sales. We have integrated Instacart into our app. We'll soon launch a national sales flyer and we'll continue to make updates to provide more functionality and streamline our customer's digital experience. We've been very pleased with our Affinity pilot in terms of the information we were gathering and the sales lift it is generating. We are committed to the program and our plans to test additional markets to further enhance the customer experience and refine the economics before rolling it out nationally. Number six, we will invest in our technology platforms to provide a better shopping experience and enable us to run our business more efficiently. We will replace our disparate core legacy platforms with unified, scalable solutions. The roll out of one POS system to all U.S. stores by the end of calendar 2016 will provide faster checkout times, improved labor productivity and better data visibility across all channels. In addition, it will enable us to provide personalized offers and new experiences at checkout via our mobile app. We also just launched our groundbreaking partnership with In 4 to co-create a next-generation cloud base retail merchandising and supply chain management platform. Admittedly behind in this area, this new retail platform will be unlike anything available today and will bring us many new capabilities such as perpetual inventory, replenishment, retail space planning and price optimization. Number seven, we will launch our second growth vehicle, 365 by Whole Foods Market. With 8 leases signed to date, we plan to open 3 stores in fiscal year 2016 and up to 10 stores in fiscal year 2017. The time is right to take the high quality standards we have developed over the last 35-plus years and make them more broadly accessible through a streamlined, value-focused format and serve communities we would not be able to reach with our larger Whole Foods Market stores. Number eight, while we remain confident in our long-term growth potential, we will increase our square footage in a more moderate pace this year. Having consecutively accelerated store openings over the past 6 years, we plan to grow our square footage at a more moderate pace in fiscal year 2016. We will lessen -- which will lessen the negative impact of cannibalization on our comps and allow us to focus on the other areas we have outlined. Number nine, we will continue to affirm our culture. Our 91,000 team members are the heart and soul of our company and the not-so-secret ingredient in creating customer experience. We believe our full-time ratio is among the highest and our turnover is among the lowest in the industry. We will continue to invest in our team members' development and growth, including creating thousands of new jobs over the coming year. 
I will now turn to our outlook for fiscal year 2016, which reflects the impact of these initiatives. We remain focused on the metrics we believe are key to the long-term health of our business and for this fiscal year we are targeting. Sales growth of  3% to 5%; approximately 30 new stores, including 2 to 3 relocations and 3,365 stores; square footage growth of 7% or greater; EBITDA margin of approximately 8.5%; CapEx of approximately 5% of sales and an ROIC greater than 13.5%. Our results are highly dependent on comps which have been particularly difficult to predict in this competitive landscape. While we have seen some stabilization in our 2 year comp trends since the end of the fourth quarter, it has only been 5 weeks. We're hopeful that our comps will improve over the course of the year given our toughest comparisons is in the first quarter. And many of our sales building initiatives are still gaining traction or are planned to roll out later this year. The higher end of our sales outlook reflects a 2.8% 2 year comp in line with the current run rate and implies flat comps for the year, improving from negative 2% in Q1 to relatively flat in Q2 and Q3 to 3% positive by Q4. The lower end of our sales outlook reflects the possibility that comps could get marginally worse before they get better, with an inflection point later in the year. Primarily reflecting our value efforts, we expect the decline in gross margin, excluding LIFO, to be greater than last year's 45 basis points decline. While we have identified SG&A improvements of approximately 60 basis points, including the impact of the recent restructuring, we expect these savings to be more than offset by the cost of initiatives to drive traffic and sales, as well as higher occupancy, depreciation and other costs. Therefore, we expect to decline an operating margin of up to 75 basis points from the 6.1% we recorded last year, excluding charges. As we announced today, our board approved an additional $1 billion in stock buyback authority and our intent is to spend the majority of that in the first half of the year. Excluding an estimated $0.05 to $0.07 per share and net accretion related to these debt-financed buybacks, we expect EPS for the fiscal year of $1.50 or greater. We will be facing our toughest comp and earnings comparisons in the first quarter and estimate approximately a $0.01 per share in costs associated with the current recent restructuring. 
I know that we have shared a lot of information with you today, but before we open it up for questions, I want to underscore that we recognize we have our work cut out for us. We believe we're taking the necessary steps to regain our sales momentum, fundamentally evolve our business model and produce the returns that the investment community expects from us and that we expect from ourselves. 
We will now take questions. Our call will end at 4:45 Central time today. So to allow more time for questions, please limit yourself to one question at a time so everyone has an opportunity to participate. Thank you.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So my one question has to do with share buybacks. I just wanted to understand the rationale for taking on debt and buying back shares right now, maybe until, instead of waiting till maybe comp trends stabilize. So maybe you help us with your thought proce
componenttext: So my one question has to do with share buybacks. I just wanted to understand the rationale for taking on debt and buying back shares right now, maybe until, instead of waiting till maybe comp trends stabilize. So maybe you help us with your thought process.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We think Whole Foods is a compelling buy at these prices, the stock buybacks were going to be accretive in the short term and the long-term. And it doesn't preclude us from making further stock buybacks in the future if necessary.
componenttext: We think Whole Foods is a compelling buy at these prices, the stock buybacks were going to be accretive in the short term and the long-term. And it doesn't preclude us from making further stock buybacks in the future if necessary.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a perfect situation, Rupesh, this is Glenda, with interest rates being where they are and the long-term debt market being what it is, and our trading metrics, price trading metrics, relative to history being what they are and we have very strong cash
componenttext: It's a perfect situation, Rupesh, this is Glenda, with interest rates being where they are and the long-term debt market being what it is, and our trading metrics, price trading metrics, relative to history being what they are and we have very strong cash flow and are very confident in our ability to service the debt and to continue to fund our growth out of our own cash flow.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And also we restructured the debt in this way, the debt buyback. This way, we have the flexibility over time to use it as we want to use, when we want to use it.
componenttext: And also we restructured the debt in this way, the debt buyback. This way, we have the flexibility over time to use it as we want to use, when we want to use it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. I'm going to ask one more question, quickly. You laid out a number of sales initiatives in your prepared comments. So as you look out the next couple of quarters, what are the key sales initiatives you believe can help drive traction especial
componenttext: Okay, great. I'm going to ask one more question, quickly. You laid out a number of sales initiatives in your prepared comments. So as you look out the next couple of quarters, what are the key sales initiatives you believe can help drive traction especially on your top line as the fiscal year progresses?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: If we had a magic bullet, we've already shot it. We don't think there's anything we can do immediately except increased promotional activity that drives sales. We think it's kind of basic blocking and tackling. We've got a -- we're going to get back to ba
componenttext: If we had a magic bullet, we've already shot it. We don't think there's anything we can do immediately except increased promotional activity that drives sales. We think it's kind of basic blocking and tackling. We've got a -- we're going to get back to basics at Whole Foods, we're going to upgrade our customer experience, we're re-examining our business and we're systematically working basically to cut costs that aren't going to create value for our customers, and then we can invest a lot of that in promotions and into strategic lower prices. So part of it would be pricing, part of it is going to be marketing. We're going to support our strategic price investments and promotions with marketing around the country. So we're upping our marketing spend this year. And want to add some more color on that, David?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Operations, I would say, this is David, so we're really eyes on the price focusing on execution. So looking at our in-stock position, we have a new stock tool we have implemented across all stores to make sure that when our customers are in the store, the
componenttext: Operations, I would say, this is David, so we're really eyes on the price focusing on execution. So looking at our in-stock position, we have a new stock tool we have implemented across all stores to make sure that when our customers are in the store, they can always buy the products that they want. This is very helpful with our friends at Instacart to increase our now record sales through Instacart. So things like that, operations with the new labor scheduling tool, which we're expanding beyond customer service into our grocery department and our Whole Body department. So just-in-time scheduling to make sure we're really taking care of our customers and eyes in the price, focusing on results, focusing on operations.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other point I want to make, this is Ken, is bringing on the GVP of culinary hospitality and recognizing that prepared foods and bakery are significant differentiation points for us, having leadership around that where we set really strong guidelines a
componenttext: One other point I want to make, this is Ken, is bringing on the GVP of culinary hospitality and recognizing that prepared foods and bakery are significant differentiation points for us, having leadership around that where we set really strong guidelines around culinary expectations. We set the expectations on hospitality in our stores, really develop partnerships with restaurateurs that are going to create differentiation for us. We really feel that's going to be an incredible sales driver for us and a differentiation point for us over the next year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Meredith Adler with Barclays.
componenttext: We'll go next to Meredith Adler with Barclays.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would like to talk a little bit about the changes you're making in the cost structure, especially you talked about procurement in other areas. I mean, you have a very successful model of being regionalized. And I'm just wondering how do you maintain the
componenttext: I would like to talk a little bit about the changes you're making in the cost structure, especially you talked about procurement in other areas. I mean, you have a very successful model of being regionalized. And I'm just wondering how do you maintain the creativity, the great shopping experience, the localization if you centralize certain things to take costs out?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Meredith, that's such a good question, and there's very few questions that Whole Foods Market's thinking about deeper than that and continuing to dialogue about it, because we know we need to evolve our business model, and we know, in many cases, such as
componenttext: Meredith, that's such a good question, and there's very few questions that Whole Foods Market's thinking about deeper than that and continuing to dialogue about it, because we know we need to evolve our business model, and we know, in many cases, such as purchasing, we want to take advantage of our scale. We have a redundancy built into the system. So the art of what we're trying to do is we want to evolve the structuring in such a way that we take out redundancy in ways, and at the same time though, we're not diminishing the culture, the empowerment efforts that make Whole Foods Market special. That just means we have to proceed very thoughtfully, very carefully and we have to be very inclusive in making the decisions so the voices are heard. That means Whole Foods does move, sometimes can move a little bit slowly, but it means oftentimes we'll make better decisions because of the inclusive nature of it. But it was a good question because we are thinking deeply about it. And I think the fact that we're so conscious of it means that we're less likely to just do something inadvertently to screw it up. We are determined to evolve so we are going to evolve, but we're going to take the culture with it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. Just to add to that is yes, which areas we're looking at every single functional area across the company. Obviously at this point we've grown to be $16 billion year in sales, all those functions have evolved over time, as you see it in dif
componenttext: This is Walter. Just to add to that is yes, which areas we're looking at every single functional area across the company. Obviously at this point we've grown to be $16 billion year in sales, all those functions have evolved over time, as you see it in different ways as you see it in different ways and in different regions and so I think the company as a whole has come to a place now recognizing that there some of those things that don't need to be done in that way anymore that are best done together in one way, and then still identifying clearly those areas where they're close to the customers, where the innovation and where the freedom remains if that makes a lot of sense to do. So that's the nature of the conversation, so an answer to your answer to your question, we're looking at TMS HR, we're looking at marketing, we're looking at purchasing, we have a very evolved plan where purchasing is going to unfold and I think trying to capture the best of both world's in making those changes to pick up the savings, to pick up the advantage of our size and scale to function more efficiently in productivity, but still maintaining that wonderful freedom empowerment that store level team members to serve customers.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's David. Just a couple of examples to think about we also have the ability to eliminate some positions because we no longer needed based on technological things we put in our stores. So, for example, the new labor scheduling tool and the big stores, on
componenttext: It's David. Just a couple of examples to think about we also have the ability to eliminate some positions because we no longer needed based on technological things we put in our stores. So, for example, the new labor scheduling tool and the big stores, one of our big New York City stores we may have somebody working 40 hours a week on the labor schedule just for the customer service team, just the cashiers. Now we have our new system actually predicts the scheduling so we probably can reduce that to 20 hours instead of 40 hours. So that's just cost we can take out of the system without radically changing our culture at all.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: One more thing I'd like to add, specifically to purchasing, I do believe that there's been great strength in the decentralization that we've had in our purchasing teams, especially in the perishable areas. And at this point, we see pretty much the perisha
componenttext: One more thing I'd like to add, specifically to purchasing, I do believe that there's been great strength in the decentralization that we've had in our purchasing teams, especially in the perishable areas. And at this point, we see pretty much the perishables for produce, meats, seafood, they will still be largely directed by the regional teams with the global teams, helping them on that. So the real exciting stuff in the store is pretty much still going to be mostly run by the regional teams. It's really in the center store where we're looking at doing a lot more -- bringing a lot more responsibility for centers to our products at global -- the global team. Why they make sense is that there's -- we work with our very large center store suppliers and we feel like we can most efficiently work with them and get the best -- have the best partnership with them at the global level but there still will be a strong regional component. We're still going to have the regional folks very involved in those decisions. But we think that we can, by improving our overall functionality in that area, we think that we can come to a lot better decisions that really work across the company.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe turning to the other margin, the gross margin, just wanted to get a little bit more sense here. I know you said that you're expecting gross margins to be down a bit further next year as compared to this year. In the past, I know that, of course, pri
componenttext: Maybe turning to the other margin, the gross margin, just wanted to get a little bit more sense here. I know you said that you're expecting gross margins to be down a bit further next year as compared to this year. In the past, I know that, of course, primarily on value efforts, in the past, you said that there's basically some things you've done have kind of given a lift, that's one of the other things that you felt you probably didn't need to do. So could you just give us maybe a little bit more sense for whether it's by category product, et cetera, kind of you're learning so far in several quarters now that these value efforts have been more focused, kind of what's working the best? What you need to do so more work on and kind of the thoughts going into next year specifically?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, A.C., good question. What we have found when we look at -- we have been doing margin, some margin estimates over the year for the last 3 years. We ramped it up a little bit in '15 and plan on doing even more in '16. Where we've seen the best results i
componenttext: Hi, A.C., good question. What we have found when we look at -- we have been doing margin, some margin estimates over the year for the last 3 years. We ramped it up a little bit in '15 and plan on doing even more in '16. Where we've seen the best results is in whatever category it's in has been through promotions. We've done experiments with lowering everyday prices and doing set, trying to set certain categories in certain places, but we found, for the most part that our customers react best to promotional activity. And so that's where we really look to focus ourselves going forward. This past year, we did pick certain markets and we did a lot more produce promotions and we were happy with what we saw there. So we look to do more this year again and also across other teams as well.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll move next to Bill Kirk with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll move next to Bill Kirk with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, over 2 years ago, you talked about a common POS system and said it would take 18 to 24 months. And then I think you also said the loyalty card will be widely available for this holiday season. What caused those initiatives to fall behind by so
componenttext: So I guess, over 2 years ago, you talked about a common POS system and said it would take 18 to 24 months. And then I think you also said the loyalty card will be widely available for this holiday season. What caused those initiatives to fall behind by so much and does your current guidance for initiatives have, I guess have more conservatism around the timing?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, this is Jason. When we gave the initial guidance, we talked about what it would take to get into our initial stores. We're currently in 18 stores with a 1 point-of-sale program. We went to that first store at the beginning of this year and so we are -
componenttext: Hi, this is Jason. When we gave the initial guidance, we talked about what it would take to get into our initial stores. We're currently in 18 stores with a 1 point-of-sale program. We went to that first store at the beginning of this year and so we are -- we think we got a pretty conservative time line that we've put in our guidance for today. As it relates to the affinity program, as mentioned, we really are very positive on the results that we've seen so far with the program. Our opportunity here is to make sure that we've got one that has got the right cost structure in place for us, has the right win-win and value propositions for the customer. We're continuing to evolve a few more different tests and we are very optimistic on being able to bring this to all of our customers before the beginning of next calendar year, as you mentioned.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to David Magee with Suntrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: We'll go next to David Magee with Suntrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: What percentage of the stores square footage would you say right now, is that at an proper pricing level? And then as a second part to that, didn't you all have a marketing campaign you kicked off last year at this time? And I'm curious if that was pulled
componenttext: What percentage of the stores square footage would you say right now, is that at an proper pricing level? And then as a second part to that, didn't you all have a marketing campaign you kicked off last year at this time? And I'm curious if that was pulled back during the course of the fiscal year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We don't really know how to answer that first question, what percentage of our stores is at the right pricing level. Does anybody else -- I can't answer it.
componenttext: We don't really know how to answer that first question, what percentage of our stores is at the right pricing level. Does anybody else -- I can't answer it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we look at it more overall position I think as I mentioned earlier, we have a Sealand our tracks to invest strategically and systematically this year through both promos and lower prices but I think for competitive reasons, you would even more gen
componenttext: I think we look at it more overall position I think as I mentioned earlier, we have a Sealand our tracks to invest strategically and systematically this year through both promos and lower prices but I think for competitive reasons, you would even more general than that.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The reason that's quite a hard question this of that it is really different in different markets and different competitors. You look at some markets we feel may feeler appropriately priced in produce and another one we need to invest more, finance undersc
componenttext: The reason that's quite a hard question this of that it is really different in different markets and different competitors. You look at some markets we feel may feeler appropriately priced in produce and another one we need to invest more, finance underscores another one so it really varies a lot by region. But the thing is that what you do is you really look and see how your customers are reacting to a particular marketplace and when you look and see what dynamics are in that marketplace and then decide how you invest there. So it's really a varied process that goes on. I think for all retailers in that type of condition.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. The only thing I would say from operations as well as purchasing is it's a two-pronged thing, we focus on being competitive on prices but we're also focused on differentiation and customer advantage. We have a fully differentiated product l
componenttext: This is David. The only thing I would say from operations as well as purchasing is it's a two-pronged thing, we focus on being competitive on prices but we're also focused on differentiation and customer advantage. We have a fully differentiated product line like our meat standards, our prepared foods where we have scratch production unlike any of our competitors, we can press that advantage. We're trying to expand the amount of items that are not -- we don't have to be just price competitive on because they're fully differentiated. We're looking on all our product lines right now to see what products we could add to be fully differentiated.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We significantly improved our price tracking tools, our competitive tracking tools. We've expanded enough items in there, this team's got of that reporting that gives us every 2 week snapshot exactly where we stand relative to the various competitors and
componenttext: We significantly improved our price tracking tools, our competitive tracking tools. We've expanded enough items in there, this team's got of that reporting that gives us every 2 week snapshot exactly where we stand relative to the various competitors and the various markets as A.C. said. We got better tools than we've ever had to see exactly where we stand and where our price relevancy -- where we need to move on price relevancy. And also to underscore David's point about the strategy here is around being a quality grocer. We are the highest quality grocer in the United States, that's who we are, that's who we stand on, we're going to combine that price relevancy but we're going to stay on the fact that we sell the best stuff.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the marketing campaign, is this going to be a lot different than what you see this time?
componenttext: And on the marketing campaign, is this going to be a lot different than what you see this time?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that thinking in the coming right now, we have some other things to take care of and put in order. As we think through -- we've already thought through what we think that next message will be, but obviously, no it would be the same message we will
componenttext: I think that thinking in the coming right now, we have some other things to take care of and put in order. As we think through -- we've already thought through what we think that next message will be, but obviously, no it would be the same message we will be building on that with a new set of message, we should continue to work on from our core and our standards and our transparency and our quality but around why those really matter to the customer and our unique place in that. So we'll also have the new digital platforms available to us as well to carry this message. As I think somebody mentioned earlier we will be launching our digital next year that will be nationwide.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get it's a bit on the e-commerce front, and by the way, thank you for quoting e-commerce report the front of your comments. I want to find out how deep you are in Instacart right now, what percentage of your sales is derived from e-commerce ri
componenttext: I wanted to get it's a bit on the e-commerce front, and by the way, thank you for quoting e-commerce report the front of your comments. I want to find out how deep you are in Instacart right now, what percentage of your sales is derived from e-commerce right now? And how many of the stores are really covered by Instacart at this point?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jason. We don't actually disclose our percentage of sales at this point. We do have an all-time record high. We've just hit the $2.5 million mark, which is the average sales of our last 4 weeks. We also have over 50 of our stores right now that ar
componenttext: This is Jason. We don't actually disclose our percentage of sales at this point. We do have an all-time record high. We've just hit the $2.5 million mark, which is the average sales of our last 4 weeks. We also have over 50 of our stores right now that are part of our what we call embedded shopper program that provide in a delivery radius.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David, also I would say anecdotally we've got -- we've had stores up to 15% of store sales or closing in on $100 basket size for Instacart. So that's our individual stores, but it shows kind of a path where we can get to.
componenttext: This is David, also I would say anecdotally we've got -- we've had stores up to 15% of store sales or closing in on $100 basket size for Instacart. So that's our individual stores, but it shows kind of a path where we can get to.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: How do you stand on getting prepared foods rolled out?
componenttext: How do you stand on getting prepared foods rolled out?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've been doing a number of tests in that particular space. As you know, the time frames at which people want those are delivered are in a very immediate time. So it's something we have been testing out in store in San Francisco and look to scale various
componenttext: We've been doing a number of tests in that particular space. As you know, the time frames at which people want those are delivered are in a very immediate time. So it's something we have been testing out in store in San Francisco and look to scale various elements as we find success there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I think, you said you wanted Whole Foods to get back to basics. You talked about a lot of new interesting initiatives today. So I sort of wanted to figure out the balance on that. What have you been doing, that's not basic, so to speak, I don't know
componenttext: John, I think, you said you wanted Whole Foods to get back to basics. You talked about a lot of new interesting initiatives today. So I sort of wanted to figure out the balance on that. What have you been doing, that's not basic, so to speak, I don't know that need some distraction are not other efforts you'll pull back on cash to build out others, trying to get a sense of what may go away as you're starting new things?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Ken. So by basics, what I meant are blocking and tackling. I mean, retail ultimately always comes down to how satisfied the customer is. So it's about retailers detail, it's a cliché and it's a very appropriate one. Things like th
componenttext: That's a good question, Ken. So by basics, what I meant are blocking and tackling. I mean, retail ultimately always comes down to how satisfied the customer is. So it's about retailers detail, it's a cliché and it's a very appropriate one. Things like the level of customer service, the level of in-stocks we have in our products, how the stores look, the overall feeling they have when they're in the stores, the cleanliness of the stores, everything that has to do with upgrading the customer experience, from signage to the way we communicate, the messages to how the prepared foods taste. It's making sure that we're executing operationally at a very high standard. So that's what I mean by getting back to basics. That doesn't conflict with our need to evolve and to introduce a bunch of -- all these new initiatives and to evolve our business model. I think those are the complementary to each other, but they have to be on the foundation of very strong operations. I mean it's ultimately satisfied customers who are your best form of advertising that you have. They're the ones who tell their friends, the loyal customer comes back every week and their basket size is going up. I'm not going to say Whole Foods has neglected that, I don't think we've neglected it, but I think we need to up our game. We are going to get better at it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Working with our regional presidents who are doing a spectacular job on some of these cost reductions. They're really focusing on anything that takes the store team leaders out of the store. So think frugality first on travel and focusing on getting our s
componenttext: Working with our regional presidents who are doing a spectacular job on some of these cost reductions. They're really focusing on anything that takes the store team leaders out of the store. So think frugality first on travel and focusing on getting our store team leaders to eliminating days they're not in the stores and at the store level getting the store team leaders to focus on getting their leadership and their team members on the sales floor, out of backroom focus and really focusing on taking care of the customers, in-store shop conditions and just eyes on the price. Anything that's extra credit or distraction, we're refocusing that back to take care of our customers.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Walter, bookending on John's comments as if it you are looking at the base, you support that by fundamentally relooking at the way you do work. So that is the structure, jobs, that is the processes used, the redundancies that might exist, and you
componenttext: This is Walter, bookending on John's comments as if it you are looking at the base, you support that by fundamentally relooking at the way you do work. So that is the structure, jobs, that is the processes used, the redundancies that might exist, and you say to yourself how can we make this work simpler so the work we're really focused on customers and each other and continued tapping more efficient and productive way I think that's the effort of the overall look at the business. And I think the second thing is using technology because clearly, these investments, these 3 platform decisions we made whether it's work day or TMS or HR side, the 1 POS on the front end side and then also on the IN4 and supply and merchandising side, ultimately, those things are going to make work a lot easier to do with more transparency and ultimately supportive of having the team members be able to focus on the customer experience and the work happen more efficiently. So it's sort of combining the future ideas with the core, as John said. And a third, I think we all know now that the door of the store is not just the physical, it is also a digital door and we've got work to do take that same in-store experience that we have created so well over the years and take that and extend it onto the digital platforms where our customers come. We have 6 million visitors a month to our website. That's a pretty high number for a supermarket and relative to -- any think we have opportunities to convert those and to continue to build trips through that. So essentially extending our experience and having a digital door to Whole Foods as well as a physical store.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Edward Kelly with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Edward Kelly with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I like to just get back to a comment that you made earlier about not participating in a race to the bottom on price. I guess, if you look at the industry, someone like Kroger has proven over time, with Walmart that you don't need to be in line with compet
componenttext: I like to just get back to a comment that you made earlier about not participating in a race to the bottom on price. I guess, if you look at the industry, someone like Kroger has proven over time, with Walmart that you don't need to be in line with competition from a pricing standpoint to reach an equilibrium in total value. Sure, that applies to your model as well, but the real question here is just how are you thinking about the appropriate level of gross margin in this business? Longer-term, you used to talk about I think 34%, 35%. Where do we stand on that? Just your thoughts there would be helpful, I think.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: A good question, it's another good question because that's something we're continually started talking about and strategizing about and evolving our position on it. But first thing I would say is that a lot of the folks that are copying Whole Foods at thi
componenttext: A good question, it's another good question because that's something we're continually started talking about and strategizing about and evolving our position on it. But first thing I would say is that a lot of the folks that are copying Whole Foods at this point, they're not copying our quality standards. They're copying our look and feel and our marketing. And so far, it's a good strategy, it's working. Many customers are not looking before or not seeing the differences. So one of the challenges Whole Foods has to do better job at is communicating our superior quality. The differentiation, it's there, it's definitely there in the perishables from our animal welfare system and need to sustainable seafood, though our responsibly grown produce. We have to do a better job of connecting to our customers to get them to understand that these are not the same things. They may look quite like the same, but they're not. We don't want to have a race to the bottom, we don't want to compromise our quality and start cutting our quality to make us more competitive on price. Sure, if you're in an center store and if they have exactly the same items then we are absolutely right. We have to be price relevant, we have to be very close or matched on those items and we're working on that. So it's simultaneously we have to do a better job of communicating our differentiation and where we have price or thumbs are out of line. It is not appropriate, we have to be more competitive in those areas. And we are determined to do so.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think what we're seeing in our guidance today's we are taking aggressive, smart and strategic steps in this direction. We are not laying out the chapter and verse exactly where that's happening for competitive reasons, but you can see in the guidance th
componenttext: I think what we're seeing in our guidance today's we are taking aggressive, smart and strategic steps in this direction. We are not laying out the chapter and verse exactly where that's happening for competitive reasons, but you can see in the guidance that reflects the decline in the gross margin, reflecting aggressive activity. And so obviously, in your question, what we're saying is we're moving the needle this year. We probably expect to move the needle next year, although we have to see exactly what works, how it works, how the customers respond to the particular combination of value and quality. So I think we're focusing right now what we're telling you for fiscal '16 and how we see our steps taking there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: One of the challenges we've got, to be honest, is that, I mean, it's hard to comp $1,000 of square foot, it is a lot harder to build a high comp on that than it is to build a 4% or 5% comp with $500 a square foot. Just have a lot more running room. Stores
componenttext: One of the challenges we've got, to be honest, is that, I mean, it's hard to comp $1,000 of square foot, it is a lot harder to build a high comp on that than it is to build a 4% or 5% comp with $500 a square foot. Just have a lot more running room. Stores are less congested. It's just easier to do. And while we do think we can increase over comps, we do think we can increase our sales per square foot. It's just our success has become just a higher hurdle for us to jump over. And if you're starting in a lower base, many of our competitors are, it's easy to show a higher comp number. The question is, can you continue to show it? I mean, we showed 8%, 9% comps for 20 consecutive years, just about. So our challenge, and it's a big challenge, is what I started out by saying we have to do a better job of communicating our differentiation so the customers understand our quality superiority and at the same time, there are no significant differentiating advantages. There is no quality standard differential. A, that is a challenge to differentiate and up the quality standards, but in many cases, that is being more price relevant. Those are that 2 things we intend to do a better job at both going forward.

componenttext: This is actually Renato on the line for Chuck. So I just wanted to flesh of the price this is A.C. a little bit. Can you just give us some specifics in terms of what percentage of markets or stores you currently have incremental price investments in? What you're planning going forward, in terms of additional rollouts? Maybe what kind of elasticity you've been seeing in terms of these investments? And then finally, just your thoughts on how deep or broad-based the investments needed to be to get the desired effect on the volume front?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, A.C. here. I would say price investments, we've made across all of our stores. We did focus, as we said, we did focus certain produce price investments this past year in certain markets for 4 markets in particular and then we added a fifth one later i
componenttext: Hi, A.C. here. I would say price investments, we've made across all of our stores. We did focus, as we said, we did focus certain produce price investments this past year in certain markets for 4 markets in particular and then we added a fifth one later in the year. And we're happy with the results in that and are looking to maintain and expand that this year in produce. And we're also looking to do increased promotions throughout a lot of other parts of the company and specifically where we do them, it really depends on us as we were saying earlier, every market's different. And so we'll focus produce promotions more in some markets. We'll do more meat and seafood in other markets, grocery in other ones. It's really a very thoughtful, careful strategy that field in each market depending on the needs that we have there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttext: This is David, just one more thing I would say is one thing we have been learning over the last few months is that the more  promos that we do together, just almost that effect all company from our recent customer-focused test promotion that amplifies the effect because we can put it throughout the digital channels the connection on price of that price is marketed across the entire company. So we're looking at more, more ways that we can amplify by doing promotions together.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttext: I guess, that closed it off. again to reiterate what John said a band when we open up around, this team is really committed to rebuilding the sales momentum traffic and sales through these actions that we kind of laid out today. And the combination of not only the price investments and the promotions that A.C. talked about but also the strong communication of our differences and our quality, which is what sets Whole Foods Market apart, which is ultimately our winning strategy, I think, for our company. But make no mistake, the same recognizes we're not really want to be right now, in respect to sales, we intend to move on that and, hopefully, we'll have some our confidence from this conversation today exactly the steps that we're going to take.
