componenttext: What percentage of the stores square footage would you say right now is at in appropriate pricing level? And then as a second part to that, didn't you all have a marketing campaign you kicked off last year at this time? And I'm curious if that was pulled back during the course of the fiscal year.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We don't really know how to answer that first question, what percentage of our stores is at the right pricing level. Does anybody else -- I can't answer it.
componenttext: We don't really know how to answer that first question, what percentage of our stores is at the right pricing level. Does anybody else -- I can't answer it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we're looking more broadly at our overall competitive position. And as A.C. mentioned earlier, we're obviously laying out tracks to invest strategically and systematically this year through both promos and lower prices and -- but I think for compe
componenttext: I think we're looking more broadly at our overall competitive position. And as A.C. mentioned earlier, we're obviously laying out tracks to invest strategically and systematically this year through both promos and lower prices and -- but I think for competitive reasons, we would leave it more general than that.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: But also the hard -- the reason that's quite a hard question is that it's really different in different markets and different competitors. You look at -- some markets, we may feel we're completely appropriately priced in produce. In another one, we need t
componenttext: But also the hard -- the reason that's quite a hard question is that it's really different in different markets and different competitors. You look at -- some markets, we may feel we're completely appropriately priced in produce. In another one, we need to invest more. Another one might be fine in center store, and another one -- so it's really -- it really varies a lot by region and by -- so -- but the thing is that what you do is you really look and see how your customers are reacting to the particular marketplace, and then you look and see what dynamics are in that marketplace and then decide how you invest there. So it's really a varied process that goes on for, I think, for all retailers in that type of condition.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. The only thing I would say from operations as well as purchasing is it's a two-pronged thing. It's -- we focus on being competitive on prices, but we also focus on differentiation and press our  advantage. So we have a fully differentiated
componenttext: This is David. The only thing I would say from operations as well as purchasing is it's a two-pronged thing. It's -- we focus on being competitive on prices, but we also focus on differentiation and press our  advantage. So we have a fully differentiated product line like our meat standards, our prepared foods where we have scratch production unlike any of our other competitors. We could press that advantage, so we're trying to expand the amount of items that are not -- we don't have to be just price competitive because they're fully differentiated. We're looking on all our product lines right now to see what products we can add to be fully differentiated.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Having said, we significantly improved our price tracking tools, our competitive tracking tools. We've expanded the amount of items in there. This team has worked to upgrade all that reporting that gives us a 2 -- every 2-week snapshot and exactly where w
componenttext: Having said, we significantly improved our price tracking tools, our competitive tracking tools. We've expanded the amount of items in there. This team has worked to upgrade all that reporting that gives us a 2 -- every 2-week snapshot and exactly where we're standing relative to the various competitors and the various markets, as A.C. said. We got better tools than we've ever had to see exactly where we stand and where our price relevancy -- where we need to move on price relevancy. And also to underscore David's point about the strategy here is around being a quality grocer. We are the highest quality grocer in the United States. And that's who we are, that's what we stand on. And we're going to combine that with price relevancy, but we're going to stay on the fact that we sell the best stuff.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the marketing campaign, is this -- is the next one going to be a lot different than what you did last year at this time?
componenttext: And on the marketing campaign, is this -- is the next one going to be a lot different than what you did last year at this time?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the thinking was -- on the campaign is the timing was off to do it right now. We had some other things to take care of and to put in order. And as we think through -- we've already thought through what we think that next message will be. But
componenttext: Well, I think the thinking was -- on the campaign is the timing was off to do it right now. We had some other things to take care of and to put in order. And as we think through -- we've already thought through what we think that next message will be. But obviously, no, it won't be the same message. We'll be building on that with a new set of message. It's to continue to work off of our core and our standards and our transparency and our quality, but around why those really matter to the customer and our unique place in that. So we'll also have the new digital platforms available to us as well to carry those messages. Not just [indiscernible] but workers. Actually, I think somebody mentioned earlier, we'll be launching our digital flier next year that'll be nationwide. So...

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttext: I wanted to take a -- take it a little bit on the e-commerce front. I wanted to find out how deep you are on Instacart right now. What percentage of your sales is derived from e-commerce right now? And how many of the stores are really covered by Instacart at this point?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jason. We don't actually disclose our percentage of sales at this point. We do have an all-time record high. We've just hit the $2.5 million mark, which is the average sales of our last 4 weeks. We also have over 50 of our stores right now that ar
componenttext: This is Jason. We don't actually disclose our percentage of sales at this point. We do have an all-time record high. We've just hit the $2.5 million mark, which is the average sales of our last 4 weeks. We also have over 50 of our stores right now that are part of our, we call it, embedded shopper program that provide in a delivery radius.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. Also, I would say, anecdotally, we've got -- we've had stores up to 15% of store sales or closing in on $100 basket size for Instacart. So those are individual stores, but it shows kind of a path to where we can get to.
componenttext: This is David. Also, I would say, anecdotally, we've got -- we've had stores up to 15% of store sales or closing in on $100 basket size for Instacart. So those are individual stores, but it shows kind of a path to where we can get to.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And how do you stand on getting prepared foods rolled up?
componenttext: Okay. And how do you stand on getting prepared foods rolled up?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we've been doing a number of tests in that particular space. As you know, the time frames which people want those are -- delivered are in a very immediate time frame, so it's something that we've been testing out in our SOMA store in San Francisco and
componenttext: So we've been doing a number of tests in that particular space. As you know, the time frames which people want those are -- delivered are in a very immediate time frame, so it's something that we've been testing out in our SOMA store in San Francisco and look to scale various elements as we find success there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I think you said you wanted to -- Whole Foods to get back to basics. You talked a lot -- about a lot of new and interesting initiatives today, so I sort of wanted to figure out the balance on that. What have you been doing that's not, I guess, basic
componenttext: John, I think you said you wanted to -- Whole Foods to get back to basics. You talked a lot -- about a lot of new and interesting initiatives today, so I sort of wanted to figure out the balance on that. What have you been doing that's not, I guess, basic, so to speak? I don't know if that means it's been a distraction or what. And other efforts you'll pull back on as you sort of build out others. Just trying to get a sense of what may go away as you start new things.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Ken. So by basics, what I meant are blocking and tackling. I mean, retail ultimately always comes down to how satisfied the customer is. So it's about retail is detail. It's a cliché, and it's a very appropriate one. Things like t
componenttext: That's a good question, Ken. So by basics, what I meant are blocking and tackling. I mean, retail ultimately always comes down to how satisfied the customer is. So it's about retail is detail. It's a cliché, and it's a very appropriate one. Things like the level of customer service, the level of in-stocks that we have in our products, how the stores look, the overall feeling they have when they're in the stores, the cleanliness of the stores, everything that has to do with upgrading the customer experience, from signage to the way we communicate, the messages to how the prepared foods taste. It's making sure that we're executing operationally at a very high standard, so that's what I mean by getting back to basics. That doesn't conflict with our need to evolve and to introduce a bunch of -- all these new initiatives and to evolve our business model. And I think they're -- those are -- they're complementary to each other, but they have to be on the foundation of very strong operations. I mean, it's ultimately satisfied customers who are your best form of advertising that you have. They're the ones that tell their friends. The loyal customer comes back every week, and their basket size is going up. I'm not going to say Whole Foods neglected that. I don't think we've neglected it, but I think we need to up our game. We're going to get better at it.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Working with our regional presidents who are doing a spectacular job on some of these cost reductions. They're really focusing on anything that takes the store team leaders out of the store. So we're -- think frugality, push on travel and focusing on gett
componenttext: Working with our regional presidents who are doing a spectacular job on some of these cost reductions. They're really focusing on anything that takes the store team leaders out of the store. So we're -- think frugality, push on travel and focusing on getting our store team leaders to eliminating days they're not in the stores. And at the store level, getting the store team leaders to focus on getting those -- getting their leadership and their team members on the sales floor, out-of-backroom focus and really focusing on taking care of the customers, in-store shop conditions and just eyes on the prize. Anything that's extra credit or distraction, we're refocusing that back on taking care of our customers.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Walter. And I'd just add to your question, kind of bookending on John's comments, is that if you were to look at the focus on the base, but you support that by fundamentally relooking at the way you do work. So that is the structure, jobs, that is
componenttext: This is Walter. And I'd just add to your question, kind of bookending on John's comments, is that if you were to look at the focus on the base, but you support that by fundamentally relooking at the way you do work. So that is the structure, jobs, that is the processes we used, the redundancies that might exist. And you say to yourself, "How can we do this work? How can we make this work simpler so that the worker really focusing on the customers and each other and can continue to happen in a more efficient and productive way? And I think that's the effort of the overall looking at the business. And I think the second thing is using technology. Because clearly, these investments, these 3 platform decisions we've made, whether it's Workday on the TMS or HR side, the one POS on the front end side and then also on the Infor on the supply and merchandising side, all 3 of those things are going to make work a lot easier to do with more transparency. They're going to be ultimately supportive of having the team members be able to focus on the customer experience and the work happen more efficiently. So it's sort of combining the future ideas with the core, as John said. And third, I think we all know now that the door of the store is not just a physical, it's also a digital door. And we've got work to do to take that same in-store experience that we have created so well over the years and take that and extend it and -- onto the digital platforms where our customers come. We have 6 million visitors a month to our website. That's a pretty high number for a supermarket and relative to our -- and I think -- so we have opportunities to convert those and continue to build trips through that, so essentially, extending our experience in having a digital door to Whole Foods as well as a physical store.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Edward Kelly with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Edward Kelly with Credit Suisse.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I like to just get back to a comment that you made earlier about not participating in a race to the bottom on price. And I guess, if you look at the industry, someone like Kroger has proven over time, with Walmart, that you don't need to be in line with c
componenttext: I like to just get back to a comment that you made earlier about not participating in a race to the bottom on price. And I guess, if you look at the industry, someone like Kroger has proven over time, with Walmart, that you don't need to be in line with competition from a pricing standpoint to reach an equilibrium in total value. Sure, that applies to your model as well. But the real question here is just, how are you thinking about the appropriate level of gross margin in this business? Longer term, you used to talk about, I think, it was 34%, 35%. Where do we stand on that? Just thoughts there would be helpful, I think.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: A good question. That's another good question because that's something we're continually talking about and strategizing about and evolving our position on it. But first thing I would say is that a lot of the folks that are copying Whole Foods at this poin
componenttext: A good question. That's another good question because that's something we're continually talking about and strategizing about and evolving our position on it. But first thing I would say is that a lot of the folks that are copying Whole Foods at this point, they're not copying our quality standards. They're copying our look and feel and our marketing. And so far, it's a good strategy. It's working. Many customers are not looking [indiscernible]. They're not seeing the differences. So one of the challenges Whole Foods has to do better job at is communicating our superior quality, the differentiation. It's there. It's definitely there in the perishables from our animal welfare system and meat, to our sustainable seafood, to our responsibly-grown produce. So we have to do a better job of connecting to our customers to get them to understand that these are not the same things. They may look like they're the same, but they're not. And we don't want to have a race to the bottom. We don't want to compromise our quality and start cutting our quality to make us more competitive on price. Sure, if you're on center store, and these -- and if they have exactly the same items, then we are -- you're absolutely right. We have to be price relevant. We have to be very close or matched on those items, and we're working on that. So it's simultaneously, we have to do a better job of communicating our differentiation and where we have price or thumbs were out of line, it is not appropriate. We have to be more competitive in those areas, and we are determined to do so.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think what we're seeing in our guidance today is we are taking aggressive, smart and strategic steps in this direction this year. We are not laying out the chapter and verse exactly where that's happening for competitive reasons, but you can see in
componenttext: And I think what we're seeing in our guidance today is we are taking aggressive, smart and strategic steps in this direction this year. We are not laying out the chapter and verse exactly where that's happening for competitive reasons, but you can see in the guidance that it reflects the decline in the gross margin reflecting aggressive activity. And so obviously, in your question, what we're saying is we're moving the needle this year. We probably expect to move the needle next year, although we have to see exactly what works, how it works, how the customers respond to the particular combination of value and quality. So I think we're focusing right now what we're telling you for fiscal '16 and how we see our steps taking there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: One of the challenges we've got, to be honest, is that, I mean, it's hard to comp on a -- if your $1,000 of square foot, it's a lot harder to build a high comp on that than it is to build a 4% or 5% comp with $500 of square foot. We just have a lot more r
componenttext: One of the challenges we've got, to be honest, is that, I mean, it's hard to comp on a -- if your $1,000 of square foot, it's a lot harder to build a high comp on that than it is to build a 4% or 5% comp with $500 of square foot. We just have a lot more running room. Stores are less congested. It's just easier to do. And while we do think we can increase our comps and we do think we can increase our sales per square foot. It's just our success has become just a higher hurdle for us to jump over. And if you're starting in a lower base as many of our competitors are, it's easy to show a higher comp number. The question is, can you continue to show it? I mean, we showed 8%, 9% comps for 20 consecutive years, just about. So our challenge, and it's a big challenge, is what I started out by saying we have to do a better job of communicating our differentiation so the customers understand our quality superiority. And at the same time, we're -- there are no significant differentiating advantages. There is no quality standard differential. Well, a, that's a challenge to differentiate and up the quality standard. But in many cases, it means being more price relevant. And those are that 2 things we intend to do a better job at both of them going forward.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our final question from Chuck Grom with Sterne Agee CRT.
componenttext: We'll take our final question from Chuck Grom with Sterne Agee CRT.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Renato Basanta on the line for Chuck. So I just wanted to flesh out the price investments here a little bit. Can you just give us some specifics in terms of what percentage of markets or stores you currently have the perimeter price inves
componenttext: This is actually Renato Basanta on the line for Chuck. So I just wanted to flesh out the price investments here a little bit. Can you just give us some specifics in terms of what percentage of markets or stores you currently have the perimeter price investments in? What you're planning going forward in terms of additional rollouts? Maybe what kind of elasticity you've been seeing in terms of these investments? And then finally, just your thoughts on how deep or broad-based the investments may need to be to get the desired effect on the volume front?

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: A.C. here. We've made, I would say, price investments, we've made across all of our stores. We did focus, as we said, we did focus certain produce price investments this past year in certain markets for 4 markets, in particular, and then we added a fifth
componenttext: A.C. here. We've made, I would say, price investments, we've made across all of our stores. We did focus, as we said, we did focus certain produce price investments this past year in certain markets for 4 markets, in particular, and then we added a fifth one later in the year. And we are happy with the results in that and are looking to maintain and expand that this year in produce, and we're also looking to do increased promotions throughout a lot of other parts of the company. And specifically, where we do them, it really depends on -- as I was saying earlier, every market's different. And so we'll focus produce promotions more in some markets. We'll do more meat and seafood in other markets, grocery in other ones. It's really a very thought through, careful strategy that you do -- that we'll do in each market depending on the needs that we have there.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is David. I guess one more thing I would just say is that when we -- one thing we have been learning over the last few months is that the more  promos that we do together -- whereas promos that affect all company from our recent customer-focused Love
componenttext: This is David. I guess one more thing I would just say is that when we -- one thing we have been learning over the last few months is that the more  promos that we do together -- whereas promos that affect all company from our recent customer-focused Love Fest promotion that amplifies the effect because we can put out through all the digital channels the connection on price, so that price is marketed across the entire company. So we're looking at more and more ways that we can amplify by doing promotions together.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess to close it off. Just again, to reiterate what John said at the end when we opened up around, this team is really committed to rebuilding the sales momentum, traffic and sales through these actions that we've kind of laid out today. And the combin
componenttext: I guess to close it off. Just again, to reiterate what John said at the end when we opened up around, this team is really committed to rebuilding the sales momentum, traffic and sales through these actions that we've kind of laid out today. And the combination of not only the price investments and the promotions that A.C. have talked about but also the strong communication of our differences and our quality, which is what sets Whole Food Market apart, which is ultimately our winning strategy, I think, for our company. And so -- but make no mistake, this team recognizes we're not where we want to be right now with respect to sales. We intend to move on that, and hopefully, you'll have some more confidence from this conversation today exactly the steps that we're going to take.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttext: Okay. I want to thank everybody for listening in today. Please visit Whole Foods Market in-store and online for the best selection of fresh, healthy holiday meals. And join us in February for our first quarter earnings call. We look forward to updating you on our progress on our Q1 earnings call next February. The transcript of the scripted portion of this call, along with a recording of the call, is available on our website as well. Thanks for listening in. We'll talk to you next quarter. Bye.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Food's Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, it is my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Whole Food's Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, it is my pleasure to turn the conference over to Cindy McCann, Vice President of Investor Relations.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. On today's call are John Mackey and Walter Robb, Co-Chief Executive Officers; A.C. Gallo, President; Glenda Flanagan, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jim Sud, Executive Vice President of Growth & Development; David Lannon and Ken Meyer, Executive Vice Presidents of Operations; and Jason Buechel, Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer. 
As a reminder, all forward-looking statements on this call are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the expectations and assumptions discussed today. This may be due to a variety of factors, including the risks outlined in our company's most recently filed Form 10-K. 
Please note, our press release and scripted remarks are available on our website. For easier comparisons, we will discuss our results excluding the asset impairment and restructuring charges. 
I will now turn the call over to John Mackey.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. I will briefly review the quarter, focusing most of my time today on the steps we're taking to communicate our differentiation, improve our value perception and fundamentally evolve our business. In Q4, our sa
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindy. Good afternoon, everyone. I will briefly review the quarter, focusing most of my time today on the steps we're taking to communicate our differentiation, improve our value perception and fundamentally evolve our business. 
In Q4, our sales increased 6% to a record $3.4 billion. We opened 10 stores, expanding our reach to 431 stores across 42 states and 3 countries. After appearing to stabilize early in the quarter, our comps moderated over the last 9 weeks, driven by changes in both traffic and basket size. 
Our EPS miss was driven in large part by weaker-than-anticipated sales. However, we still delivered a strong EBITDA margin of 8% and healthy cash flow from operations of $132 million and our seasonally slowest sales quarter of the year. 
In the face of increasing competition, we are not standing still. As highlighted in our press release, we made measurable progress on many of our strategic initiatives over the past year including using technology to deliver an improved shopping experience. 
For the fiscal year, we produced industry-leading sales per gross square foot of $970, over $1.3 billion in EBITDA, a record $1.1 billion in cash flow from operations and a 15% return on invested capital. Through our strong balance sheet and robust cash flows, we self-funded our new store development and strategic growth initiatives while returning close to $700 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, ending the year with approximately $582 million in cash and investments. 
Whole Foods Market has been a driving force in elevating food consciousness and raising the bar on quality standards for 35-plus years. We have a proven track record of delivering long-term shareholder value, and our tremendous success has bred increased competition. Our partners at United Natural Foods estimated over 70,000 new points of retail for natural and organic products over the last 3 years. 
In this dynamic and increasingly competitive marketplace, we recognize we need to move faster and go deeper in creating a solid foundation for our long-term profitable growth. Later, I will outline the decisive steps we are taking to enrich the customer experience and gain efficiencies on our overall cost structure. 
Promotions and price investments are an integral part of our conversation, but we are not participating in a race to the bottom. Some would say increasingly everyone is selling the same food and that price is all that matters. The reality is Whole Foods Market sells the highest quality food in the world. Our standards lead the industry, and our selection and in-store experience cannot be matched by the competition. Yes, we're going to be competitive on price where we need to be, but first and foremost, the Whole Foods Market brand stands for the highest quality, selection and service. We believe values matter. It is what our customers tell us they love most about us, and we're not going to change that. 
One of the things we're doing is launching 365 by Whole Foods Market, a complementary brand that will broaden our reach to new customers and new markets. Guided by the same industry-leading quality standards, our 365 stores will allow us to address the value-quality proposition in a new way while maintaining the integrity the Whole Foods Market brand represents in the marketplace. 
There has never been a time where customers have had more interest in what they eat, where it comes from and who's growing it. I believe we'll look back on 2015 and recognize it as the tipping point of a food revelation -- revolution in this country about the direct connection between what you eat, your health and well-being. 
At the same time, food retailing is rapidly evolving in new ways from online delivery in 1 hour to click and collect, to personal shoppers. Some now estimate online sales could grow from 2.5% of total food retail sales to 8% or $100 billion by year 2025. Going forward, we envision a fusion of the store experience and technology with the customer at the center. 
No one delivers the dynamic and compelling in-store experience that we do. We will keep innovating and creating environments where people can connect and find a sense of community in our stores and in the digital world. Our strategy revolves around leading a race to the top in terms of a differentiated customer experience, continuing to raise the bar on quality and selection, providing new levels of transparency and accountability and leveraging technology to deliver an improved shopping experience. 
As the consciousness about fresh, healthy foods is awakening and the ways in which people want to buy their food evolve, the market opportunity is continuing to expand. There will be more than one winner. It is not a zero-sum game. Our company mission, commitment to transparency and culture of innovation are more relevant and timely than ever, and where our company is today is just a fraction of where we think we'll be 20 years from now. 
As I highlighted earlier, while we're making progress on many of our initiatives, in this dynamic marketplace, we recognize we need to move faster and go deeper to rebuild traffic and sales and create a solid foundation for our long-term profitable growth. These are the steps we are taking to communicate our differentiation and prove our price perception and fundamentally evolve our business. 
One, we are committed to a fundamental restructuring of the cost side of our business and have already taking steps in this direction. We have a plan to reduce expenses by a $300 million run rate by the end of fiscal year 2017. We are systematically looking at every aspect of our business to eliminate cost that do not produce value for our customers. We recently eliminated more than 2,000 positions, are transforming our purchasing operations to allow us to function more productively, to be more competitive and better leverage our growing size and scale, and are looking for similar opportunities in other key areas. We have also introduced a new labor scheduling tool to our customer service teams with plans to expand to additional teams over the next year. 
Number two, we will innovate faster to further differentiate the Whole Foods Market shopping experience with a focus on our Exclusive Brands and prepared foods. We are operating some of the highest volume restaurants in the country, and no house brand comes close to the quality standards of our Exclusive Brand products. Totaling close to $5 billion or 1/3 of our sales, our Exclusive Brands and prepared foods are key differentiators for us, and we plan to partner with our suppliers to widen our competitive advantage in these areas. As part of this initiative, we have created a new Global Vice President of Culinary and Hospitality position, which we expect to fill in the next -- in the coming months. 
Number three, we will improve our value perception through increased promotional activity and selective and strategic price reductions. We will utilize new talent, tools and systems as well as consumer insights, benchmarks and KPI progress reporting to better track how our promotions and investments resonate with customers and impact our results. 
Number four, we will support our differentiation and value strategies through enhanced external marketing efforts. We will use media to support our pricing efforts across all major markets, clearly communicating not only our pricing investments but our quality as well. We will holistically address the way in which we communicate our value and values to our customers at every touch point, including our online, digital and social platforms. 
Number five, we will invest in digital strategies to convert the strong traffic we generate online into sales. We have integrated Instacart into our app, we'll soon launch a national sales flyer, and we'll continue to make upgrades to provide more functionality and streamline our customers' digital experience. We have been very pleased with our Affinity pilot in terms of the information we were gathering and the sales lift it is generating. We are committed to the program and have plans for tests in additional markets to further enhance the customer experience and refine the economics before rolling it out nationally. 
Number six, we will invest in our technology platforms to provide a better shopping experience and enable us to run our business more efficiently. We will replace our disparate core legacy platforms with unified, scalable solutions. The roll out of one POS system to all U.S. stores by the end of calendar 2016 will provide faster checkout times, improved labor productivity and better data visibility across all channels. In addition, it will enable us to provide personalized offers and new experiences at checkout via our mobile app. We also just launched our groundbreaking partnership with Infor to co-create a next-generation cloud-based retail merchandising and supply chain management platform. Admittedly behind in this area, this new retail platform will be unlike anything available today and will bring us many new capabilities such as perpetual inventory, replenishment, retail space planning and price optimization. 
Number seven, we will launch our second growth vehicle, 365 by Whole Foods Market. With 8 leases signed to date, we plan to open 3 stores in fiscal year 2016 and up to 10 stores in fiscal year 2017. The time is right to take the high-quality standards we have developed over the last 35-plus years and make them more broadly accessible through a streamlined, value-focused format and serve communities we would not be able to reach with our larger Whole Foods Market stores. 
Number eight, while we remain confident in our long-term growth potential, we will increase our square footage in a more moderate pace this year. Having consecutively accelerated store openings over the past 6 years, we plan to grow our square footage at a more moderate pace in fiscal year 2016. We will lessen -- which will lessen the negative impact of cannibalization on our comps and allow us to focus on the other areas we have outlined. 
Number nine, we will continue to affirm our culture. Our 91,000 team members are the heart and soul of our company and the not-so-secret ingredient in creating our customer experience. We believe our full-time ratio is among the highest, and our turnover is among the lowest in the industry. We will continue to invest in our team members' development and growth including creating thousands of new jobs over the coming year. 
I will now turn to our outlook for fiscal year 2016, which reflects the impact of these initiatives. We remain focused on the metrics we believe are key to the long-term health of our business and for this fiscal year we are targeting: sales growth of  3% to 5%; approximately 30 new stores, including 2 to 3 relocations and 3 365 stores; square footage growth of 7% or greater; EBITDA margin of approximately 8.5%; CapEx of approximately 5% of sales; and an ROIC greater than 13.5%. 
Our results are highly dependent on comps, which have been particularly difficult to predict in this competitive landscape. While we have seen some stabilization in our 2-year comp trends since the end of the fourth quarter, it has only been 5 weeks. We're hopeful that our comps will improve over the course of the year given our toughest comparisons is in the first quarter, and many of our sales building initiatives are still gaining traction or are planned to roll out later this year. 
The higher end of our sales outlook reflects a 2.8% 2-year comp, in line with the current run rate and implies flat comps for the year, improving from negative 2% in Q1 to relatively flat in Q2 and Q3 to 3% positive by Q4. The lower end of our sales outlook reflects the possibility that comps could get marginally worse before they get better, with an inflection point later in the year. 
Primarily reflecting our value efforts, we expect the decline in gross margin, excluding LIFO, to be greater than last year's 45 basis points decline. While we have identified SG&A improvements of approximately 60 basis points, including the impact from the recent restructuring, we expect these savings to be more than offset by the cost of initiatives to drive traffic and sales as well as higher occupancy, depreciation and other cost. Therefore, we expect to decline an operating margin of up to 75 basis points from the 6.1% we recorded last year, excluding charges. 
As we announced today, our board approved an additional $1 billion in stock buyback authority, and our intent is to spend the majority of that in the first half of the year. Excluding an estimated $0.05 to $0.07 per share and net accretion related to these debt-financed buybacks, we expect EPS for the fiscal year of $1.50 or greater. We will be facing our toughest comp and earnings comparisons in the first quarter and estimate approximately a $0.01 per share in costs associated with the current -- the recent restructuring. 
I know that we've shared a lot of information with you today, but before we open it up for questions, I want to underscore that we recognize we have our work cut out for us. We believe we're taking the necessary steps to regain our sales momentum, fundamentally evolve our business model and produce the returns that the investment community expects from us and that we expect from ourselves. 
We will now take questions. Our calls will end at 4:45 Central time today. So to allow more time for questions, please limit yourself to one question at a time so that everyone has an opportunity to participate. Thank you.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.

componenttextpreview: So my one question has to do with share buybacks. I just wanted to understand the rationale for taking on debt and buying back shares right now maybe until -- instead of waiting till maybe comp trends stabilize. So if you can maybe help us with your thoug
componenttext: So my one question has to do with share buybacks. I just wanted to understand the rationale for taking on debt and buying back shares right now maybe until -- instead of waiting till maybe comp trends stabilize. So if you can maybe help us with your thought process.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We think Whole Foods is a compelling buy at these prices. These stock buybacks are going to be accretive in the short term and the long term, and it doesn't preclude us from making further stock buybacks in the future, if necessary.
componenttext: We think Whole Foods is a compelling buy at these prices. These stock buybacks are going to be accretive in the short term and the long term, and it doesn't preclude us from making further stock buybacks in the future, if necessary.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's sort of a perfect situation, Rupesh, with -- this is Glenda, with interest rates being what they are and the long-term debt market being what it is and our trading metrics, stock price trading metrics relative to history being what they are. And we h
componenttext: It's sort of a perfect situation, Rupesh, with -- this is Glenda, with interest rates being what they are and the long-term debt market being what it is and our trading metrics, stock price trading metrics relative to history being what they are. And we have very strong cash flow and are very confident in our ability to service the debt and to continue to fund our growth out of our own cash flow.

headline: Whole Foods Market, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
